PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That we the undersigned, having great concern that Canberra is now the ``Porn Capital'' of Australia and because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to introduce immediate legislation in support of existing State Legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over the importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes particularly in the A.C.T., with the open sale and/or hire of only G, PG, and M-rated video cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale or hire of R rated video-cassettes, so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated or ``N.V.E.'' rated video-cassettes, which would allow the legal sale and hire of hard-core pornographic videos for viewing in the homes of our nation, which would endanger our children; and
2. To give whole-hearted support to Senator Walter's Private Member's Bill to implement the recommendations of the Select Committee on Videos; and

3. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which contain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc., or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Solar Energy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is widespread community concern regarding
1. the almost total dependence in Australia on fossil fuels and their deleterious effects in producing the greenhouse phenomenon in the environment;
2. the proposal to spend millions of dollars on research into nuclear power, the production of which has in other countries proven expensive and dangerous; and
3. the lack of adequate funding for research into, and promotion of alternative renewable sources of energy, in particular, solar power.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
1. fund adequate research into production of a large scale solar energy for industry; and
2. encourage the use of known technology for hot water and space heating by tax incentives on solar heating equipment for houses and commercial buildings.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
if open not-for-profit Health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to
take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace Trust Fund Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
At present all Australians, including those who conscientiously object to war and the preparation of war, are required by law for a portion of their income tax to be spent on military use.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Peace Tax Trust Fund Bill 1989 which has been presented by Western Australian Independent Senator, Jo Vallentine. This Bill does not propose that anyone be permitted to withhold tax, but that the law should be changed to allow conscientious objectors to divert the military portion of their tax into more positive and socially useful programmes.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most womens' groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of Members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia.
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported.
that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the A.C.T. Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material.
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia.
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Knowles (from 146 citizens) and Parer (from 154 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Company Tax Collection System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's Budget decision to change the company tax collection system will be a crippling blow to many small businesses, already suffering as a direct result of the Hawke Labor Government's high interest rate policy.
The earlier remittance of company tax payments to the Government will substantially reduce the cash-flow position of thousands of small businesses.

Many small businesses will be driven under as a result of the Government's decision unable to find funds for both tax commitments and new stock, only able to borrow at record high interest rates and unable to claim any tax relief on such borrowings to meet their tax commitment. This having been placed on top of 23% interest and 3% Super etc etc. The Government's proposed changes to the company tax collection system has only been introduced as a greedy grab for more tax revenue.

The small business community would prefer the Government to completely abandon the proposal rather than make only minor alterations to the original Budget decision, which are not likely to alleviate the situation to any significant extent.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX 89
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned:
(1) are opposed to the holding of an Arms Bazaar, AIDEX '89, at the National Exhibition Centre in Canberra on 28-30 November 1989

(2) believe that it is inappropriate for Australia to seek to offset its balance of payments deficit incurred through the import of expensive and unnecessary military equipment by seeking to double military exports over the next three to five years

(3) regard it is offensive that on one hand we offer foreign aid to neighbouring countries to improve their material standard of being, while on the other hand the merchants of death seek to persuade their rulers to buy military equipment which is entirely inappropriate to the needs of the people
Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to cancel this exhibition just as its predecessor, PADEX, was called off in 1986, the International Year of Peace.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's attack upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has cast grave doubts over the future viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide much-needed service to the community, including particularly those in rural areas;
The proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will further jeopardise the viability of pharmacists;
The latest decision to slash PBS payments to pharmacists by an average of $1.05 per script is simply unacceptable and will force the closure of many pharmacies.

Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure adequate remuneration levels for pharmacists, so that they may be able to provide a high quality health care service which is the right of every citizen of Australia.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Parental Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned strongly object to the Legislation which is being recommended by Professor Duncan Chappel, Department of Criminology, that parental rights to discipline our children by spanking (if necessary), being taken from us.

If we are not allowed to discipline our children at home, in love and according to God's Word we fear that we will have a nation of completely rebellious children on our hands. God's Word says, `Spare the rod and spoil the child' and also that `Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child, but the rod of correction will drive it far from him''. We would therefore appreciate your consideration of our rights as parents to correctly and lovingly discipline our own children, and feel that if this right is taken from us we would lose the respect of our children.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before debate on this legislation was adjourned last night, I was putting a few figures to the Senate on the capital gains tax. The number of people who have to pay capital gains tax has increased over the last two years, and the amount of paperwork done by accountants in handling the sale of assets that attract capital gains tax has increased along with it. It was pointed out on 2 November by Senator Walsh in answer to a dorothy dix question that 23,225 taxpayers-0.3 per cent of Australians-were paying capital gains tax. We will give him the benefit of the doubt. He may not have had the latest figures, which should have been available, whether they were or not. The latest figure is that 64,453 individuals have paid capital gains tax in the last financial year. That is an increase of 2.8 times on last year. If one extends that to the financial year we have just completed, 1988-89, 177,000 Australians will have paid capital gains tax. Another year down the track, with the same percentage increase, 492,000 Australians will have to keep more and more records through the accounting profession. This may have been an unintended consequence of the Government's move to bring in capital gains tax but unfortunately it is with us.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many other unintended aspects of the capital gains tax. For instance, if one varies a partnership one becomes liable for capital gains tax-immediately if certain property was bought after 20 September 1985 and, if it was bought before that date, it becomes liable to capital gains tax in the next round. That includes variations to family partnerships. For instance, if a person decides to bring his or her son or daughter into the partnership of a small business it is deemed to be a variation of the partnership, a new valuation has to be made of the property and the next time around it is liable to capital gains tax. It is liable, of course, if the property was bought after 19 September 1985.

Last night I was talking about the impossibility of doing financial returns in 28 days, let alone the 15 days which the Government specified in the previous Bill. I believe that it will be impossible to do these returns even in 28 days, considering the amount of work the accounting profession will get all at once. It is one thing for the accounting profession to be snowed under with work but it also has to be paid. Unfortunately, it is the taxpayer who cops the accountant's bill on top of his tax. Of course, it would be much harder to put a taxpayer's profit for the last month of the financial year into dollars for the trading he has done in that time. After all, there is genuinely 30 days credit, from 30 June until 31 July, before one collects anywhere near all of one's profits for sales during that month.

Under the previous system provisional tax was paid in four instalments: by 15 August, 15 November, 15 February and the balance by 15 April. This was provisional tax for next year's income. That system worked very well for many years and, no doubt, would have worked well for years to come except that this Government wants to bring in the money earlier. The Government rides on the fact that there will be a saving in public debt interest (PDI) by bringing forward tax collections. I suppose that is a fact. But, on the other side of the equation, someone has to pay for it. In 1989-90 it is estimated that $11.5 billion will be collected in company tax. We are led to believe that, because of this legislation, early tax collections for this financial year will be $885m, largely paid by companies balancing their books early. In addition, there will be the $150m I mentioned earlier in 1991 for the same period. However, someone has to pay for this saving in the PDI. The interest bill, as a result of paying the tax earlier, will be removed from the Government and will be paid by the companies themselves. This will particularly affect small businesses which will have to pay increased interest as a result of borrowing to pay their tax earlier. As I said, this measure is a de facto income tax in its own right. Businesses will have to borrow money to pay tax which will not be tax deductable.

I move to self-assessment and the removal of the true and full disclosure provision. A self-assessment system for determining tax has operated in part since 1986. It operated virtually on a trial basis at the beginning but more so as time has gone on. Under this system, taxpayers lodge a return which is not subject to detailed technical scrutiny, with the Commissioner of Taxation calculating tax payable and issuing an assessment on the basis that the return is correct. Under the new provisions, firstly, companies will still be required to lodge a tax return, with less information than normal, showing taxable income and tax payable. Secondly, the return is to be lodged with the final payment, and an assessment is deemed to have been made on the day the return is lodged. Thirdly, the Government has removed the concept of true and full disclosure from the self-assessment system. Fourthly, the limitation period applying to amendments up or down on the taxpayer's liability has been increased to four years, except in the case of fraud and evasion. Previously it was three years where full and true disclosure was made. If that measure-that is, total disclosure-was not made, the Australian Taxation Office could amend it up to six years. Fifthly, the required period for the preservation of records for income tax purposes has been reduced from seven years to five. This is a measure I welcome. A lot of unnecessary paper can now be thrown out after five years rather than seven.

I have no comments to make on points one, two and five, but I have grave reservations about points three and four. Taking point three firstly-that is, the true and full disclosure aspect-it would be fair to say that, with more and more self-assessment being used, it is only a natural progression that this aspect could be eliminated. Certain sections of the accounting profession would say that it is only a natural progression for self-assessment to contain minimal amounts of figures and other information, but then it could never be deemed to be full disclosure. It could be deemed to be true disclosure, but not full exposure. Some people seem to agree that it could be done away with. However, I disagree with this notion. Though I agree with self-assessment in principle, it is of utmost concern to me that this provision in the Bill will do away with the protection afforded to honest taxpayers, especially those with limited resources. Correspondingly, the Commissioner will have greater discretion.

The next point I am concerned with is the question of contentious issues in taxpayers' returns. Senator Stone pointed this out last night. With self-assessment, even a contentious issue is taken to be correct for the moment of assessment. With the removal of full and true disclosure, there is no replacement protection for taxpayers from the substantial tax penalties in these cases. There is no mechanism for obtaining greater certainty from the tax system by way of binding rulings being obtained from the Commissioner. With true and full disclosure, there was protection where there were arguable issues. The position was that if one made a true and full disclosure on a contentious issue-it may not be a contentious issue, but a new interpretation-one could put in a tax return and the Commissioner would assess the return and give a decision on it. It is all well and good if he allowed something; if he did not, the assessment could be changed but there were no penalties.

Even under abridged tax returns, an option should remain for the taxpayer to have his or her assessment assessed and receive a definite ruling on a taxation matter which can have more than one answer. That option should be available to people whose returns are not necessarily contentious, but on which two answers could be given. We should bear in mind that under the new four-year amendment rule, a commissioner who gives a certain ruling this year may have a vastly different view in four years time. Ideas, political pressure, and media pressure can result in a changed view on the same facts. Hence, after looking at the same facts four years later, a commissioner or his staff could come up with a totally different interpretation.

There are further problems with this idea. For example, a small businessman puts in a tax assessment and the money remaining-the profit-can be invested further in his business. But if an assessment is contentious, one does not know whether the Commissioner is going to review it in four years time. One has to be careful to make sure that funds are available and that one does not have to borrow again if the Commissioner makes a different ruling in that four years. One would not only have to have the money to pay the extra tax, but also the penalties that go with it. That is a very important issue. That situation applies already to companies waiting for long term assessments.

I now move to the point of changing the three-year amendment rule to four years and the limitation applying to increasing a taxpayer's liability other than in the case of fraud. This also includes the reduction of liability. The Bill, however, will provide for the Commissioner to be able to seek an extension of this new four-year provision in the Federal Court of Australia. I have no trouble about that. It seems reasonable in principle, but it seems to me that there is no right for the taxpayer to put his view to the Court against the extension being granted. If the Commissioner seeks a tax liable variation beyond 20 per cent of the assessment, I believe the taxpayer has the right to appear before the Federal Court and put forward his case about why it should not be extended. I understand that if it is a liable variation which is less than 20 per cent, then he has not got that right.

It does not worry me if the Commissioner gets an extension in the case of dishonest taxpayers, I do not care if the extension is for 20 years. Leaving aside the case of less than honest taxpayers, the danger lies in a provision that the Commissioner can use to overcome inefficiency in his own Department. It would be simple for the Commissioner to appear before the Federal Court to ask for an extension on some pretence or other. The reasons that the Commissioner can ask for an extension are set out in the Bill. I do not have the time to go through them now, but they are quite varied and they can be used to get an extension simply if the Department is running behind time in carrying out field audits. I presume that most of the extensions asked for will arise from audits. If the Department is running behind and cannot deal with all the audits in time, it simply has to go to the Federal Court and apply for extensions to overcome its inefficiencies. Therefore, I believe that the taxpayer should have the right to appear and put his case.

The taxpayer must have the right to be advised of the Commissioner's intention to go to the Court so he can put his own case forward, if the liability is assessed at over 20 per cent, to test whether the Commissioner does have valid reasons to apply for an extension and not simply for the Department to be able to catch up with its work.

Finally, I turn to the Bill's provision for deductability of fees paid to tax advisers for income tax advice and disputing an assessment, tribunal fees and court costs. Especially added to this is the cost associated with audits by the Australian Taxation Office. The audit costs are so heavy these days that one is even able to take out insurance to cover the possibility of such an occurrence. The cost of an audit, even in a small or medium sized business, would be tens of thousands of dollars because one would have to have one's accountants doing the tax returns and in attendance all the time. Their charges do not come cheaply. The deductability for tax advice is an overdue measure and I congratulate my colleague Senator Watson for the results of the work he has done on this issue. He brought forward a private members' Bill and the Government adopted the idea.

In conclusion, I support the amendments moved by my colleague Senator Stone and emphasise my concerns about in some of the more nasty provisions of the legislation. I am looking forward to speaking on the finer points at the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is cognately debating three Bills relating to the tax area. They are the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989, and the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. There is very little that needs to be said about the last Bill. It simply provides legislative authority for the entry into force of comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and Papua New Guinea and between Australia and Thailand. Those are regular items that come before the Senate as Australia and other countries reach agreements in regard to taxation issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The important Bills that need some discussion here are the other two. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 is essentially a research and development (R&D) measure. It broadens, as the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) said in his second reading speech, the income tax concession for research and development project expenditure incurred after 20 November 1987. It also extends its availability for a further four years with deductions being allowed at a rate of 150 per cent to 30 June 1993 and at the rate of 125 per cent until 30 June 1995. It is worthwhile pointing out that this reflects on Australia's poor R&D record and on the attitude that the manufacturing sector and other sectors take in this country with regard to going into research and development projects in new technology for export development markets for developing new import replacement items. It may come as a shock to many people to recognise, when they look at Australia's record in R&D funding in comparison with many other countries, that Australia is well and truly down the list. We sit here on a daily basis and grizzle about the fact that we have a trade deficit, that we are not developing new export markets, that we are not developing new import replacement items, and then wonder why this is happening. The fact is that most other countries, particularly since the war, have taken much more extensive measures than have Australia and Australian industry in gearing themselves up for new markets and new technological developments.

It is not surprising that a country like Japan leaves Australia for dead in its technological and other developments when we consider how much money it was prepared to pour into investment opportunities. The Japanese Government, for example, after World War II made a conscious decision that it would make available to anybody who wished to borrow it, cheap money for researching and developing new products. Like Australia, prior to World War II Japan was very much a rural based economy. It knew in the middle 1940s that it could not continue in that way and, by a variety of devices, including not taxing the interest that Japanese people earned on savings that they put into Japanese banking institutions, Japan acquired a significantly large amount of money to be lent at low interest rates to those people who were interested in researching and developing new projects.

The Australian attitude has been somewhat different. By and large, if we do not give a 150 per cent tax deduction to people who are looking at R&D, they will not engage in those activities. The other problem that we face in this country is an attitudinal one. If Australian industry cannot produce the world's best mousetrap tomorrow, it has a tendency not to bother even looking into the matter. It leaves it to somebody else who will perhaps spend 10, 20 or more years in developing a system for new products and then wonder why we are left behind in international markets. It is about time that management, in particular, recognised that productivity and developing new markets are its responsibility. It should stop blaming the work force, high wages and high taxes in this country, when its colleagues in other countries-for example, those in Europe-have been prepared to face much higher taxes than here. It should get off its backside and do a bit of work, spend a bit of money, look a little further forward than the next election and produce the sorts of goods that Australia needs to get itself out of its economic malaise.

It is with some irony, but nevertheless approval, I suppose, that we see the Government extending those R&D incentives to business and industry for a further five or so years. I hope that one day we will see a situation in Australia where industry does not have to be given a 150 per cent tax deduction before it is prepared to put its money where its mouth is, to stop whingeing about how we are non-competitive and to start getting around to some research and some development of new export items and import replacement items.

Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) is a different kettle of fish entirely. It contains some essentially non-controversial matters such as the land tax deductability of fees paid for the management and administration of a taxpayer's income tax affairs, enabling more people to get the advantage of the special tax exemption given to qualifying fixed interest approved deposit funds and so on under the May 1988 changes. Those are non-controversial and have not caused any particular comment either in this place or in the House of Representatives.

However, the Bill does two things which are regarded as significantly controversial. It is introducing a new system for the collection of company tax and it is moving to extend to companies the self-assessment procedure that currently applies to pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers. We have heard a great deal from the Opposition with regard to both proposals, in particular, quite rightly, with regard to the originally proposed new system of collection of company tax-including, by the way, from superannuation rollover funds-that was announced by the Government on Budget night. That announcement has since been significantly amended, due in no considerable part to the pressure that has been applied to the Government by non-government parties. In many ways, that change to the collection of company tax can be regarded as nothing much more than a one-off revenue-raiser that the Government perceived as being a good idea at the time. But it seemed not to take into consideration the considerable and very undesirable impact the changes were likely to have on small business. The Government decided to change the current system and bring forward the payment of company tax without taking into account in any real way, apparently, the cash flow problems or the credit access problems that are facing many small businesses in Australia.

Until Budget night, companies with a tax liability of $1,000 or more paid their tax in four instalments spread over the year following the income year. The Government then decided that it could accumulate quite a nice little one-off nest egg if it changed that system and made the new arrangements such that the quarterly tax payments were replaced by a new system whereby all companies were required to pay 85 per cent of their notional tax in a single instalment due 15 days after the end of the income period. For most companies that meant 15 days after 30 June; that is, they were expected to produce 85 per cent of their notional tax on 15 July with the remaining 15 per cent being paid nine months later. The reason for this, if Mr Keating's calculations are anything to go by, was that this would produce something a little less than a billion dollars for this financial year's revenue and that the Government would save some $330m in public debt interest because it would get that $885m earlier and would therefore have to borrow less. However, it did not take into account the enormous pressure that this was going to apply to many small businesses.

Companies under the proposed arrangement were to get only 15 days from the end of the financial year to estimate their tax liability and then to produce 85 per cent of that to the Commissioner of Taxation. That meant that tax agents and accountants were going to be inundated with requests to calculate just exactly what their clients' corporate tax liability was and they were expected to do it in little more than two weeks. That is significantly unrealistic in any terms. Bringing forward a tax payment of this size will mean that companies will be forced to reduce their working capital to pay their liabilities. In many cases, they are likely to face the problem of borrowing the money at a time when, as small companies, they are facing cash flow problems of no small consequence-all of this happening at a time when company sales and profits are generally falling because the Government, one can only assume deliberately, has engineered a sort of mini-recession through a massive hike in interest rates.

These small companies are facing some quite severe financial problems. Anybody who knows anybody at all in small business will tell us that the normal 30-day credit that small businessmen allow people who buy their products has been extended, to all intents and purposes, to a de facto 60-day credit, simply because the people they sell to are having trouble meeting their own repayments. This means that the suppliers of the original small business are being asked to wait while business A waits to collect from business B.

They have a couple of options: they can stop selling to people who will not pay in less than 30 days, which immediately affects their own sales and profitability, or they can borrow or lift their overdraft rate in order to meet the demands from their suppliers. Neither of those is a particularly acceptable mechanism. To then have thumped on them a requirement that 15 days after the end of their income period they had to pay 85 per cent of their notional tax to the Government was an appalling imposition. Most of them would have been forced to borrow that money. That, in itself, would have increased their own debt problem, but it would have also placed-when one considers how many small businesses in this country are pushed into that position-enormous pressure on the lending institutions. That almost inevitably would have forced interest rates even higher than they currently are. I do not know who dreams up some of these ideas in Treasury or the Tax Office, but certainly he or she needs a long, quiet holiday somewhere because coming up with this kind of scheme effectively is going to kill one of the few geese in this country that is still laying a few golden eggs; that is, the small business community, with its employing prospects and its ever decreasing profitability.

It was with ironic pleasure, I suppose, that we noted that eventually the Treasurer, Mr Keating, got the message from small business and on 2 November announced that companies with a notional tax of a significantly higher amount than that did not need to comply. The Government decided that companies with a notional tax of between $1,000 and $20,000 could elect to pay the total actual tax liability on 15 December, instead of 85 per cent on 15 July, and 15 per cent nine months later. In the debate in the House of Representatives, Dr Hewson moved an unsuccessful amendment to increase the threshold for 15 December full payments from $20,000 to $80,000. That would have been a permanent amendment to the tax Act-or as permanent as amendments to the tax Act ever are in this country. The Government, jollied along, I presume, by the fact that the Treasurer was overseas, then decided to go even further and it introduced two more amendments. It increased the $20,000 threshold for 15 December full tax paying companies to $400,000. That, in itself, makes one wonder exactly who, if anybody, is thinking up there and what he or she is thinking about. We have jumped in two moves from $1,000 to almost $500,000 in what the Government is prepared to allow companies to earn before they have to bring forward. What in heaven's name is going on in some government departments?

TALK.START.PARA: —Their taxable income has jumped from $2,500 to $1m.
—Exactly-from $2,500 to $1m. There is certainly something bizarre going on in Treasury or the Tax Office.
—They still have not costed it.
—Of course they have not costed it. It was obviously a move undertaken under considerable stress and with even less thought than when the original move was made.
—What do you think their motive was?
—I am not even sure they know what their motive was.
—Sheer expediency.

—Senator Stone says, `Sheer expediency'. Maybe this indicates that we will have a February election; I do not know, and I do not much care except that it is an indicator of the incapacity of some decision-makers in government and in the instrumentalities that advise government to make bizarre decisions for single instance increases in the Government's revenue raising without looking at the ramifications for the greater economic context of this country and, in particular, the part played in that by small business.

SPEECH.PARA: So, the Government increased the $20,000 threshold, having previously increased the $1,000 threshold to $400,000, but it did so only for the 1990-91 tax year. So it is a transitional measure only. I am concerned about that because that will mean, albeit with at least a year's warning this time, that companies will have to bring forward their tax payments the following year. The Government also altered the initial tax payment date from 15 days after the end of the year of income to 28 days after the end of the year of income. I suppose that we should be grateful for small mercies.

I am disappointed that the Opposition is not pursuing the Hewson amendment as a request from this place. I understand that the Opposition is not continuing with that amendment. At the very least it could have been put by the Senate as a request for the Government to make the changes in the 1991-92 year so that there were increased thresholds of earnings and notional tax applicable after the one year's grace, if one can call it that, that the Government has introduced through this one-off system that will take us into the next financial year.

The other concern that has been expressed about the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) is that it has extended to companies the self-assessment procedure that applies to PAYE taxpayers. I have had absolutely no correspondence from people in the business sector with regard to their concerns for self-assessment. At least, if I have done, it has slipped by me without my noticing it, and that is a fairly unlikely event. I do not think that it will cause the sorts of hassles and concerns that some members of the Opposition believe it will. PAYE taxpayers have been subjected to self-assessment since 1986. All that this Bill does is extend that system to companies. Under self-assessment, taxpayers calculate their own tax payable, lodge a return and at some stage may or may not be subject to an audit. I can only assume that there are a few people lodging company tax returns who are a bit bothered by the idea of suddenly being hit by an audit. If that is the case, maybe they will get only what they deserve.

Despite what it sounds like, self-assessment does not mean that people can choose to pay whatever tax they deem to be appropriate to the Tax Office, although I am sure that there are many ordinary individuals who would not mind being able to have a self-assessment procedure of that sort so that they can decide what they think the Tax Office deserves to get from them, and pay it accordingly. Treasury would be reduced to collecting next to nothing if that were the case. Self-assessment does not mean that a person sits down and assesses what he or she would like to pay, it essentially means that--

TALK.START.PARA: —You assess what you are liable for.

—People assess what they are liable to pay-what the Government is likely ultimately to drag out of them, whether or not they are kicking and screaming at the time, is irrelevant-and they have to pay that accordingly. What it essentially does is free up some resources that have otherwise been used within the Tax Office for other purposes in audit coverage. Maybe the concern of some members of the business community is that while tax officers are not tied up in going through individual company tax returns, they are going to be much freer and there will be many more of them able to undertake audits of companies they suspect of using tax loopholes or complicated tax systems to avoid paying the sort of tax that is their due. I think the revenue implications of this, therefore, could be quite considerable in several ways. First of all, substantial tax and penalties are earned from taxpayers caught engaging in avoidance or evasion practices. In the 1988-89 tax year the Australian Taxation Office audit program raised a little under $1 billion in extra revenue. That is something to be applauded. Nobody likes people who cheat on their tax. If there was, in that year alone, something like $1 billion-$910m, in fact-raised through tax audits, we ought to acknowledge that there are a lot of people out in the community, in companies and elsewhere, who are either deliberately or perhaps inadvertently, but much more likely the former, reducing their tax liability by a variety of means which are frowned upon by the Government and ought to be frowned upon by everybody else in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite what some people think about the tax system, it is the revenue that provides us, if it is spent properly, with decent hospitals, decent schools, roads, research and development funding, if necessary, and so on. If the money is not raised it cannot be spent. I, like a lot of members of parliament, get letters from people complaining about the tax they pay, and similar letters from other people complaining that the Government is not spending enough on one service or another. One cannot have it both ways. To have some people, particularly major companies, avoiding their social responsibilities to the tune of $910m in the 1988-89 tax year is something that we ought to be concerned about. The increased audit activity is likely therefore, just by being there, to encourage-shall we say-better compliance with the tax laws, maybe by those companies who are worried about being audited, and certainly by those companies who have already been audited and found that they have had to pay back-tax plus a penalty.

The Australian Democrats are not at all concerned about the implications of self-assessment for companies. It can only mean that those companies who have been avoiding paying tax by whatever means in the past will be forced to pay that money. If we were living with a benign government, and in an ideal world, that means that the tax paid by the rest of us may even be reduced. Maybe some of us will live to see that happen.

Our major concern with the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) lies with what is going to happen down the track to small companies who are forced to comply with the bring forward requirements under this legislation. The one-year reprieve that most of them will get under the second of the Government's two amendments is fine as far as it goes, but I would like to hear from other Opposition speakers why they are not proceeding with the Hewson amendment, which we certainly would have supported by way of a request to the Government from this place. We cannot amend tax laws in the Senate but we can certainly request that the House accede to an amendment put forward by the Senate. In 1981 we had singular success in doing that with some sales tax laws that the Fraser Government introduced.

We still have a way to go in this second reading debate and a considerable way to go in the committee stage. I ask Senator Baume and Senator Short, if he has not already spoken, to indicate whether the Opposition will see fit to raise this amendment by way of a request and put some pressure on the Government to acknowledge that a one-year stand-off is not going to help small businesses. If it can by degrees raise the original level from $1,000 to $400,000, and the profitability level from $2,500 to nearly $1m, and if it can do that for a single year, it ought to be prepared to acknowledge that there will be subsequent problems in the 1991-92 tax year and do something to protect small businesses from that. They are, at the moment, to a major extent, the ones feeling the pinch in the business community from economic pressures as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tries to keep the economy at the tight level that it currently is at. It is, therefore, incumbent on us to make sure that not too many of them go down the gurgler with the subsequent loss of services to the community, of choice to the community, and of employment in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills that we are debating cognately today, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989, and the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, are a package which collectively imposes some very significant changes to the taxation of certain sectors of the Australian community, in particular the small and medium business community. I want to address my remarks today entirely to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and specifically to one part of that Bill. It is a very broad ranging and important Bill. It amends the Income Tax Assessment Act in many ways, including in relation to the collection of taxation, returns of income and the franking of dividends. It also amends the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 and the Taxation Administration Act 1953.

SPEECH.PARA: Before getting into the detail of what I propose to speak about, the point must be made that, despite the amendments that the Government has introduced to this Bill since its contents were first announced in the Budget-and there have been two amendments proposed by the Government since then-this Bill will still have quite draconian effects on small and medium sized businesses, certainly after the next financial year. It continues what I believe has been a quite vicious tax attack on the small and medium business sector in this country over recent years.

In many ways small and medium businesses have been raped by the Commissioner of Taxation and by the Government to enable it to gain revenue to pay off its mates and do all the other sorts of things that have become the hallmark of this Government through its refusal to take broadly based and necessary measures of economic policy action, at both the macro and the micro level. We have had significant debate on the micro-economic reform failures of the Government in recent days. I do not propose to go over that again today. So far as I understand, there was no consultation at all with the business community in the development of this package of Bills that we are looking at. That is an approach that compares very vividly with matters which may affect the trade union movement. Then, of course, there seems to be total consultation and, indeed, in most instances, total capitulation to the views of the trade union movement.

If one looks at the treatment accorded the trade union movement, one can see what the Government and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) mean by so-called tax equity, because there have been huge taxation changes affecting the private sector in the past couple of years. The most notorious example perhaps-and it is one that I cannot comprehend the Government getting away with, and I do not believe it will continue to get away with it to the extent it has-is the enormous changes of a detrimental nature for all of us in relation to the taxation of the superannuation industry, at a cost of literally billions of dollars to the Australian community through the treatment of superannuation funds and superannuation companies. Perhaps that has been the most notorious of them but there have been many other examples as well, several of which are reflected in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989.

But if we look at the taxation treatment of the trade union movement over the last couple of years, we find a staggeringly different situation. It is not hit by these changes; it is exempted from the capital gains tax; and it is not hit by the fringe benefits tax. Indeed, we have a series of proposals designed to pull forward the revenues from thousands of small and medium sized businesses. In the process there is no doubt that we will see thousands of these businesses sent to the wall while the favoured half of the family of the labour movement-namely, the trade union movement-is left totally exempt from these taxes.

The amendments that the Government has moved to its original Budget proposals will not fundamentally alter the situation that confronts the small and medium sized business sector, other than in the first year. I wonder whether the small business community has really caught up with the fact that the amendments-and particularly the second amendment proposed by the Government, obviously hastily concocted for opportunistic, political reasons with an election coming up, but an amendment that was rushed into the House of Representatives on 22 November-will apply only for the first transitional year and, thereafter, the full draconian thrust of the Government's proposals will come into force. So for the Government to say that it has taken account of the fundamental concerns of the small and medium sized business sector in relation to the change in the tax payment arrangements is to state an absolute lie other than in the first year.

The Treasurer has continued the arrangement whereby the bulk of company tax will be required to be paid in two instalments: the first payment, being 85 per cent of notional tax, will be due on 28 July in the year following the year of income; and the final payment will be due in March of the following year; that is, in relation to companies that have a notional tax liability of $20,000 or more, and those are the companies that I am basically concerned with, at least in my contribution to this debate. The Government, in its amendment, said-and I am quoting from the explanatory memorandum:
as a transitional measure, the $20,000 threshold referred to above will be $400,000 for the year of income ending 30 June 1990;

I repeat: it is only in the first year. That contrasts very markedly with the proposal that was put forward by the Opposition in the House of Representatives when this Bill was debated there on 22 November, whereby the Opposition proposed that the tax liability limit be raised from $20,000 to roughly the equivalent of $80,000. In other words, a company with a taxable income of $200,000 or less would be exempt from these new changes in payment arrangements. Of course, that was a proposal of an ongoing nature which would have applied from one year to the next; not just the transitional year that the Government has introduced. I have considerable sympathy with the comments of Senator Haines in this debate, but that is a matter for the Opposition spokesman on taxation matters to comment on further.
The costing of the Government's changes I also find difficult to follow because we now have three. In the Budget, the Treasurer said that the changes then proposed would:
. . . bring forward $885 million in revenue this year but, more significantly, will generate an ongoing saving in public debt interest of about $330 million per year.

Between then and the Bill actually being formulated and coming into the House of Representatives in November, that assessment of $885m in this year and $330m for each year thereafter has been changed, according to the explanatory memorandum that was available to members of the House of Representatives when they were debating this Bill, to $880m this year and $150m in ensuing years.

I can understand the reduction of $5m from the Budget figure of $885-that is as a result of the minor amendment that was made and announced by the Treasurer on 2 November-but I do not understand how the $330m that was mentioned as the ongoing saving in public debt interest after the first year could conceivably have fallen as a result of that first amendment, the 2 November amendment, to a figure of $150m-that was the figure shown in the House of Representatives explanatory memorandum-because there is no way that that minor change of 2 November could have had that effect. I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to explain how that change could have arisen, and how it is that despite the second and more considerable transitional year amendment that has subsequently been announced, the figure for the ongoing revenue gain will remain unchanged at $150m a year.

Those figures just do not add up. It is an indication of several things. First of all, it is an admission that the Government has rushed into these changes without any real idea of what they will cost. My guess is that the Government did not have a clue as to what effect the original proposal would have. Certainly, it is quite obvious from the subsequent figures that we have been given that they must be regarded as rubbery in the extreme.

The other point that needs to be made about the changes that the Government is now proposing is that despite the cost to the revenue of the subsequent amendments, particularly the amendment of 22 November, no explanation has been given to the Parliament as to how that revenue loss will be funded. Presumably it will be funded simply by allowing the Budget net outturn to change accordingly, and that is in marked contrast to the way in which the Opposition has approached the amendment in the interests of the small and medium sized business sector that was produced in the House of Representatives on 22 November. We said that our concession to the revenue would be fully funded by the cancellation of the totally unjustified payment to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd as a quick-fix political deal and by the equally and, indeed, more notorious payment to the airlines to enable them to try to keep sweet with the trade union movement and to preserve the accord. So our amendment was fully funded. It has been properly costed. It is not transitional; it is an ongoing proposal, and the Government's proposal, as I said, does not really solve the problem at all. We have in this legislation a continuation of a savage attack by this Government on the small and medium sized business sector. It is not just an attack through the taxation system; it continues an ongoing attack on the business sector, particularly the small and medium sized business sector--

TALK.START.PARA: —Pharmacists are another example.

—As Senator Stone says, the pharmacists are a classic example when it comes to the Government changing the rules of the game, changing the playing field supposedly to make it more level. But, as we all know, that is absolute nonsense. The playing field has not been made more level; the Government has progressively disadvantaged those very sectors of our economy which we are going to rely on to get us out of the dreadful hole that the Government's economic policies have dug for this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the small and medium sized business sector, along with families, that have suffered the worst of all blows from this Government, as a result of the incredibly increased burden that the interest rate structure has imposed on them-a direct result of the mismanagement of this Government. The changes to the tax arrangements proposed in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) compound the interest rate problems that the small business sector is already facing because meeting the payment arrangements being proposed by the Government in this legislation will cause most small and medium sized businesses, after the transitional year, to have to borrow very heavily indeed immediately after the conclusion of their financial year-and they are already paying interest rates of between 21 and 25 per cent. The pressure that will be put on the financial markets and therefore on interest rates as small and medium sized businesses have to go to the market to meet their tax liabilities will be enormous. I doubt whether the Government has given the slightest consideration to the impact of these taxation proposals on the financial markets, particularly during that seasonal period in July of each year after this first transitional year.

I am sure we have all received numerous representations of concern from small and medium sized businesses about these proposals. They are very genuinely and logically based objections. I have here a copy of a letter from a company that wrote to the Treasurer on 1 November-before the amendments were introduced, but the thrust of the letter is still entirely relevant. It is from the Rider Hunt group of construction cost consultants and quantity surveyors in my own State of Victoria. It is a letter very representative of many of the other letters I have received. It is a letter to the Treasurer expressing concern about the proposals contained in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and makes the point, which has been made by many speakers on this side of the House during this debate, that not only will there be great pressure on companies to borrow to meet their tax requirements but also there will be difficulty in arriving at a figure within, now, 28 days of the end of the financial year and producing accounts which will give a reasonably accurate indication of their taxable income. I wish to quote several paragraphs from the letter:

By the middle of every month we prepare a profit and loss statement for the previous month and this enables us to monitor our performance to ensure that our business is running efficiently and any problems are picked up very quickly.
The monthly profit and loss statement is by no means an audited or final figure as many other factors have to be taken into account in the overall assessment of our profits for the year.

Such items as bad debts, fees accrued reserve, interest in the parent Company, overseas cross holding with Hong Kong and New Zealand are all factors that our accountants review when finalising our profits for the year. Any of these items can have quite a significant effect on the profit figures for the year.

The letter goes on to make a very important point; one that has been commented on by other speakers, including Senator Stone, and I know that Senator Michael Baume and Senator Messner are greatly concerned about this:
You-
that is, the Treasurer-

will therefore realise that although by approximately the 15th of every month we do have some idea of our profits this cannot be considered as a figure on which we would be prepared to finally commit ourselves for taxation purposes.

Therefore to impose a fine of considerable proportion if there is an error of 10 per cent is draconian to say the least and undoubtedly this, together with the earlier collection of tax, will lead to the bankruptcy of many small businesses.

You appear to be proposing a law that will seriously affect the small business community in Australia and I strongly urge you to reconsider, with your parliamentary colleagues, the arrangements proposed.

Normally it takes us approximately 6 months to finalise our accounts and I would not consider this to be an unreasonable period in which to allow a business to provide a proper profit and loss statement on which to calculate tax.

That is a statement reflected by hundreds-or more-of similar letters that I know we have all received and that I assume the Government and its advisers have received since these proposals were announced. The amendments introduced on 22 November, I repeat, in no way tackle the problems of the small and medium sized business sector, other than in the first transitional year. The fundamental problems will be ongoing. This Bill is a very bad Bill. It is a Bill the thrust of which is quite contrary to what this country needs. We should not be giving handouts through tax benefits or in any other way to the business sector, but for heavens sake why are we squeezing and squeezing that very sector of our economy which we require and which we are all urging, hour by hour, to be more productive and more efficient so it can be more competitive in a highly and increasingly competitive international environment? Why are our Government policies doing quite the opposite of what is really required? I join other Opposition speakers in strongly criticising this Bill, and I have pleasure in supporting the amendment moved by Senator Stone on behalf of the Opposition that, at the end of the motion that the Bill be read a second time, we add the following words:
``, but the Senate:

(a) condemns the Government for its flagrant disregard in its taxation policies of the circumstances faced by many small businesses in Australia, as typified by its original 1989 Budget decision on company tax collection; and
(b) rejects the Government's proposals on self-assessment of company tax because of the inadequate safeguards to protect the integrity of taxpayers''.

The Opposition has raised many points in this debate-and there is much else it could say-but this amendment puts our position very clearly. I hope that the Government will take account of some of the comments made in the debate before it finalises the enactment of this legislation. If it does not, it will be adding just another set of nails to the coffin of the small and medium sized business sector of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what Senator Short has been saying and I certainly support the Opposition's amendments to this legislation. In particular, I point out to the Senate that this legislation represents the latest instalment in the Government's non-stop succession of mistakes. It has the capacity to mess up legislation, particularly taxation legislation which has involved non-stop changes and fiddles. Not only have we had a situation where the legislation has been announced months before it has arrived in this place but we then have the situation where, after it arrives before the Parliament, it gets changed and changed; in this legislation in three months we have had three versions of what the threshold should be. What sort of certainty does that give to the taxpayers? What sort of confidence does it give to anyone that this Government knows what it is doing or that the Australian Taxation Office knows what it is doing? In this legislation we are now giving the Taxation Office even more discretion.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to be a knocker of the Tax Office or a knocker of the Government but the fact is that I am sick and tired of having legislation come into this place that has to be dramatically amended because the Government does not understand. The legislation itself is prepared by people who do not understand and by a Government that does not understand the real impacts of this kind of thing on the private sector. We have continual change, continual mess, continual uncertainty and, I might say, increasing discretion to the Commissioner of Taxation. It is totally unsatisfactory. We have a situation here where the industry was simply not consulted. It was a sort of confrontation approach as to how to go about doing this sort of thing.

I remind the Senate that in the days when Mr John Howard was the Federal Treasurer, there was a Taxation Advisory Committee so that there were top practitioners-not only competent but totally honourable men, as the experience of that Committee demonstrated-who provided the Government with advice. So it did not make the sorts of silly continual mistakes that this Government has been making in the area of tax.

This Government is too arrogant to consider that the private sector would have any capacity to provide honest, decent and useful input. The fact is that if this Government were a little less arrogant, a little less concerned about papering over the cracks in its own policies-by artificially bringing forward, as this legislation does, close to $900m of revenue to make its surplus look a little more respectable this year-it would be a little more concerned about the impact of its policies and its actions on the private sector which is struggling to recover and to succeed in an environment where, as a result of this Government's policies, interest rates for small business in particular, are up around the 21 to 25 per cent mark. This Government should have more concern about what is really happening in the real Australia and less concern about its own arrogance, its own determination to be seen to be having a level of surplus that happens to make it look good, a level of surplus achieved not by cutting its own expenditures enough but by continually increasing tax revenues. That is what this legislation is all about. It is by increasing the level of tax, in this case company tax, that will make the surplus look bigger this year.

It is simply a timing device. But the timing device does a few other things. It massively increases business costs because the money has to come from somewhere, and it will come largely from borrowings. The people who will pay tax will have to pay interest on the borrowings to meet that tax. I will go into that later. How it will be established, how the Tax Commissioner will determine that X amount borrowed at a particular time is in fact for the purpose of paying tax which is not deductable as against being borrowed for the purpose of carrying out business, how it will make that subtle brilliant distinction we do not know because there is no statement from the Tax Office about how this is going to be administered. All these brilliant things we have to leave to the discretion of the Commissioner. I must say that I find this whole approach of a basic lack of understanding of the reality of the small businesses environment-in fact, of the total private sector-to be massively disappointing. It is a matter that has shattered the confidence of business at a time when it is already shattered by this Government's incompetent monetary policy, by its failure to take the fiscal measures that have meant that Australia's external debt is so huge and, as a result, that interest rates are so massive and now, of course, our bankruptcies are on the up and up, despite Government Ministers quaint attempts to try to prove the other day that the bankruptcies were going down.

Senator Haines made some good points. I must say that I do not usually acknowledge that she has made good points because generally she has not. But this time she has because she correctly noted that the big changes in this legislation were forced on the Government by the non-government parties. The coalition of course was to the fore. It is no coincidence that on that very day the Government made this latest change-22 November-when it said, `Yes, the Opposition has been right. It is an unfair burden so, as a temporary measure during this transition period, we will not have such a low threshold which is $20,000, we will increase it to $400,000'. Is it not quaint that that happened on the very day that the Opposition moved an amendment to the second reading motion in the House of Representatives calling on the Government to increase substantially the threshold to which the two new instalment company tax arrangements will apply. The very day that the Opposition went out and said what it would do to fix this up, the Government magically discovered that it could increase that particular threshold to $400,000. No costing was mentioned, of course. If ever the Opposition puts up any proposal the Government says, `Yes, but what will it cost?' and tries to damage the credibility of Opposition statements because the Government says either the costings are not there or they are not realistic. This Government has not even provided a costing on this latest change. Apparently, it does not know what it will cost. If it does know it is not prepared to say. If it does not know it is incompetent; if it is not prepared to say then it is deceptive. It is about time that this Government came clean and did say what the reality is now that the changes have been made in a temporary way.

I must say that I look forward to a situation where, early in the new year, a new Government will take office and this mess will be fixed up properly. Dr Hewson in the House of Representatives on 22 November introduced that amendment requesting the level be increased substantially-it was defeated by the Government, of course-but then, later on that day, the Government substantially increased the cut-off level. Apart from the hypocrisy of that, I would have to say that we, as an Opposition, have given this clear statement through Dr Hewson, the shadow Treasurer, who will be the next Treasurer early in the new year whenever the Government calls the election. Dr Hewson has said:
We do not like this legislation . . . we undertake . . . to review . . . this legislation in government.

He went on to say that we would meet the cost of our decision to increase these thresholds this year by reversing the Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd decision and by terminating the payment of compensation to the airline industry-in other words, paid for out of the special handouts this Government has been spraying around in an attempt to placate special interests that have been disadvantaged by a whole range of activities, including some of the Government's. The following second reading amendment moved by Dr Hewson was defeated in the House of Representatives:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) recognising the plight of small businesses in Australia, calls on the Government to increase substantially the threshold at which the new two instalment company tax arrangements will apply;
(2) rejects the Government's proposals on self-assessment of company tax because of the inadequate safeguards and protection of the integrity of taxpayers; and
(3) condemns the Government for its flagrant disregard in its taxation policies of the circumstances faced by many small businesses in Australia''.

Senator Haines indicated that she wishes that we were proceeding with that amendment. As I understand it, she would have supported at least the first part. That has been withdrawn for the very simple reason that the Government has substantially increased the threshold, as I understand it, beyond the one that we suggested. We were moving to amend the Bill to remove the impact of this tax on the small business sector, particularly on companies with taxable incomes of up to $200,000. The Government has now gone beyond that but in a specific and limited way. It is only a transitional proposal.

Quite frankly, there is no need for us to move our original amendment now because the simple fact is that that transitional arrangement will survive for the current tax year. By the time the next tax year comes around, from 1 July, there will be a coalition government. We have said that we do not like this legislation and we have given a clear undertaking to review it in government. As I said, there is no need to proceed with the amendment moved in the House of Representatives, because we will fix the matter up. There is no point in having this amendment beaten once again in the House of Representatives. The Government has already expressed its lack of understanding by rejecting that very sensible amendment that we moved in the House of Representatives only last month.

I am really concerned about the way the Government has handled this legislation. Apart from the fact that in three months it has had three totally different views about the appropriate way to adjust both the timing of the payments and the threshold, all of us have every reason to be totally cynical about these changes since the Budget announcement. The increase in the threshold is only for the transitional year. Clearly it is being done because there will be an election early next year. There appears to be no other reason. The Government has not said, `Yes, it is a serious and permanent problem that the Opposition has raised'. Not on your life! It has said, `Yes, there is a problem in the transition period'. The transition period magically happens to be the period in which there will be a Federal election.

Is there any reason why the Opposition or the people of Australia should be anything other than cynical about this decision temporarily to recognise the problem? As I understand it, the Government intends to restore the $20,000 threshold-the disaster threshold-in a year's time if it is still in power. Of course, it will be saved that problem because it will not be. But the straight cynicism involved in appearing to protect the interests of small business whilst cynically doing so for a period that just happens to cover an election is a bit rich, even by this Government's standards.

The costing of this interests me. Some rough figures have been prepared showing that the Government's proposals will cost about $120m this year and close to $200m next year. We have not heard from the Government about that. It would be nice if the Government would let us know whether those figures are reasonable. If so, it means a reduction in the forecast surplus for the current year and this will be totally unfunded. There has been no statement about where it will come from. That is in stark contrast to the coalition's economic statement, which funded everything. There was no way this Government could establish any flaws of any substance whatsoever in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan, which involved significant tax benefits to the family and a basic and major change in the approach that governments are allowed to have to taxation by assuring and guaranteeing the people of Australia that no longer will they be subject to the bracket creep that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has imposed on Australians, pushing them all into higher tax brackets every time there is any inflation-and our inflation rate is roughly double that of our trading partners. That bracket creep has resulted in about $13 1/2 billion in extra tax for this Treasurer since he came into office. As I said, the Opposition has costed and funded its proposals. This Government, with its massive double standards, feels under no obligation to do the same when it fiddles its tax bill for cynical party political reasons.

I will finish up simply by commending the only good part of this legislation, and that is the part that involves the present Government absorbing into the legislation the private member's Bill that passed through this chamber, generated by Senator John Watson, a Liberal senator-and a very good one-from Tasmania who actually understands the tax situation. He certainly understands the tax law far better than this Government seems to. It is a great credit to him that his proposal has been taken up. Senator Watson's proposal was to allow the deductability of fees in relation to tax advice.

The Bill will allow deductions for expenditure incurred by taxpayers in connection with the management or administration of their income tax affairs. Examples of expenditure that will be allowable as a deduction include fees paid by a taxpayer to a registered tax agent, solicitor or barrister for professional advice in relation to the income tax affairs of the taxpayer; costs associated with disputing an assessment or determination made by the Commissioner of Taxation; expenditure incurred in attending to an Australian Taxation Office audit; and costs associated with tax planning. That is all very sensible. It follows Senator Watson's private member's Bill, which was introduced in the Senate in May and passed unanimously. This is unusual. I commend the Labor Treasurer (Mr Keating) for incorporating into a Government Bill the thrust of a private member's Bill introduced by a Liberal Party senator.

It is interesting to note that while this is being done there is the extraordinary situation where companies which are being forced to borrow huge amounts of money to pay their taxes early, in many instances before they really know what their profit is, cannot claim the income on that borrowing as a tax deduction. I stress that many will not know what their profit is. Surely the Government realises that the role of an auditor in preparing a company's account is to resolve what can often be fairly heated disagreements between management and the auditor on what the profit really is. Practising accountants on our side of the chamber know this; they have been involved in it.

It is ludicrous to suggest that within 28 days of the end of the financial year there would be any prospect of most major companies or, in fact, many small businesses, knowing what their profit is. From 30 June the local suburban accountant will be inundated by small businessmen who have to know, within that very short period, what their profit is. There will be chaos for the accounting profession. For many companies it will be into August before there is an agreed profit for taxation purposes. There is a curious mixture. Some companies are desperately keen to make their profit look bigger, for a whole range of reasons, and many others are determined to try to make it look smaller for taxation purposes. The proper role of the auditor is to establish that the correct view is taken. Companies will not know what their profit is until, say, August and they will have to pay 85 per cent of their tax by 28 July. That extraordinary situation is another example of how the Government simply does not know how the private sector operates. As a result, it introduces silly legislation.

I will not proceed further on that point. In the last few weeks of sitting we have been inundated with legislation. This legislation was rushed through the House of Representatives under a guillotine, despite the fact that it has major significance and implications for the private sector. It was part of a mountain of legislation that was rushed through the House of Representatives. There was limited discussion and a limited capacity to examine properly what it is all about and now we are under some sort of moral pressure, if you like, not to keep everyone back over Christmas. As it is, we are sitting until 22 December. We are dealing with legislation which is simply ill-prepared, ill-considered and has a negative and damaging effect on the private sector.
