It is to the Government's discredit that it has proceeded this way both in terms of the presentation of this legislation, and the repeated changes to it, and the manner in which it has whacked such legislation through.

Maybe the reason the Government has made this transitionary arrangement to try to help small business is not the crude political one that I am afraid springs to mind. Maybe the Government's thinking is that only transitional measures are needed because business is going through a situation of temporary disaster. There is no doubt that there is a disaster at the moment. Small business in particular is feeling the pinch of high interest rates of 21 and 25 per cent. Corporate cash flows are being squeezed. The pilots dispute is crippling many in the tourist industries. The prospect of a significant slump in demand early in the new year grows as the Government keeps claiming success in being able to dampen down-that is, pour cold water on-business activity. Sure, business is going through a special crisis. However, the problem is that if the Government is re-elected it will be a permanent crisis. I am overjoyed to see that public opinion polls keep pointing to the fact that it will not be re-elected.

Nonetheless, it is absolutely vital that this continual attack by an incompetent government on the private sector, particularly the small business sector, stops. One of the reasons a coalition government is needed in Australia is to make certain that it does stop. I hope that all small business people and those who are employed by small business-that represents the great bulk of the Australian work force-recognise what the Government is doing to them, their job prospects and their prospects of economic survival. That is why, in what may well be the last session before an election perhaps as early as February, it is vital for us to have an opportunity to reveal and point out to the Australian people, in discussing this kind of messy, silly and anti-business legislation, just what the Government is doing to them. It is vital that we have an opportunity to debate fully the Government's hostile, negative and money-grubbing approach to small business. The Government wants to take all the money it can get no matter what the consequences. Provided we have an opportunity to keep pointing this out to the Australian people, I believe that when the next election comes they will throw the Government out of office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues on this side of the House in condemning the legislation before us. I will not delay the Senate, and I will focus on three main areas: firstly, the issue that most exercised Senator Baume's mind-that is, the new proposal for the collection of 85 per cent of notional income tax for corporations within 28 days of the end of the financial year; secondly, the question of self-assessment-the new system that is being proposed for corporations; and, thirdly, the question of the deductability of interest and finance-related expenses in respect of income tax that will be required to be paid under the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 14 years that I have been a member of the Senate I have never seen such a vociferous reaction from the small and medium business community on any issue that I have seen in connection with the new corporate tax collection proposals. That led me to take an interest in the matter so I could ensure that people had their views properly expressed in the Parliament through a petition. I have presented to the Parliament a petition with several thousand signatures which indicates the depth of feeling in the business community, at least in South Australia.

The absolute despair into which the Government has thrown the business community by introducing this measure cannot be properly understood, especially by the Government since it fails to comprehend what kind of psychology exercises the minds of those engaged in private enterprise. It is that kind of lack of appreciation of the real concerns of business that has led the Government to make this disastrous decision to try to implement the proposal in this financial year.

What is the genesis of the proposal? I can only assume that somewhere in some room late at night the Treasurer (Mr Keating) had a bright light go on in his mind which led him to say that he would have to have a surplus in the current Budget of the order of $10 billion. Having cast about for a way to do this, he found that the good old stand-bys that he has relied upon-for instance, the new tax on superannuation and, more particularly, the profits that the Reserve Bank of Australia has been able to make over the last several years which have helped to reduce the Government's deficit-had run out. The Budget figures show that the Reserve Bank's profits have declined from more than $2 billion to under $1 billion. That hole had to be filled up somehow. So he came up with this brilliant idea of taxing the hell out of businesses and virtually sending them to the wall.

The 85 per cent tax proposal will go down in history as one of the most ill-thought out proposals that has come before us, at least in the period of this Government. There is no doubt that that is a very significant statement to make in the light of some of the other absolute cock-ups in legislation we have seen since it has been in power. The capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax are two examples in recent history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Massively altered.

—As Senator Baume points out, massively altered. We have had numerous attempts by this Government to pass amending legislation to correct the messes it has made over that period. But this must be the daddy of them all. We are now expected to pass today a piece of legislation about which the Government announced, before it had actually been passed in the House of Representatives, significant changes-not in a definite way but, rather, in a hurried, ill-considered fashion-which hint at reviews of certain vital parts of the legislation rather than spell out quite clearly what those changes will be. For instance, in the case of deductability of interest on loans used to pay company tax, Mr Dawkins in his press release on 22 November said that this issue was being reviewed. Yet we are expected to pass a Bill today which includes a provision to set up the provisos by which those kinds of deductions can be made, passing into law something which the Government itself does not believe in.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not the only example. We also have the self-assessment provisions. Again, there is a great deal of conflict between professionals and the Government about the form of the new proposals the Government has brought forward. I will come to some of the details of that a little later. The Government has now admitted, in Mr Dawkins's press release on 22 November, that that is going to be reconsidered as well. Yet again, in the Bill we are expected to pass we have a law set down which, on advice from the Government, in all probability will be changed. I do not believe that it is the proper role of Parliament to pass laws which the Government says it is going to change. It is asking the Parliament to roll over and have its tummy tickled in order to get on the books legislation which it has already admitted is faulty. As we have already mentioned, we have had examples in the past of legislation being in error or wrong or incorrect or-what is that phrase the Government uses?

TALK.START.PARA: —The unintended consequences.
—The Government uses the phrase `the unintended consequences' on occasions to justify changes to the law.
—One of these Bills is about little else.

—Exactly. I do not believe that this is good enough. I do not believe that this Bill should be passed by the Parliament in this faulty fashion, especially since the Government has indicated that it will be changing that legislation before too long. When such things are put forward, it undermines the credibility of the Parliament. Obviously, it is done with an intent that has nothing to do with proper law or proper government. It is to do with political expediency.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is desperate to maintain some credibility for the Budget it brought down in August so that it can go to an election, probably as early as February, and claim that it is the greatest manager of economic affairs since Federation, or something to that effect. We have become used to listening to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) saying that kind of thing often. Here we have political expediency overriding the proper role of the Parliament. That is a major issue in the way this legislation has been treated. We on this side ought not to agree to the passage of legislation in this situation; I believe that that feeling is shared by a great number of my colleagues on this side of the chamber.

Let us look at the new 85 per cent collection system. As Senator Michael Baume and Senator Short pointed out, the transition arrangements, which have now been modified by the statement by Mr Dawkins on 22 November, are in respect of the transition year only. They are not permanent changes to the law. They will have effect only during the next year so as to relieve the most onerous burdens on small and medium sized businesses in the period immediately ahead of us. They do not change the principle the Government has introduced, which itself is most onerous and dangerous to the health of small and medium sized businesses in this country. Again the Government has just bought time, for politically expedient reasons, to see itself through the next election. What other draconian things the Government has in mind for 1990-91, if it is by any mischance elected, remain to be seen. Of course, we are confident that that will not occur since we will be in power and able to modify substantially this cruel legislation that is before us.

When the legislation is finally in force, it will drag out nearly $1 billion of extra tax from small businesses. I know that in some sections of the Labor Party and in the bureaucracy people seem to think that all businessmen are in business simply to rape the public and to pinch money from the underprivileged in the community. The truth is that in this country we have 750,000 small businesses employing around half of the total work force in this country. The work force numbers something of the order of eight million; therefore we can say without any fear of contradiction that small firms employ roughly four million Australians. That is a most significant proportion of our total work force. The profits which small businesses make, pitifully small as many of them are, go to keeping these people employed, keeping Australians working, keeping the money turning over in our shops, and ensuring that more jobs are created. Yet this attack on small business, through the introduction of this new company tax collection system, is designed with no other purpose but, seemingly, to destroy that.

In the Government's Budget we can see that it has estimated that the Federal Government is going to save, by the introduction of this method of collection, $300m or thereabouts in interest. That is fine for the Federal Government, but it means that it is merely transferring the cost of interest from the government to the business sector. That means that the business sector will have to meet an extra $300m on top of the $900m of income tax that it will have to pay by virtue of this measure. That interest cost is a very sizeable hit in anybody's language when one is talking about an uncontrollable expense in a situation where interest rates, as they have been forced up by this Government, are so high. I think that it is an horrific situation when the Government is of a mind simply to transfer its own costs to the people. Of course, that will be reflected in prices, lower profits and fewer jobs for Australians. Surely, that is a very stupid way of going about business. We ought to be providing more and more incentives for small business to employ more people, not fewer. Yet, that is what this Government is on about with this legislation.

As Senator Michael Baume said clearly in his remarks, this simply stems from a total misunderstanding or lack of appreciation of the need to foster business in this community so as to ensure that we stimulate more jobs, provide more welfare for people and ensure that the Australian economic growth level is maintained and improved.

I would now like to turn to the new self-assessment system that will apply to corporations. We know that in 1986 the Government introduced a self-assessment system for individuals. That affected some businesses but not corporations. We now see a system being introduced for corporations. The thing that is of concern to me in this particular proposal-even the Acting Treasurer Mr Dawkins, saw problems with it as he signified in a press release issued in November that it will be reviewed-is the new arrangement whereby the Commissioner of Taxation can review the taxation affairs of taxpayers and can go back four years even where there has been a full, fair and true disclosure of facts by the taxpayer in the submission of his or her tax return.

This is a natural consequence of the type of system which the Government is intending to introduce. I believe that this is going too far. It will leave people in limbo, with no end to the possible inquiry by the Taxation Commissioner, and no clear definition of what tax will be payable in each year. In the period of four years immediately following the lodgment of a tax return, taxpayers will still be wondering whether they have incurred all of the liability that they expected to incur. In the event of the Taxation Commissioner within that four-year period reviewing the taxpayer's return by way of an audit and subsequently determining that, even though there has been full disclosure by the taxpayer, an item of expenditure may have been claimed wrongly, but in good faith, that taxpayer will find that extra tax will be charged. Taxpayers will incur not only tax but very high penalties-perhaps at the level of interest rates which we suffer today. Those penalties will be incurred as a direct consequence of this new self-assessment system without people actually knowing that that has happened.

This is not a good principle to introduce into tax legislation. Surely one of the most important principles that should guide all legislators is that any law, be it in tax or any other area, should be certain as to its effects and consequences. This will open up enormous uncertainties for small and medium sized businesses which will find themselves in a situation that they may not have envisaged as a result of the introduction of this system. To put a slightly finer point on the matter, today taxation laws, as we all know, have become extraordinarily complex. Inevitably, in the affairs of individual corporations which lodge taxation returns, there will be some doubt as to the legality of every single claim for expenditure within the law. That is because the law itself is not entirely clear in many areas. There will always be room for debate and that debate will not finally be settled until all of the litigious consequences are worked through.

People can, in all good faith, make full, fair and true disclosure of all the facts surrounding an issue and still not be sure that they will not suffer some challenge from the Taxation Commissioner at a later time and therefore cannot rely on the last word having been said on their affairs for any particular year. That lack of certainty, which depends entirely upon the Taxation Commissioner's discretion to exercise his right of inquiry within that four-year period, ought to be thrown out. I believe that the Opposition is correct in opposing this part of the legislation. It is wrong to hand such enormous powers over to the Taxation Commissioner in these circumstances. As I pointed out earlier, this has been acknowledged by the Acting Treasurer in his press statement. He said that a review of this matter would be conducted. Yet, we are expected to pass into law a Bill which incorporates this very faulty piece of legislation.

The third matter I want to mention relates to clause 8 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) which will not allow the deduction of certain financially related expenses in relation to the payment of income tax. This has been raised by journalists and others in recent times. It is a matter which is of a great deal of concern especially in the light of a story that appeared this morning in the Australian Financial Review in which Mr Boucher, the Commissioner of Taxation, made the point that he sees no reason why interest incurred on borrowings in order to pay income tax should not be deductable under section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I hope that is what he is saying in this rather confused article in the Australian Financial Review. To be honest, from this article it is so unclear as to what is actually intended that it behoves the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to answer this point and make sure that honourable senators fully understand what the Government is intending.

If one looks at the wording of clause 8 of this Bill, one sees that there can be absolutely no doubt that we are writing into law a prohibition on the deduction for income tax purposes of financing costs, such as interest on moneys borrowed in order to pay income tax. That applies, as I read this Bill, specifically in relation to the collection of income tax under the new corporate tax proposals and generally in relation to past payments of tax.

I am concerned about this because, as we have already discussed, one part of this Bill is about changing the self-assessment system and about removing the protection for taxpayers where there has been full and true disclosure of all the facts. If we tie these two things together, we have the situation in which interest paid in respect of borrowings to pay income tax could be deemed not to have been deductable for years immemorial-back to the commencement of the life of the corporation. By the removal of the full and true disclosure provisions, the Taxation Commissioner may well be able to go right back and throw out all income tax deductions for interest paid in respect of borrowings to pay income tax. That is a horrifying proposition. The Minister must explain this to the Senate so that we properly understand what the Government intends. Mr Boucher's effort in this morning's Australian Financial Review has served only to cloud the issue even further for some of the people who might have thought they understood it earlier. This is an important issue and it must be cleared up before the debate on this Bill is concluded.

A further point to which I draw attention is that both the issues of the self-assessment procedures and that of the deductions of the financing costs on borrowings to pay income tax have been specifically made subject to further Government review by the Treasurer in his statement of 22 November. Why then are we passing these matters into law? Why are we being requested and forced by the Government to pass into law a Bill that the Government knows that it will have to change in the not too distant future? It is wrong parliamentary practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a Budget Bill. There's a lot of revenue in it as well as public debt interest saving.

—As the Minister knows, we do not oppose the collection system as such. The points I have just mentioned do not relate to that; they relate to other parts of the Bill which can be excised from it. The Government would then have passage of a Bill more in keeping with the spirit of what most members of the Senate think, and thereby somewhere near correct. Surely that is a very worthy proposition, although one has to have regard to the fact that the Government has never seen much sense in getting legislation right. We all know that the errors that have occurred in past legislation have been monumental.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by repeating that the Government is merely trying to fill up the potholes caused by a changing revenue situation to meet a political objective of ensuring that it has a $10 billion surplus for the purpose of going to an election in the not too distant future. That is what all this is about. The ruination that could occur to Australian business by the passage of this legislation is just too monumental to contemplate. As I mentioned earlier, in my parliamentary experience I have never seen a reaction from the small business community such as I have seen on this issue. If the Government and its Ministers could understand the depths of despair that have been inflicted on the small business community, they might understand why we cannot get the improved productivity that is needed in this country. That is the key issue. This destruction of the psychological state of mind of small businessmen, the reduction in their feelings of positive achievement and the dismay that the Government has spread amongst them, will not enhance the capacity of this country to pull itself out of the mess that this Government has got it into with huge foreign debt, lack of productivity and rising taxation levels. With that lack of incentive, one would expect any government with half a brain to be able to work out that it is going in entirely the wrong direction from what is needed to improve the stature of this country. Yet this Government sees fit not to cut expenditure or to take the knife to some of its own friends, but rather, to impose higher and higher taxation on its most productive sector and biggest employer group in this country. That is wrong and the Government should be condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to clause 24 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), which I have already referred to in my speech during the second reading debate on the cognate legislation. This clause gives effect to a decision by the Government to rectify to some limited degree the treatment of capital gains-in other words, premiums-obtained by a lessor when he or she provides a lease and receives a financial premium for doing so. I will not go over again what I said on the matter in my speech during the second reading debate because we have no quarrel with what the Government proposes in relation to a principal lessor in that regard. What the Government is doing is arguable, perhaps, but we do not propose to argue it because that is not the gravamen of our concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Our concern relates to the situation of a person who has already undertaken a lease and is, therefore, a lessee but who then wants to sublet the property in question for a period-for any period, let alone the period of 50 years or more which is mentioned in the clause. As we read the Bill, what the Government proposes is that the lessee who is undertaking the sublease to a third party will still be liable for full capital gains tax on any premium obtained by him or her in respect of that sublease but will not be able to offset against that premium the costs to him or her originally of acquiring the original lease. That seems to us to be quite inequitable.

We can certainly accept the Government's view that, where one is talking about a principal party undertaking a lease of his or her property, capital gains tax should be payable-assuming one believes in the tax at all, which we do not, of course, but I will leave that aside-on the premium less any costs which are incurred in the entering into of the transaction. In that case the ownership of the underlying property remains in the hands of the principal and, therefore, it would not be appropriate, so to speak, to offset against the premium the cost of the property because, as I say, the ownership of the property remains his or hers.

But it seems to us that there is a different situation in the case of a person who has already acquired a lease and who then wants to sublet. That person has paid a premium for the rights granted to him or her under the lease and yet that cost will not, as we read the clause, be taken into account by the Government when taxing the premium received as a result of the sublease. I would like the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to respond to our concerns on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer which I believe and hope is satisfactory. I think I understand it, but just to make sure I will read what the officials have written for me. It concerns long term leases, broadly, of at least 50 years. Clause 24 introduces a tax concession for persons who grant long term leases or subleases. It covers that as well, I am advised. It will operate to treat the grant of a long term lease or sublease to include the disposal of the underlying asset. That is usually land or buildings. This effectively means that, if the long term lease relates to land or buildings acquired before the introduction of the capital gains tax in September 1985, there is no capital gains tax liability on the grant of a long term lease. The asset is reacquired for nil cost.

SPEECH.PARA: But, if a taxpayer elects under this provision, that is, clause 24, to get this tax concession, the subsequent cost base of the asset-that is, the lease, sublease and the underlying asset-for obvious reasons will be nil. Accordingly, there is no indexation available in these circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the second reading debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) failed to cover the concerns raised not only by the Opposition but by the accounting and taxation professional associations about the need for adequate consultation. —Has the attention of the Minister for Resources been drawn to statements by Mr Neil Pickard, the New South Wales Minister for Energy, and Mr Bob Katter Jr, who was the Queensland Minister for Mines and Energy, suggesting that ethanol fuel is a practical answer to the problem of dwindling supplies of crude oil? TALK.START.PARA: —No, Mr Pickard is not correct that a number of countries are turning to ethanol. He is about as correct on that as he was about the promise he made to some south coast coalminers early in the year. Later he had to say that he misled them. Indeed, his announcement recently that he is setting up an ethanol investigation task force contains echoes of what Bob Katter Jr, the then Minister for Mines and Energy in Queensland, announced just a couple of months ago before the Queensland election, about ethanol in that State. Bob Katter Jr has a particular and unique distinction as a National Party Minister in Queensland. However, the facts about ethanol are that--

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Macklin interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in the way in which it passed that vote of no confidence. What was said about the ethanol program in Queensland needs to be corrected. One comment is attributed to Transfield, the consortium that was formed under the guidance of Mr Katter to do what he said should be done; that is, to start an ethanol program in Queensland which would involve selling ethanol to refineries within 18 months, leading in a very short time a 10 per cent ethanol blend in petrol distilled in Queensland. ANSWER.PARA: It was also said that there would be no increase in petrol prices at the bowser. It is true that ethanol would be competitive with oil if oil were selling at $US40 a barrel. Oil is trading at between $US15 and $US20 a barrel, and the medium term prognostication is that it will remain so. To envisage a price going to $US40 suggests that the price of oil at the bowser would be massively increased.

It is also important to observe that Mr Ahern, when Premier of Queensland for a short period, rejected this harebrained scheme as well. The Australian Minerals and Energy Council made a study in 1987 on alternative fuels and indicated that production costs for ethanol were then about 60c a litre compared with production costs shorn of taxation, which some members of the Opposition have interjected about, of 20c per litre.

In Sao Paulo agricultural land has been turned over to sugar plantations to cash in on ethanol when the nation could have earned billions of dollars by cropping that land alternatively.

Can the Minister confirm whether this theory is correct and, if so, is there any danger of Australia relinquishing control and ownership of its beef industry to foreign investors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his question Senator Colston has called this a theory. I acknowledge that it has been represented as a theory, but I would have thought that the correct definition of the word `theory' is something for which there is empirical evidence sufficient to cause a process called a theory to be developed, which can then be tested to see whether a principle in fact exists. I think to dignify this allegation as a theory is to take a shock-horror conspiracy idea and promote it as if there were some empirical evidence to justify it. I cannot find any empirical evidence at all to justify the development of a theory based on what is occurring in the fisheries industry or in terms of foreign investment in Australia in relation to the beef industry or abattoirs.

ANSWER.PARA: An objective examination shows that it is true that some fisheries are being depleted at a rate that is not ideal. But objective evidence shows that the Australian Government has been very active in making sure that in this industry-in fisheries, above all others, or equal to others-the principle of sustainable development has been observed.

In the Prime Minister's environmental statement we made a major contribution to conserving southern bluefin tuna stocks and have a program so to do costing $1.45m over two years. As well, we have made considerable progress in areas such as opposition to long-line fishing, and gill net fishing. We work with the States through the Australian Fisheries Council to see that seasons are opened and closed commensurate with the sustainability of the fish resource. Australia has been active offshore with adjoining nations, notably Indonesia, in working out fishing agreements which guarantee sustainable development. I do not think the first principle of this alleged theory can be justified.

In regard to the second principle, we are, of course, subject to Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines and we maintain an open stance in terms of foreign investment in industry in Australia. Some foreign investment has occurred in the abattoir industry and in pastoral enterprises, but it is all consistent with the foreign investment guidelines. To cobble that together to pretend that some sort of theory can be justified is to stretch the meaning of that word in real English.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT ORGANISATION: MEMBERSHIP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to last year's Government decision to terminate Australia's membership of the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation (UNIDO), whose mandate it is to promote industrial development and cooperation. I refer him to a letter which he received from the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology dated 29 August, urging a review of the decision to terminate Australia's membership of UNIDO. I ask the Minister: given the visit by the Director-General of UNIDO to Australia in August and visits by officials from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to Vienna to meet with UNIDO officials, has the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade or any other department conducted a review of Australia's membership of UNIDO? If so, when will the report be finalised and when will a decision be made public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a subject that has been very much on my mind. In the last two minutes I have been engaged in a conversation with Senator Button on that very subject. Quite separately, distinctly and fortuitously, in light of that question, Senator Button and I are glad to report that, as a result of the summit encounter we have just had, that review should be done jointly; that it should be initiated forthwith; and that it should be concluded some time in the first quarter or so of next year so that any decision that is made to re-establish membership presumably could be done within the 1990-91 financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: I hasten to make the point, however, that no assumption whatsoever should be made about the outcome of that review. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. Is it true that biologists from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Division of Wildlife and Ecology recently collected a pair of regent honeyeaters, an endangered species? Were the birds nesting at the time and had they been banded as part of other studies? Is it considered that two specimens are an adequate sample for scientific study? If not, why were the birds collected? Where are the birds now? Are they alive? How much of each specimen was retained for study?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am extremely grateful to Senator Dunn for having given me notice of this question because it is not a topic about which I am necessarily literate, numerate or whatever is required. The CSIRO Division of Wildlife and Ecology confirms that two specimens of the regent honeyeater were collected under permit at Gooroo Hill, in the Australian Capital Territory, out of the breeding season in February this year.The specimens were collected as part of a program to determine the evolutionary radiation and distinctiveness of the Australian bird fauna. The collection of the birds is part of CSIRO's research directed towards the conservation of endangered species.

ANSWER.PARA: The CSIRO Division of Wildlife and Ecology is well aware that the regent honeyeater is of some concern to conservationists as a declining species and that is why the sample was limited to two and it is envisaged that no more specimens will be taken. Further systematic studies of the regent honeyeater have been held up by the lack of material available for molecular analysis. Mr President, as this answer is somewhat long I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of it in Hansard. In terms of Senator Dunn's question I must say that, since I got notice of it, I have been worried about whether these two honeyeaters, which have been retained by the CSIRO, are alive or dead. I have just been passed a note which says that they are stuffed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for the incorporation of the rest of the answer in Hansard? There being no objection, leave is granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: One of the birds collected had been previously banded by the Division, as part of a general banding program.
The purpose of collecting these specimens was to gather soft tissues to determine by molecular analysis the correct evolutionary position of the regent honeyeater amongst Australian birds.
This information forms the basis of all conservation and management decisions for Australian wildlife-we have to know what we have before we can manage it.
Such information from this CSIRO Division has already formed much of the scientific basis for setting aside the north Queensland rainforests for World Heritage listing.
The specimens now form part of the Australian National Wildlife Collection, housed at CSIRO Division of Wildlife and Ecology at Gungahlin.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources would be aware that his colleague Senator Richardson has stated that national environmental guidelines for pulp mill developments are to be announced shortly. —Has the Minister for Local Government seen a report in the Sydney Morning Herald which warns that local councils are facing problems in recruiting suitably qualified staff? What steps has the Federal Government taken to address these labour market shortages?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Government has been well aware of these concerns for a number of years because in 1986 we initiated a national review of local government labour markets. This review has just been completed and we are optimistic that, because of a range of information that has been collected over the last three years and because of the commitment that has been given through the Federal-State Local Government Ministers Conference, action will start to be taken by State, Federal and local governments and particularly by local government industry training groups.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said, the review has been completed and, as part of the review, a nationwide survey of occupational shortages and training in local government was undertaken. The survey sampled 200 councils throughout Australia which represented 20 per cent of Australian councils. In brief, the survey found that 54.7 per cent of the councils surveyed have difficulty recruiting labour, particularly health surveyors, accountants, civil engineers, building surveyors and building inspectors, and only 43.5 per cent of councils provide on-the-job formal training. There have been particular difficulties in training women and outdoor staff.

The review is concerned that some of the shortages could be attributed to outmoded recruitment and personnel practices. In 16 papers that have been issued a number of suggestions have been made to the local government industry. In May 1989, Commonwealth and State Ministers endorsed a number of principles recommended by the review. These include the need for councils to implement equal employment opportunity and to develop structures to encourage appropriate education, training and development opportunities for staff within local government. A number of my State colleagues are seriously addressing these issues. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and work with local government to overcome these concerns about shortages.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business to the comment made in the Federal Court of Australia by Justice Davies in the LNC-Wholesale Pty Ltd case that Customs refusal to refund money to the importer was not regarded as `high minded'-the judge's words-rather, as a `shabby thing or dirty trick which the court will not allow'. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian Government assistance to Air Vanuatu has been a most effective use of the Australian aid program. It is worth recalling that Vanuatu's economy is very small and very fragile. Commodity export earnings traditionally came from only one source, copra, and the economy in the country as a whole was highly vulnerable as a result. For some time Australia has been helping Vanuatu in its own efforts to develop tourism as a major industry base. We are significantly lengthening the Bauerfield Airport at Vila and, as Senator Schacht has just indicated, we have supported Vanuatu's efforts to purchase and operate its own aircraft. That ownership has now let Vanuatu optimise airline schedules to and from the country to its own advantage.

ANSWER.PARA: Ownership of the aircraft, supported by a major tourism program, has led to impressive results. In the third quarter of this year Air Vanuatu's average load factor was a healthy 88 per cent and total tourism numbers were up by 50 per cent on the previous quarter. The occupancy rates for the two largest hotels in Vanuatu rose from around 35 per cent in 1988 to 70 and 50 per cent respectively. This has led to increases numbered in the hundreds in employment in hotel staff, tour operators and restaurants. The increase in tourism has, moreover, provided a significant contribution to Vanuatu Government revenue through turnover tax on hotels and restaurants. The Vanuatu Government has clearly expressed its appreciation to Australia for our assistance in improving Vanuatu's self-reliance and its export earning capacity in this respect. Although a number of factors no doubt contributed to the success of tourism in Vanuatu in recent months, the point is that the country has now been geared up and is capable of taking advantage of opportunities as they arise. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Parks and Wildlife Service for years now has been responsible for starting to put into Kakadu and Uluru the infrastructure to enable tourists who enjoy those places to go there. When the Commonwealth does something, Senator Tambling queries it. The National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Commonwealth generally have a very proud record up there. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA-SOVIET UNION: SUMMIT CONFERENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the Senate of the Government's assessment of the outcome of the United States-Soviet summit held in Malta at the weekend?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government very much welcomes the statements of President Bush and President Gorbachev following their two-day meeting in Malta, which has clearly been a very important step in the emergence of a new era of cooperation between the superpowers and between East and West more generally. Of course, it has laid the foundation for a fully fledged summit in the United States in June next year. In addition to what is on the public record and the preliminary briefings we have already received, I should mention that a senior United States official will be coming to Australia in the next few days to brief the Government in detail on the outcome of the talks. It is apparent that progress has been made in many areas, including arms control, on which I will say more in a moment, and also on projected Soviet participation as an observer in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) following the conclusion of the Uruguay Round and the possibility of increased United States-Soviet economic cooperation. The matter of the United States of America's readiness to support observer status in GATT is something that Australia particularly applauds and welcomes. It was the subject of some discussion between Australia and the United States in the recent ministerial talks in Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: On the subject of arms control, I want to say that the Australian Government is particularly pleased about the important step that was taken at the summit towards the early finalisation of a chemical weapons convention, an issue on which Australia has taken a very prominent and active role in recent times. The United States has indicated its readiness not now to pursue the possibility of continued binary chemical weapons production after the entry into force of a comprehensive convention. We warmly welcome that further evidence of the commitment of the Bush Administration to the early conclusion of a chemical weapons convention. It will be recalled that this has been the subject of some controversy and it is a subject on which I have had very extensive dialogue with United States Secretary of State Baker, as have senior United States and Australian officials in recent months, most recently at the Australia-United States ministerial talks in Sydney.

Australia and the United States are also engaged in discussing strategies to promote early widespread adherence to a chemical weapons convention. The regional initiative which we set in train at the instance of the Prime Minister a few months ago has been picked up elsewhere, as I have already mentioned in this place, with Venezuela announcing a similar initiative for Latin America. We are working together with the United States and a number of other countries in Geneva in the hope that next year will be the final year, if humanly possible, in the convention negotiation process. Australia will be playing the role of coordinator of the Western Group at the disarmament conference next year. We hope that we can make some progress in that capacity.

More generally on arms control, attention at the summit focused on the centrally important START agreement-strategic arms reduction talks agreement-with both sides indicating their willingness to complete the agreement, which they hope will be ready for signature next year. President Bush proposed that the United States and Soviet Union work toward completing the agreement in time for the June summit. To this end, United States Secretary of State Baker and Foreign Minister Shevardnadze will hold several meetings over the next few months to discuss three main issues: air-launched cruise missiles; encryption of missile test telemetry; and accounting procedures for non-deployed missiles. Conditions of the agreement are expected to include ceilings for each side of 1,600 intercontinental ballistic missiles--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate, Mr President, that matters of nuclear war and peace have always been of profound indifference to the mob opposite. That is something that will be noticed by the Australian electorate when it comes to the determination of this matter. They are not of indifference to the Australian Government.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. For the last week or two now-and we appreciate that Senator Evans is anxious to get off to his Christmas holidays in Europe next week-we have been drawing to your attention the tendency of Ministers and, in particular, Senator Evans to use Question Time as the basis for making lengthy statements about significant matters in the knowledge that they are not then for parliamentary debate.
—That is not a point of order.

—That will be a matter for the President to rule on. We have requested you, Mr President, in terms of enforcing the Standing Orders, to draw the attention of Ministers to the fact that if they wish to make statements which ought properly to be debated they should do so other than under the guise of answering a prepared question. I ask you, therefore, to indicate to Senator Evans that the rulings that you have given in the past on this matter ought to be adhered to by him. If he wants this matter debated, let him stay here next week and present a statement and we will debate it.

—Order! There is no point of order. I have made no rulings. But I have reminded a number of Ministers recently when they have gone past a certain period of time-which I have judged to be five minutes-that they should conclude their answers.

—Order! I take the question that was asked of Senator Evans as being within his portfolio. It is very important. I would point out that so far in Question Time today there have been, I think, approximately 14 questions asked. I ask Senator Evans to conclude as soon as possible.

—I was on my last two sentences, Mr President, as it turned out. Before finishing them, let me comment on the way that it is a very odd point of order to make on a day when I am about to deliver a parliamentary statement of a very wide-ranging kind on foreign policy issues. As I said, and I hope it will be a matter of some interest to the Opposition-which is forever going to remain thus-that conditions of the agreement are expected to include ceilings for each side of the 1,600 intercontinental ballistic missiles and 6,000 nuclear warheads. Both sides were also optimistic about progress on troop reductions in Europe. The United States proposed that the threshold test ban and peaceful nuclear explosions treaties be finalised and ratified. There are a whole series of outcomes from the summit which were important for the world at large, manifestly important for us to acknowledge in this place and manifestly important for us to applaud.

—I refer the Minister for Resources to an answer he gave earlier in Question Time to a question from Senator Faulkner in respect of the production of ethanol from sugarcane and its viability or otherwise. In response to Senator Faulkner, the Minister said that for ethanol to be competitive it would need massive subsidies. I think that is the correct expression used by the Minister. I ask: Does the Government intend to absolve the ethanol from sugarcane from all secondary taxes, excise taxes and other taxes?

—It is a matter of plain fact on production costs alone from the statement attributed to Transfield Pty Ltd, after it had consulted with the Queensland Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr Katter, that there would be no extra cost at the bowser for consumers of ethanol blended petroleum in Queensland. On production costs alone for ethanol to be competitive, so that there would be no extra cost, the price of oil would have to be $US40 a barrel-it is currently between $US15 and $US18. The Australian Minerals and Energy Council, as I said earlier, in a 1987 study had indicated that production costs-I am only talking about production costs-were then around 60c per litre for ethanol compared to petrol at 20c per litre. To go to the point that I was making, if there were not to be a higher impost paid by motorists then there would be required to be massive subsidies. That point is valid, and remains valid, irrespective of the taxing regime. In terms of tax, that is a matter for both the Commonwealth and the State and those taxing regimes apply as both the Commonwealth and State appropriately invoke them. The point is not a question of tax, which is a neutral issue in this, but it is a question of production costs.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I must say that I am quite amazed by the answer from the Minister. As he would not answer my question in respect of Commonwealth Government secondary taxes as applied to ethanol, I ask him how does he explain that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, 12 months ago wrote to the Premier of Queensland and said that secondary tax would not apply but that he could not speak for future governments. I would be happy to give Senator Cook a copy of that letter if he wishes.

—It would take only a Queensland Liberal Party, to the extent that it still exists in Queensland, to actually find something different between what the Prime Minister said and what my answer was. My answer is about the cost of production of ethanol compared to petroleum. The Prime Minister's commitment in that letter, of which I am aware, is consistent. The honourable senator's question still makes the point for me that if the cost at the bowser were to be the same it would still require a massive public subsidy. That is the point I was making in my contribution. I thank the honourable senator for assisting me to make it again. The taxation issue suggests, as the honourable senator has raised, that a degree of public subsidy will be applied because if a commodity such as ethanol is not to be taxed then the public good is not being met, in some sense, which would otherwise be attained by taxation.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. In the recent Budget, the Government's retirement incomes policies emphasise the importance of savings contrary to the claims of the Opposition and Australian Democrats in this place. What step is the Government taking to encourage better use of savings for senior citizens, and for those approaching retirement?
—Tax them!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an ignorant quip. There are two major objectives of the Federal Government's retirement income policy. Firstly, and fundamentally, is the provision of adequate income support; secondly, the creation of opportunities for pensioners to better use their savings. Senator Crowley's question goes very much to the second part. It goes to the provision of opportunities for pensioners to better use their savings. In this area, the Government is implementing a comprehensive information strategy. It is one that is based on allowing pensioners to take advantage of the new opportunities created in the retirement income policy. As part of that program, we have special pensioner hot lines; the Aged Pension News, a newspaper entirely devoted to aged and financial service pensioners; new financial counselling services; a clearing house for pensioner investments; and, most importantly, the new financial information service for pensioners. This service has had quite a successful introduction. It is operating from 20 Department of Social Security area offices. It is based on the work of staff which can explain how income from investments or earnings or loans affect a pensioner and, of course, it traverses a range of problems pensioners face under incomes and assets tests as well as in relation to fringe benefit purposes and for tax in general. I say that it has had a successful introduction as it has been in operation now for three weeks. In that period it has dealt with 1,000 clients and conducted about 300 interviews.

ANSWER.PARA: The strategy is designed to help pensioners benefit from the retirement income reforms which promote savings. These include: first, the radical three-stage reform of income test and tax measures providing incentives to maximise investment income for pensioners; secondly, and importantly, the concessional treatment of annuity under the income test; thirdly, the improved pensioners credit scheme; fourthly, disregarding under incomes tests of up to $40,000 received from a home equity conversion loan; and, fifthly, and most importantly and fundamentally, the indexation for the entire system of income test free areas, fringe benefit limits and the assets test limits. I made the point that the interjection from those opposite was ignorant because the last point about the indexation of both payments and these areas is quite fundamental. It is an essential part of the program. It is also essential because it provides certainty for pensioners.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite may not want to hear about this but the important point is that there is a clear distinction between those opposite and us in this particularly fundamental area. We have promised to index the adequacy of incomes and we have promised to index these areas that we are talking about.
—Do we have an inadequacy index?

—It is another area of major difference, Senator Alston. As yet the Opposition has not made its commitment to indexation of these areas clear. This is an area where pensioners need certainty for planning both their future investment and their future income. It is unforgivable-no amount of bickering and interjection can exculpate those opposite from this-that those opposite have not made clear their position on this basic question of indexation.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I hope that he can expand on his knowledge about retirement income policies in answer to me. I refer the Minister to the Government's Budget changes to its retirement incomes policy, and specifically to the introduction of income tax deductions for employees who are members of certain employer supported superannuation funds. Did the Budget Statements show that from 1 July 1990 employees will be able to claim the maximum allowable $3,000 tax deduction for contributions where the employer provides up to 4 per cent in contributions scaling down to zero where the employer contributions are over 6.5 per cent? As the Budget disclosed that the Government is proposing another 3 per cent award increase in wages for occupational superannuation on top of the existing 3 per cent, lifting the minimum level of employer supported superannuation to 6 per cent, does the Minister agree that the bulk of the work force would then be allowed to claim a maximum deduction of $1,000 only, or one third of the maximum that the Government provided for, with great fanfare, in the Budget? In those circumstances of little or no tax deductability being available for low income earners, where is the great tax incentive for them to provide for their own retirement through superannuation?
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It follows Senator Puplick's point of order on the length of answers. We should have some presidential guidance on the length of questions.
—It is a very long question. Is it concluded, Senator Messner?
—Yes.

—There is a basic problem in answering Senator Messner's question. As he may know, superannuation is within the province of my colleague Senator Walsh, who is in a state that probably all of us in this place have been in because of the boring questions asked by those on the other side. Once I have spoken to Senator Walsh about it, I will give Senator Messner a full answer.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health advise how many people had no cover under previous private health insurance schemes operating in Australia and how many are now covered under Medicare? How much does the average family save in health insurance under Medicare compared with previous schemes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This invites me to make a BM and AM comparison-a before Medicare and an after Medicare comparison. Before Medicare upwards of two million Australians did not have any health cover-either private health insurance, or they were not covered by the Commonwealth as pensioners, unemployed or low-income earners. So in the old era nearly two million of our fellow citizens were without health insurance protection. Of course, since the advent of the Medicare arrangement all Australian residents are now automatically covered for basic health costs, indicating one of the most far-reaching and significant social reforms achieved in medical coverage in Australia. This Government is well recognised for that.

ANSWER.PARA: To compare the costs before Medicare and after Medicare is a bit of a difficult task because one cannot strictly compare the two situations. However, by applying the increases in consumer price index to the average family basic medical and hospital insurance contribution of $14.50 a week or $754 per annum just before Medicare was introduced to June 1989 equivalents, we see that it would generate a family contribution of $21.60 a week or $1,123 per annum. This would need to be reduced to reflect the 30 per cent tax rebate that applied at that time, but this would still give a weekly outlay of $15 or an annual outlay of $786. This means that a family would need to be earning in excess of $62,000 per annum, after taking into account the tax rebate, before it would be worse off under Medicare. The Australian Bureau of Statistics in August 1988 indicated that the mean average family income was $655 a week or $34,000 per annum. Thus, we have $34,000 compared to $62,000. In other words, the average family could be up to $6 a week or $360 per annum better off under Medicare than under the previous Fraser Government user pays scheme that operated during 1982-83. In concluding my answer, I note that in statements attributed to the shadow Minister for health, Mr Peter Shack, it is indeed yet once again-boringly, repetitively-the intention of a conservative coalition to abolish Medicare.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories would be aware that the vessel Polar Queen departs Hobart today with a team of Royal Australian Air Force personnel and members of the Antarctic Division, whose task is to construct a runway for Antarctic supply flights to the Casey station. How does the Minister justify this proposal, given that a detailed report prepared by the Antarctic Division itself in 1985 and titled A Review of Antarctic Air Transport Options concluded categorically that air transport to the Antarctic was uneconomical and presented grave risks to the crew and passengers of such flights? Is the Minister aware that the United States stopped air transport to the Casey region because of a number of near misses even though the United States aircraft were equipped with the more preferable ski landing gear whereas the Australian aircraft are to be equipped with the more limited landing wheels only? What is the cost of constructing the Casey runway and what provision has been made for emergency medical and rescue services because of the hazardous nature of these flights? Finally, what percentage of the flights which leave from Hobart does the Minister expect to be able to complete their journey on the basis that only guesswork could determine whether weather conditions at Casey would remain stable for the duration of the flight as weather forecasting in that area is particularly limited?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the Polar Queen is carrying some Air Force personnel who will be looking at the construction of a runway. As Senator Calvert and I think many other honourable senators would be aware, during the course of this season we intend to trial a number of flights to see how effective air transport down there can be. That will be an enormous undertaking. A report was done in 1985 but it did not review all of the methods that we will be trialling this year. This year there will be a couple of Hercules flights. It is difficult to say exactly how many as we do not know what the weather will bring. If this is to become a permanent feature, we intend to do far more in the way of weather forecasting. I hope that we can make sure that the operation is totally safe. Certainly the Air Force, when assessing last season whether there would be any flights at all, took that into consideration. The Air Force has regard not only for the safety of passengers and equipment but also for its own personnel. It would not be undertaking these flights without being convinced that they would be safe.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been a number of changes to the way in which the Division would like to see air transport used. If there was to be an ice-snow runway on which these Hercules could land, our intention was to use long range helicopters from Casey to the other bases. That has now been altered and we will be using fixed wing aircraft because our trialling of the other methods showed that this just was not possible. We hope to have the runway sufficiently frozen over by early February to allow us to begin some flights. I cannot be specific about the percentage that will go. There is a point at which, after leaving Hobart, a final check is made with Casey and if the pilot is not satisfied the plane turns around. However, given the time of year that the flights are going down there, the percentage of flights that will get in should be pretty high.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Coulter proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to comprehend the indissoluble links between good environmental and good economic management.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the numbers of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear from the number of statements made by Government Ministers in recent weeks that there is considerable misunderstanding of the links between the economy and the environment. This extends from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) down and involves most senior Ministers. This ignorance is shared by most media commentators. It poses several serious threats to Australia's and the world's well-being and that is why this is a matter of public importance this afternoon. At the most profound level it means that the legitimate environmental concerns will be deflected by government application of bandaids which fail to address the underlying causes of progressive environmental deterioration. The environment will continue to deteriorate while the public is misled into thinking problems are being effectively addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Related to this is the damage done to informed public debate. Emerging recognition of significant global environmental damage should lead to extensive and informed public debate. Very profound changes which affect attitudes and many aspects of lifestyle will need to be made. These cannot and will not be made unless there is public information and the formation of a consensus. As present government and media, through their lack of understanding and their backward orientation, are impeding this process.

Finally, even within the present flawed economic modelling, Australia is being left behind other nations because it is failing to recognise that large and significant economic improvements can be obtained even while addressing the problems of resource and environmental protection and that, particularly in the energy area, reduced energy use through conservation and use of alternative and renewable energy technologies are consonant with improved economic performance. Government attitudes and research and development spending in these areas are causing Australia to be left behind, even when looked at from the Government's narrow competitive view of the world economy. I want to pick up each of these areas in turn.

Firstly, there is a fundamental and irreconcilable conflict between the continual pursuit of economic growth and the establishment of a sustainable environment. To speak of sustainable growth, as do both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), indicates that both either do not understand that economic growth means an increased flow of resources through the economy and is therefore not endlessly sustainable or believe in perpetual motion machines, a belief firmly held by most economists. Indeed, the economist Herman Daly, in commenting on this, likens it to a biologist trying to understand animals only in terms of their circulatory system, with no recognition that they have digestive tracts. He says:

The metabolic flow is not circular. The digestive tract firmly ties the animal to its environment at both ends. Without digestive tracts animals would be self-contained perpetual-motion machines. Likewise for an economy with an entropic throughput.

Facing this fundamental conflict will require more than assertion that it does not exist or evasion on the part of government, but so far that is all we have had from government. Exponential growth in material consumption has clear limits. Energy consumption is a direct cause of greenhouse gas emissions and escalating changes in the composition of the global atmosphere. Energy use is closely linked with the extraction and use of all other material resources. Therefore, continued growth in the consumption of material resources is incompatible with ecological sustainability.

But what of labour, the other input to gross domestic product (GDP)? The United States and Japan have recently experienced economies growing much more rapidly than the increase in their use of material resources. The labour content of their GDP has increased far more rapidly, marking a shift from material resource use to an increase in labour input to that index of growth. But labour is also limited. There are only three ways in which an individual or community can increase the value of the labour component of GDP: work harder, work more hours or increase the value of those hours vis-a-vis the value of the hours of others. Working more hours or working harder at the same job clearly has strict limits. Moreover, one could seriously question the sanity of a society which sought to make its citizens work harder and longer merely to chase a growing GDP. Doing the same work or doing different work and charging more for one's time involves one person taking an advantage over another in a zero sum game. Inequity is increased. This places a limit on growing GDP or on a growth economy.

The zero sum nature of the labour component of GDP is important to grasp. It arises out of the fixed and equal number of hours available to everyone. For instance, if a pilot charges three times as much per hour for his or her labour as I do, I must work three hours to buy one hour of a pilot's time; if six hours, I must work six hours to buy an hour of a pilot's time. As the pilot's fortune rises, so my fortune falls in a precisely reciprocal way. So it is between nations. If the Japanese charge more per hour for their time, it follows that Australians must work more time to buy the products of Japanese labour. Inequality places very strict limits on growth through this course-the course of increasing the labour content of GDP.

This analysis also shows that human inventiveness does not resolve the conflict between growth and sustainability. Innovation will not of itself cause global economic growth but may allow one person or group or nation to grow at the expense of another. For those who are left behind by competitive labor costs, there is one temporary solution; that is, to attempt to feed their economic growth by increasing the rate of exploitation of material resources. But, as I have shown, there are strict limits to this. This explains how countries with growing economies-such as Japan, the United States and to some extent Australia-even those with relatively declining material input to those economies nonetheless exacerbate environmental despoliation and depress resource prices in those countries struggling but failing to make their own economies grow.

Many technological developments allow us to use resources more efficiently, but growth means growth in the dollar value of goods and services made each year after allowing for inflation. The pursuit of growth, therefore, means that the benefits of technological improvement are at least partly taken out as increased real inputs of material resources and/or labour somewhere else in the economy. Thus applied, improved technology results in an overall increase in throughput in the economy.

If we were not growth directed, we might take technological and other improvements as an opportunity to decrease economic inputs for the same output. We may then have a falling GDP while maintaining the same material and an improved non-material quality of life. We may, for instance, take the improvement as increased leisure rather than increased production. That is a sustainable economy, one that seeks to maintain a suitable stock of material things with a minimum and sustainable throughput, or GDP, of material resources and labour rather than merely attempting endlessly to increase the throughput. There is a sharp and irreconcilable conflict between these two economic models, a conflict which this Government has not yet recognised, much less sought to resolve.

The second area I wish to address concerns the unfounded assumptions that environmental protection and resource conservation come at such a high price that only limited protection and conservation are consistent with economic rationalism. I quote from a couple of articles by Ean Higgins in today's Australian. Commenting on the greenhouse, he says:

On a policy front, it would mean a concerted and expensive effort to combat the emission of greenhouse gases, such as imposing a `carbon tax' on fuels which let out large amounts of carbon per unit of energy.

He goes on to argue that this would be so expensive as to interfere with the economy. Reporting on the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation conference on greenhouse, going on in Sydney, Ean Higgins quotes Mr Jim Le Cornu of Shell as saying:
. . . the hoped-for lower cost, lower greenhouse impact options are essentially not available.

We find this attitude coming not only from the Government but also through the media. Compromise, indeed, is the word most often used-compromise between the dictates of economic growth and the desirability of protecting the environment. This attitude leads to the belief that the global, economic and industrial arrangements in the year 2010 will not be markedly different from what they have been for the last several decades, only more intense and extending over more countries. For instance, it has been asserted recently that there are no environmental constraints to conventional industry-based economic growth in China over the decades ahead. This belief finds practical expression in the allocation of research and development funds and industry assistance in this country.

The Australian Democrats believe that there has been, and is, a serious misallocation in these areas because of the inability or unwillingness of government to comprehend the portents for change which can be read in the deteriorating environment. Other countries are making better, more far-sighted development decisions than Australia. We are being left behind with yesterday's technology, despite the fact that some of the most brilliant research is being done in this country. For instance, in the last nine years, $640m has been spent on energy research in Australia. About 40 per cent of this has gone into nuclear energy and 27 per cent into coal research. It has been repeatedly shown that nuclear is not economic when fully exposed to a competitive market. Moreover, carbon emission taxes, which will discriminate heavily against coal, are already being considered in some countries. Thus, two-thirds of our energy research expenditure in recent years may have been in areas with a limited and declining future. Meanwhile, only 15 per cent of our research effort has gone into renewable energy and energy conservation.

Moreover, over time the funding for renewable energy and energy conservation has declined in real terms. Whilst Sweden spent US206c per head of population on renewable energy in 1986 and Japan spent US82c, Australia spent only US48c. Most developed countries spent more than Australia. One important consequence of this, and the attitude which caused it, is that while between 1973 and 1985 Japan reduced the energy required per dollar of GNP by 31 per cent, Australia improved by only 6 per cent. This occurred during 12 years when the Japanese economy was growing very rapidly and the savings were also won against a much less energy intensive base-the base from which the Japanese economy began. As energy savings are a direct addition to profits-that is, to the bottom line, not to the top line in a country's accounting-this suggests a path by which Australian industry could become more profitable without increasing output but with a lowered environmental impact. That this path is not being followed we lay fairly and squarely at the door of government.

Electricity use in Australia is inefficient. This inefficiency has been brought about by the control exercised by supplying utilities in the States. Excess generating capacity with associated large foreign debt is present in every State in this country. The excess will become enormous if energy efficiencies which are now achievable were to be practised. For instance, the most efficient available lighting uses a quarter of the electricity that the current incandescent lamps use for the same light output. Refrigerators and air-conditioners can achieve the same efficiency. We pose the question: Will Australia be left behind with out of date and inefficient technology which the rest of the world does not want? We believe the answer must be yes, if the blinkered attitude of this Government to energy efficiency continues.

As for alternative renewable and environmentally clean sources of electricity, California already has 1,500 megawatts of wind generating capacity using 17,000 wind generators. Denmark in the first four months of 1989 produced 70 gigawatt hours of electricity, saving the emission of 350 to 500 tonnes of sulphur dioxide, 210 to 420 tonnes of nitrogen oxides and 52,000 to 87,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide. Australia has some of the very best sites in the world for wind generators but where is our wind program? It has been shut down by Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and other funding cuts. The Pacific Gas and Electric Company, a commercial company operating in California, spends $30m a year on renewables on the ground that photovoltaics will be competitive by the mid-1990s. Some of the most exciting research in this area is being carried out in this country but where is the development research funding coming from? It is coming substantially from overseas and that is the direction to which the research development will return.

Volkswagen, Volvo, Peugeot and Renault all have prototype four-to-five seat cars with fuel consumptions ranging from 81 to 124 miles per gallon. These could be introduced at no greater cost than present models. But we have the Button car plan which takes no account of greenhouse emissions or declining supplies of indigenous hydrocarbon fuels. A sliding sales tax on fuel inefficiency in motor vehicles with rebates for efficiency could fairly quickly steer Australian producers towards cars which the world must use in the future. Since 1979 in the United States, seven times as much energy has come from reduced energy intensity as from all net increases in supply. This has been done at less cost, not more.

In the 10 years 1973 to 1983, reduced United States electrical intensity has saved approximately 141 gigawatts of installed capacity at a marginal capacity cost of $200,000m. So one can achieve very sub-stantial economic savings and at the same time produce and use the energy much more efficiently and achieve substantial improvements in environmental quality with reduced greenhouse emissions. This Government is failing to recognise the advantages which both improved efficiency and renewables could bring. It is not adequately funding developments in these areas. In the words of the matter of public importance, the Government is failing to understand the indissoluble links between good environmental and good economic management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite certain what to say in response to Senator Coulter's speech. I will, however, attempt to interpret what Senator Coulter was saying and comment on it. I must confess that I may need to read the Hansard tomorrow quite carefully to understand all that he was saying.
—Or anything.

—I was certainly finding some of it a little difficult; nonetheless, it was a long night. I gather that the failure of the Government to which Senator Coulter alluded is our failure properly to take account of how we might best deal with energy conservation and research. Related to that, I suppose he is alluding to some other failure in research. In the first part of his speech he gave some analysis of what growth means.
