I can remember an Australian Labor Party colleague from a faction not quite the same as mine-I will not name the colleague because I would hate to embarrass anyone at a time like this-suggesting at a New South Wales conference that there was something wrong with Paul Keating's economics.
—Is he dead?
—As a matter of fact, he sits in the Senate.
—That is not necessarily mutually exclusive on your side.

—That is distracting. My colleague said, `Don't be seduced, delegates, by the politics of growth'. The difficulty with that statement and with what Senator Coulter has said today is that it ignores what human endeavour has been about since time began. There is no question but that the great majority of people want growth and want better standards. A delegate from Tanzania said to me at a conference recently that the only time his people see electricity is when lightning flashes in a storm. The arguments about how we cut emissions from power stations amused him. Over 90 per cent of Tanzania's contribution to carbon emissions come from the burning of wood for cooking. He and the Third World are desperate for a growth path. We, having experienced growth and all the material benefits it brings, will simply not be in a position to say to anyone, `You cannot grow. You must remain where you are'. Rather, we will have to help them to manage their growth so that the damage which is done to our planet is minimised. All countries in the developed world will have to do the same thing. We can have economic growth and yet retain a more than responsible attitude to the environment and to the use of resources.

SPEECH.PARA: I recently returned from a conference in the Netherlands on the greenhouse effect. It focused its efforts on gas emissions and what governments could expect to do over the next 12 months. The facts coming out of that conference were that the whole world is waiting for the report of the international panel on climate change, which is due in July next year, before making final decisions on what might be appropriate targets for reductions in some greenhouse gas emissions. It would seem to be entirely reasonable that the panel was given the task to write the report. In the meantime the United Nations, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, the United Nations environment program and scientists within a range of developed nations will be spending a great deal of their time and their governments' moneys in working out how best to conserve energy in the meantime. The consensus around the world is that the best method of containing greenhouse gas emissions will be by conservation, by making sure we use energy better.

It cannot be said that the Australian Government is lagging behind in that respect. At a meeting of the environment Ministers of Australia and New Zealand held in Victoria in October we undertook a program to look at how the States can best conserve energy in the course of the next few years. We set a target of looking at the possibility of cutting greenhouse gas emissions by up to 40 per cent. People should not be too alarmed by that figure. Those who believe there will be too much pain in doing any of this should remember that we were able to get a reduction in halons and freons and the like of the order of 17 per cent. A figure like 40 per cent with respect to greenhouse gases, therefore, does not frighten me all that much. Naturally, all of the States of Australia and the Australian Government are like the European governments and most of the governments of the world in wanting to make sure that we set about some achievable programs. That is why they are waiting until the research comes in.

Everyone coming out of the conference in Nordvik had to be of the view that around the world everyone was serious about cutting greenhouse gas emissions, with the possible exception of the United States and Japan-two countries to which Senator Coulter referred a number of times during his contribution. They certainly took the hardest line against the possibility of targets being set in the near future. I do not look upon the stance taken by the United States as being a backward one. Like all democratic governments, the Unites States Government will have to go at a pace at which its people will allow. As honourable senators are no doubt aware, in the US Congress there is now a Bill which would greatly reduce emissions of sulphur dioxide, not such a huge problem in Australia. We do not have an acid rain problem here, but in the United States it is an enormous problem. That Bill places an immediate cost impost on industry of $5 billion. If one reads between the lines, one sees that the Bush Administration is a bit concerned about taking on carbon dioxide at the same time. Once the SO2 Bill passes, as I believe it will, the United States Government will move on with the next step. I must concede, however, that I did not glean from speaking to the Japanese delegation that Japan had any plans to reduce emissions seriously in any industry that was causing us concern. That was a real worry. I hope that international pressure will address that in the course of the next 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you're not holding out too much expectation.

—I must concede that the Japanese would appear to be the slowest to realise that they might need to change. Change in Japan will not come easily. I remain an optimist, however. The Japanese gradually reduced their whaling activities, so they may even move on this. Over a five-year period, whaling activity has been reduced enormously. However, the 300 whales taken this year would probably not think of that as a saving grace.
—They are only the ones they tell you the truth about.

—I acknowledge that there is always an argument about how many they take. Nonetheless, the environment Ministers of Australia took the view that we could look at a number of programs immediately. I will not go through a list of examples, although I will provide one to Senator Coulter if he would like. As an example, each State has agreed to participate in some pilot programs where, using particular electricity substations so the results can be measured and the areas from which power is being taken can be identified, the governments are going to provide households with light globes that are much more energy efficient. There are now some phenomenally efficient light globes. We hope that with a 12-month trial of that program we can change the attitude of all governments on questions like this and make sure that those are the sorts of globes that people begin to buy. They will be made to buy them if we make sure that there is such a cost impost on less efficient globes that people will not use them any more.

SPEECH.PARA: Amory Lovins from the Rocky Mountains Institute was in Australia last week and I had the opportunity to talk with him. I am trying to arrange for him to attend the next meeting of the Environment Ministers Council; it may well be that we invite energy Ministers to attend as well. As honourable senators may know, Mr Lovins is a world leader in looking at energy conservation. The sorts of things that he has to say are exciting. He has suggested that those in the energy field in Australia who look upon carbon taxes or even carbon dioxide emission reductions with great trepidation will have to come to realise that there is a very fertile field there for them to make much more money out of than they are currently making from producing power in the way that they do. Mr Lovins's ideas are not those of a crank. He is acting as a consultant to electricity authorities in a range of Asian countries, European countries and in Japan, which is a very good sign. He believes there is a lot of money to be made for those who get in early selling methods of energy efficiency in conservation. The Environment Ministers Council is also looking at what we can do with water heating, which in Australian households uses a great deal of power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very inefficient.

—Yes; they are hopelessly inefficient in their methods. We are confident that very significant gains can be made in looking at just that one area. Obviously we have to take the energy Ministers along with us and that is why I am suggesting that we might have Mr Lovins come and talk to us. He also spoke to me about cars. We have made some real advances in our cars, with the introduction of lead-free petrol and the like in recent years, but there is obviously a long way to go.

SPEECH.PARA: In America there are cars now available on the market-not just prototypes-which are incredibly more efficient than those which we now drive. I would agree with Senator Coulter that Australia needs to look at these cars and their engines very seriously at the earliest opportunity because it may well be that we need to do something about introducing a timetable by which those who import them and those who make them for this country can start the change. That is certainly high on my agenda, although until I have much more information on it I do not think I will be in a position to propose a course of action. I intend to be in a position to do that by the middle of next year. When one looks at the sorts of arrangements that are already under way it is clear that the Government is well and truly looking at some of the things Senator Coulter raised. The matter of public importance states:
The failure of the Government to comprehend the indissoluble links between good environmental and good economic management.

I would have thought there were stunning examples not of our showing a failure but of our infinite capacity to grasp that link. In the last few years, the Government took a decision to ban rainforest logging in north Queensland. The decision on the use of the resource there was made after taking into consideration the cost not only in pure dollar terms but also in the quality of life for Australians, which is more important, in my view, than mere dollar considerations.

The Great Barrier Reef is a wonderful example of the Government understanding the link between good economic and good environmental management. That environment is being preserved, yet it earned over $1 billion from tourism last year. That leads one to the Wesley Vale decision, in which the classic balance had to be determined. We had to get down to the argument of economic management and environmental management. The Australian Government was prepared to take a stand and say that, unless guidelines that were far stricter than those laid down by the Tasmania Government were laid down, the project could not go ahead. That decision took courage. It was not a decision gained after acrimonious Cabinet debate; it was a genuinely unanimous decision. It was so because the facts were overwhelming. Next week-I had thought it was going to be this week and I apologise to Senator Durack, whom I told it would be this week-Cabinet will make a decision on the guidelines for all those who seek to use forest resources for the purpose of a chemical pulp mill. All potential operators will note when they see those guidelines that they are by far the toughest in the world-as well they should be. Again, the Government perceived the link between the two. Simply because the Government is laying down a set of guidelines for kraft chlorine mills does not mean that that is the only technology that is applicable. All chemical mills cause some damage-some much less than chlorine mills. The Government would be interested to hear from anyone who has a proposal to build something a bit different. The Tasmanian Government is encouraging companies to do that. The fact that the Government brings down these decisions will not necessarily mean that there will be a kraft chemical mill built next week in Tasmania. Wherever it is built, it will not be built at Wesley Vale.

In more recent times the Government came up with a truly courageous decision which has received a great deal of public criticism from those aggrieved by the decision, but nonetheless, it has received tremendous public support: That, of course, was the decision on Kakadu to take 98 per cent of the conservation zone and put it into the Kakadu National Park and eventually into the World Heritage area. Obviously, these are difficult decisions which are not taken easily. But when one looks at the results, one realises that it is very difficult to say-in my view, impossible-that the Government failed to comprehend the links between good environmental and good economic management. We have been prepared to take the hard decisions on the hard issues whenever they have come up, and we will continue to do that. Honourable senators can rest assured that the direction the Government is taking will not change. The Government is very firm in that course. I believe that the Australian people applaud us for it.

Rather than produce a motion in the terms of the motion we have before us today, it might be a little fairer if Senator Coulter looked at the very many pluses that the environment has had in the last few years. He will see that the environment has finished well in front. As Senator Coulter well knows, and as Senator Macklin knows no doubt, in spite of whatever Senator Puplick's private views would be, were the Opposition to be elected, the environment would be, unfortunately, due for a very rocky road. Development and economics would win every single time if the Opposition were to be elected to government. The environment would be under very serious threat. The main threat would have come from the former Queensland Government, but that Government has been successfully buried in the last few days and we will now have a Goss Labor Government, which will cooperate with us not only in ensuring that proper decisions are made on Cape York but also in withdrawing a court case on the rainforests which has cost the Queensland taxpayers millions of dollars. And what for? It is all for that blind ignorance and stupidity displayed by the Queensland Nationals, who now amount to not much more than a rump-although they still amount to more than Senator Parer's lot, the Queensland bobsled Liberal Party. There are only four representatives left, and they are all heading downhill and doing it at a great rate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a matter of public importance in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to comprehend the indissoluble links between good environmental and good economic management.

For reasons which are quite different from those advanced by Senator Coulter, the Opposition supports the matter of public importance. It characterises comprehensively the failure of Senator Richardson and his Government in terms of the economic and environmental management for which they have been responsible over the last few years. No sense will be got out of this debate by listening either to the new age nonsense of the Australian Democrats or to the cynical green politics of Senator Richardson and his cohorts in the Australian Labor Party.

The most important single threat to the planet, to the biosphere, to our world environment, is the threat of poverty and the threat of overpopulation. Neither of those problems will be solved without economic growth. The moral culpability of people who say, `Let us have limits to economic growth and let us accept that people in India, people in the Third World, in the poor countries of Central America and South America, and of Sub-Saharan Africa, should be denied the benefits of economic growth, their standards of living should continue to be depressed, people should continue to starve to death, and people should continue to live in misery, rather than have the sort of economic growth without which the problems of world poverty and overpopulation simply cannot be addressed' is reprehensible. It is one of the most morally reprehensible statements that I have ever heard put before this chamber or into the public debate as a whole. This sort of macro-biotic Malthusianism that we get from the Australian Democrats is absolutely morally indefensible. It is for that reason that the intelligent participants in this debate, people like Prime Minister Brundtland, have produced a formula and have started to talk in terms of the slogan of sustainable development-not sustainable non-development, but sustainable development. I shall come back to what Mrs Brundtland and her committee and others have had to say about this in recent months.

I want to make a point about the sort of doomsday predictions that one gets constantly from Senator Coulter in this place. Senator Coulter likes to tell everybody that he is a scientist, and that economists are notoriously bad in making predictions. Yesterday and today he has been bucketing the economists-for whom I hold no particular brief. He tells us that it is only if we listen to the scientists that we will get all of this right. Perhaps I should remind him of Lord Kelvin's prediction. I quote Lord Kelvin, one of this century's most distinguished scientists:
Radio has no future.
Perhaps I should quote Einstein:
There is not the slightest indication that nuclear energy will ever be obtainable. It would mean that the atom would have to be shattered at will.
Perhaps I should quote Lord Rutherford:
The energy produced by the atom is a very poor kind of thing. Anyone who expects a source of power from the transformation of these atoms is talking moonshine.
Perhaps I should quote Lord Kelvin again:
Heavier-than-air flying machines are impossible.
Perhaps I should quote Thomas Watson, the founder and head of IBM in 1943:
I think there is a world market for about two computers.
Perhaps I should quote Lord Kelvin again:
X-rays are a hoax.
Perhaps I should quote the Astronomer Royal of the United Kingdom in 1956:
Space travel is utter bilge.

One could go on at length talking about the sorts of predictions made by people whose minds are firmly rooted in existing, or indeed pre-existing, technology and technological and political solutions and who have absolutely no capacity to understand the capability of human society to address and solve significant problems.

Similarly, we have had all of Senator Richardson's usual cant about how concerned he is about the environment, about the extent to which, if this side of the chamber were in government, there would be some assault upon the environment. Let me remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that, as you would well know, this side of the chamber was formally calling for the Australian Government to refuse to sign the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities at the time that Senator Richardson, as Environment Minister, and Senator Evans, as Foreign Minister, were travelling around this country telling everybody that we ought to sign the minerals convention.

Let me remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it was the commitment given by the coalition parties to work for a 20 per cent targeted reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by the year 2000 that Senator Richardson has consistently said is an irresponsible policy to which he and his Government will not commit themselves. So, as far as these things are concerned, Senator Richardson has indicated quite clearly exactly the balance that he seeks to strike, not between the environment and development or between environment protection and Australia's national economic interest, but quite simply in relation to the one-off calculus of the moment, where the votes happen to lie and whom one can confront at any particular time for no advantage to the environment, for no advantage to the Australian economy, simply for the crude political advantage of the Labor Party.

I said that Prime Minister Brundtland of Norway has, on a number of occasions made comments about the question of sustainable development. She has done so not only in the Brundtland report-she was the chairman of the World Commission on Environment and Development, which produced it-but indeed in the Sir Peter Scott lecture which she delivered in Bristol in October 1986. Prime Minister Brundtland said this:

The World Commission does not believe that a dismal scenario of mounting destruction of national global potential for development-indeed, of the earth's capacity to support life-is an inescapable destiny. The problems are planetary-but they are not insoluble.
She concluded her remarks by saying that solutions to these problems required:
. . . a broadening of the concept of development so that it covers not only economic growth but also social and cultural development.
Nobody would resile from that except, of course, Senator Coulter and the Australian Democrats.

I have said that the approach taken by Senator Richardson on a number of these matters has been based purely upon political considerations. It should not simply be taken that a member of the Opposition would assert that. He should stand condemned from the mouths of his own colleagues, so I propose to quote what the Treasurer, Mr Keating, said about the Wesley Vale decision which Senator Richardson turned his mind to a few moments ago. On the 7.30 Report of 16 March 1989 Mr Keating said:

Well I think part of the problem was that the Government relied on the State of Tasmania to set the environmental guidelines and in the end Tasmania threw the game and we were placed in a position where we couldn't adopt the Tasmanian standards because they were not adoptable. So the responsibility came to us. Now you may deduce from that it may always come to us but if it does on pulp mills we should develop a Commonwealth standard, it's a much better way of approaching the problem than trying to deal with each case by case.

Yet, six months down the track, the Government is still not honouring the promise it made to this chamber to put out acceptable standards on pulp mill guidelines by 30 November. Perhaps I should quote what Mr Kerin has had to say about Senator Richardson and about the way he has conducted his campaign in this country. Mr Kerin said of Senator Richardson:
He wanders around the country bagging the miners and the farmers and all the rest of it . . .

He is not making a significant contribution to the environmental debate. As we all know, Mr Kerin has been chastised by his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and by other members of his Government for exposing Senator Richardson on this matter. No wonder the Sun-Herald, in its editorial of 12 November 1989, said this:

Mr Kerin's arguments in support of `balanced, sustainable development' are sound. He is not a development at any cost politician, but a voice of common sense in a Cabinet largely comprised of howling, vote-catching Opportunists.

That is exactly right. One knows from what Mr Keating, Senator Button and Mr Kerin have had to say that the Government and Senator Richardson stand condemned for their total failure to understand the proper relationship between economic development and environmental protection and management.

In the time we have had available I have not been able to develop the detailed argument which should be developed in terms of the correct approach, the correct strategy, to be taken towards achieving this integration, other than to say that quite clearly there is now a major swing throughout the world to looking at market forces-those much despised forces that Senator Coulter denounces on a regular basis-as the correct solution, the correct technique. This is evident whether one looks at the Treasury Economic Round-Up paper of November 1989 entitled `Developing Government Policy Responses to the Threat of the Greenhouse Effect' or whether one looks at the other end of the political spectrum, at a recent address given by Professor David Bellamy, in which he said:
To set the world on a new path to a sustainable future will cost an immense amount of money. That money must come from industry, and the will to succeed must be market-driven.

It will be not by the regulatory tools suggested by Senator Coulter on every occasion but by the forces of the market place that most progress is going to be achieved in this area, underpinned by the necessary controls which governments rightly ought to put in place. It is on that basis that the Opposition parties have produced a series of policy statements dealing with this matter. In our own environment policy document we make it quite clear that our commitment is to the protection and conservation of the natural environment and that that is unqualified, that we believe we have policies which will integrate conservation and development.

Conservation, like development, is for people and, while development aims to achieve human goals largely through the use of the biosphere, conservation aims to achieve them by ensuring that such uses can continue. We have put out a specific statement entitled `Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions' in which we set out our program for achieving protection of the earth's atmosphere by achieving acceptable standards of greenhouse gas emissions and a target for their achievement.

The Chairman of our Federal rural committee, David Hawker, the Federal member for Wannon, recently released a paper entitled `Agriculture and Our Environment-Making it Work, A Charter for Sustainable Agriculture', in which he develops the arguments which need to be put in place for the management of the nation's agricultural resources in an environmentally sound and ongoing fashion. We have indicated our support for the effective use of the taxation system in this regard. Indeed Mr Peacock, in his `Millennium Milestones' address in August this year, indicated our commitment to have a review of the taxation system so that:
Our taxation arrangements should reward all those individuals and companies alike who act with the greatest degree of environmental responsibility and which penalise those who do not.

We have set out in that document-also in our environmental policy document; in our heritage policy document; in the document titled The Climate Challenge; in our sustainable agricultural policy; in our briefing notes on the reduction of the greenhouse gas emissions and, most recently, in my Alfred Deakin lecture which I gave on 30 November entitled The Environment and the Liberal Tradition-the ongoing commitment we have to achieving a proper link between good environmental management and good economic management. There is absolutely nothing wrong with the underlying principle which Senator Coulter is putting forward. Nor is there anything wrong with the motion which condemns the Government for its failure to understand the indissoluble link which exists between the two. However, Senator Coulter does not offer any realistic solutions whatsoever to overcome the actual problems of providing economic growth and development and, at the same time, sustaining the biosphere and providing a proper level of environmental protection and conservation. The resolution of those problems will wait; it will not wait long. It will only have to wait for the election of the Liberal-National Party government within the course of the next six months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be relieved that I have no intention of following Senator Puplick's childish debating techniques or normal ad hominem diatribes, except to say that the type of venom that drives him obviously flows from his embarrassment as the environment spokesperson for the Opposition. For example, he could not even manage to get the Opposition not to vote against the Democrats when we were seeking to make the Antarctic a world park. He was scrabbling in a month later on that particular issue after we had led the way. Again, he was unable to get the Opposition not to vote against the Democrats motion to take sales tax off recycled paper. Yet he managed to scrabble in about three weeks later with a policy of his own which was identical to ours.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, he did not manage to get the Opposition not to vote against the Democrats when we sought to have effective policies in place to prevent chlorofluorocarbon emissions. He scrabbled in about a month later again with a cobbled policy of his own. So his venom is basically based on the fact that he has had to pick up all of the policies put forward by Senator Coulter and run with them himself; but always after the effect and not before it.

I want to concentrate on a point that he made and that was with regard to world poverty which, in his normal, rather wimpish way, was so far off the point as to be laughable. He made a very clear statement that poverty in the Third World has absolutely nothing to do with our industrial growth. This is absolute nonsense, as anybody who knows anything about the inter-connection of the trading environment in our world would know. The world poverty that exists is very much to do with the wealth of the Western countries. Today, I want to have a look at that other part of Senator Puplick's comments about the market forces which are going to `save us all'. Why private profit should save us was certainly never explained by Senator Puplick; it may be explained later by other Liberal speakers. It would be fascinating to hear where we are going to find private profit in the protection of our environment.

The economic debate has been hijacked by those people who have the most to gain out of it. The whole debate generally takes place in the context of the cost to Australia of economic protection measures. Certainly, the Government goes along with this. We have raised time and time again in this place the need for environmental protection and we are told by the Liberal Party and by the Labor Party about the substantial costs in terms of jobs, profit, income and consumer prices. We got the whole diatribe again from Senator Richardson and Senator Puplick today on that basis. The economic message that we are supposed to be getting is that if we hold business responsible for environmental damage then we are going to lose. The same is said about health, safety regulations in the workplace, economic justice to poorly paid people and about justice to women and to Aboriginal people. Exactly the same types of things are said: `Let us not have any regulation'. Senator Puplick ended his speech by saying, `Let's not have any regulation because the market will look after it all'-those magical people who for private profit are going to be nice to everybody else. The fact of the matter is that they never have been and they never will be.

Economics is seen basically by most people as a mechanism designed to protect businesses from the charges of exploitation, and it does that job fairly well. The fact of the matter is that the financial interests of the business community are not identical to the economic interests of the larger community. We have to look at what type of structure and what type of goods in an economic environment cannot be handled by this market mechanism. There is a number of them. The first group of valuable things in our community that we do not want provided by the commercial market includes roads and human lives. For example, there would be a very large market for buying and selling children, but we do not allow that and we have to ask ourselves why. The list also includes parks and political office. We have a State in Australia which, thank God, has now changed its government, that had an accepted business of buying and selling political offices. We do not buy and sell votes and the like. What do we put in place? We happen to think there are other values and qualities that need to be addressed. So basic food, housing, energy and health care are increasingly provided outside the market through social security programs. The community doubts, and has enormous reservations, as does the Labor Party and, oddly, the Liberal Party, the basic fairness of a market mechanism with regard to the allocations in those areas. Hence the Liberals are going to support some sort of a social security system if they come into power, although not a very good one. They are on the same track of doubting the basic fairness of market allocation.

The second group of valuable goods that we do not think commercial markets could handle well are things like defence, against both external and internal aggression-we are not keen on private armies or police forces-clean air, scenic natural wonders, species threatened with extinction, and stable, secure communities. It is hard to see how anyone could be excluded from enjoying these once they are provided. One can hardly expect people to pay for them in a commercial market setting, or expect somebody to try to produce and sell them at a profit. That is why the market will not and cannot be essentially involved in that type of exercise.

One of the most frequent assertions in public discussion of the environmental quality and the quality of life is that decisions on these matters are mainly non-economic; they are moral, social or of some other nature and then, of course, everybody's judgment differs so you really cannot take account of these particular things. Therefore, it lies, as they say, outside the scope of economics.

If this were true then clothing, motion pictures, music, radio, television, publishing, cosmetics, architecture, interior decorating, dining out and so on-which rely on human beings making quality judgments-would also be said to be non-economic and not subject to rigorous economic analysis. Clearly, producers and consumers in all fields make subjective analyses and judgments. There are substantial disputes over this. Nevertheless, they are seen as part of an economic debate. It is absurd to say that we are placing ourselves outside of the economic debate when we seek to protect environmental values. The reason there is a problem has nothing to do with no unanimity with regard to those judgments. It is because those sought after qualities cannot be provided by a commercial market.

While popular music is adequately catered for by the market, the music of a bellbird in the bush and the non-music of an international jet coming in are not provided for, but they involve essentially the same matters. The absence of a commercial market for environmental services does not make them any less important or any less economic. It is clear that in those types of examples we are pursuing similar qualitative objectives.

I will use another example: pleasant aromas can be pursued by purchasing expensive perfume or an inexpensive air deodorant. Alternatively, we can seek to improve the ambient air quality by reducing the level of various air pollutants that we have in our community. Likewise, we can decorate our surroundings by buying prints, paintings and other goods or, alternatively, we can attempt to save the trees that line the streets. We can purchase sophisticated recordings of music and enjoy them or, alternatively we might save the birds in our urban environments and reduce the level of ambient noise to our houses. The objectives are similar but items such as perfumes, fine art and music recordings can make a profit, while, clearly, others, such as clean air, trees in our streets and reduced levels of noise are not part of the market system. Public goods, from which people cannot be excluded, cannot be produced at a profit by a private firm. Nevertheless, they are an essential part of our economic environment.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made a point that he is about to launch a campaign on the urban environment. Indeed, he should, since our cities are plagued with air pollution, congestion, noise and general grime. However, some suburbs have quiet streets, less noise and less congestion. The houses in these environments have a considerably higher price tag than an identically sized house of similar quality in a polluted suburb. Selling and buying houses is an important economic activity. The subjective judgments made on environmental grounds do not baffle home buyers or real estate agents; indeed, the private pursuit of higher quality environments has transformed our cities in the last 30 years. Millions of Australians-unlike what Senator Richardson has said-have voted with their feet with regard to the environment and are willing to spend tens of thousands of their own hard-earned dollars for better environmental circumstances in which to live.

Unfortunately with no-one in control until recently when government took a hand, these environmental aspects were not under the control of anybody. Hence we could release anything into the air, which we all have to breathe. In the absence of good zoning laws, property owners could do what they liked with their land. They could destroy parkland, vistas and outdoor recreational opportunities. They could create more noise, congestion and grime and, in the process, the very things that bring well-being were destroyed.

The exercise is very clear. It is probably made most clear when we look at the effect of air pollution on health. Most people would feel at least some sympathy on this matter. Medical reports from major cities around the world indicate that a 50 per cent reduction in air pollution leads to a 25 per cent reduction in lost work days and a 15 per cent reduction in days of reduced activity due to pollution-induced illness. If we cleaned up our air entirely, the average number of sick days in Australia would decline by 1.7 million per year. If the values assigned to non-fatal accidents are applied to this type of reduced illness, we are looking at an economic gain straight off of $57m. If we add pollution-caused deaths, estimated to be around 9,500, we are looking at an economic gain of the order of $800m a year.

Quite frankly, it is absurd to suggest in any way that people would want to vote with their feet on this issue. In fact, every time this question has been put clearly and unambiguously to the people they have opted for quality of life over standard of living. They want more secure communities, clean air, clean water and, by and large, the suburban and urban environments where people live to be environmentally safe, secure and pleasant. They are willing to do that at a cost, and they are willing to wear that cost. They ask: Why is it that public goods such as the ones that I have just raised should be converted into private profit? The people of Australia are now standing up and being counted on this matter and those who get in their way will be walked over.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devereux Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance raised by Senator Coulter, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to comprehend the indissoluble links between good environmental and good economic management.

In my view that claim just cannot be sustained. If the Australian Democrats were to change to wording slightly and replace the word `Government' with `Opposition' it would certainly get my wholehearted support. It is clear on hearing Senator Puplick's contribution today that there certainly is not any grasp of the connection in the Opposition parties.

Before I go any further I will comment on one thing that Senator Puplick said. I do not think he said anything else that is worth commenting on. I notice that Senator Macklin also picked up this point. Senator Puplick commented that there was a problem throughout the world of population growth and poverty. I could not agree more with him that that is an enormous problem. He then went on to say that the answer to that is greater economic growth throughout the world. I find that quite remarkable because if we were to continue in the way we are with economic growth we would simply be creating circumstances where some people end up getting richer. It will do nothing at all to solve the problems of those suffering from poverty and starving in underdeveloped countries. Absolutely no argument could be put forward to refute that. Quite interestingly that is the tack that Senator Puplick took today on debating this matter of public importance. In another circumstance, when the present Opposition was in government in Tasmania, its policies on the issue of the environment were rejected by the people. On 30 June 1989, after the election, the following comment was made by Senator Puplick:

It's a significant loss, but I don't think it's a disaster, and in fact in some respects, it has this compensating factor. I think it indicates to the people on the mainland or, as my Tasmanian friends like to say, on the north island, exactly what the so-called green movement really is all about. Not a genuinely independent political movement, but essentially a political movement of the left and one which I think people in the rest of Australia will now see exposed as frankly just another political organisation.

Clearly, every time the Opposition spokesman for the environment is confronted with a question about the policies of the Opposition he tries to deflect the argument with the sort of nonsense that was in that quote and what he went on with today.

Let me come to the proposition that is before the Senate. As far as Senator Coulter's contribution is concerned, I think I am in the same boat as Senator Richardson. I will have to look very closely at the Hansard tomorrow. It would be reasonable to say that I support the principles put forward by Senator Coulter. I do not want to go over the ground which was covered by Senator Richardson and Senator Macklin in their contributions. I want to highlight two important areas in a practical sense to try to bring home the fact that it is not quite as simple as Senator Coulter would have us believe. He says that as a Federal government we can simply make decisions that will solve all of these problems. It is not that simple. He did make the comment-and I agree wholeheartedly with it-that there is an enormous waste of electrical energy in Australia. The difficulty is that we are dealing with State governments who are in control of the power production in the States. As Senator Richardson said, there are attempts being made to get some agreement to do something about that. But it is not just a simple matter of our making a few speeches in the Senate and fixing the problem. We need cooperation and we need to set about that in a very practical way.

I particularly want to highlight two areas in my State and some of the difficulties that we faced in those areas. I am talking about the decision not to allow the Franklin Dam to proceed and the Wesley Vale decision. There is no doubt that in those two decisions the Federal Government was motivated as much by economic circumstances as it was by environmental ones, and so it should have been. As far as the Franklin was concerned, the Federal Government had to make a decision to stop the State Government from proceeding with that proposal. In doing so, the Federal Government had enormous pressure applied to it by the Liberal Party of Australia, by businesses, and so forth-not just in Tasmania but throughout the country. They argued that it was interfering with decisions within a State. It has been proved beyond any doubt that the decision that was taken, not only on environmental grounds, was absolutely the correct decision, as was argued at the time. More importantly, in my view, it would have been a decision of economic stupidity to have proceeded.

Since that decision, the King and Anthony power schemes have been brought on line as substitutions for the scheme and work to construct those two schemes was started, substantially with money provided by the Federal Government. We are now well down the track with them. The decision has been made that it will take at least three years longer than anticipated to build them, not because the work cannot be carried out but simply because now the truth of what was said by many people during that debate is emerging: there was no need for the power. That is irrefutable.

When the debate with respect to Wesley Vale was on, we had all sorts of weird and wondrous things bandied about: it was going to create 500 to 700 jobs, and what a wonderful thing it was going to be for Tasmania. The truth is that, on the company's figures supplied to unions in discussions, there were to be 300 jobs in that mill. At the same time as that mill was to come on line, Long Reach would have been shut down and 250 jobs would have been lost. At Triabunna, because of the effects of loss of resource, a number of jobs would have been lost there. In Burnie, the possibility existed that, because of the antiquated machinery there, that one would have been shut down and a number of jobs would have gone there. It is a very conservative estimate to say that another 200 jobs would have been lost. Wesley Vale would not have created these 500 to 600 jobs that the gloom and doom merchants were saying would disappear if we did not proceed with it. We have to take into account the fact that, if it had proceeded and the Federal Government had been irresponsible, we would have wiped out millions of dollars for the fishing industry in Tasmania once the pollution started to belch out in Bass Strait. They are the sorts of decisions that have been taken by the Government. On those sorts of decisions and on a number of others that Senator Richardson spoke of, it is fairly hard to sustain the contention, as Senator Coulter has tried to do in this matter of public importance, that this Government has not been prepared to take the hard decision and link the environment and the economy together. Sure, we would all like to go much further, but in the real world-and here we get to the real nub of the problem-as Senator Coulter said in his contribution, there needs to be cooperation. There certainly does need to be cooperation. I believe that that process is starting to happen.

Again I refer to the situation in Tasmania, because I think that, in the whole question of environmental problems that we are facing, Tasmania has been one of the real battlefields. Great credit must be given to the people concerned, particularly now that there is a new Government in Tasmania which is prepared to cooperate. With regard to the forestry operations in Tasmania, there is today a delegation from Tasmania talking to members of Cabinet about a proposal which, I hope, may lead to there not being any need for logging in National Estate areas in the future. The people involved in the delegation demonstrate the level of cooperation we want. They are the Tasmanian Government, the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association, the combined environment groups, the Forest Industries Association of Tasmania, the Tasmanian Trades and Labor Council and the Forestry Commission of Tasmania. We, as a society, must get together people with differing views, such as these groups, and convince them that the right track to go down is the track of getting people all of the information that they require to make an informed decision and of making all of that information available in a proper way to the public, in particular people in workplaces, because people in workplaces have been entirely misled for many years over these sorts of questions.

I might just digress for a moment and say that, when the debate over the construction of the Franklin Dam was at its peak, there were public statements made and a newsletter went around to every worker at Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd which told all of the workers that, if the dam was not built, there would be 1,000 people sacked in their industry. It was absolute nonsense. It was designed to scare people and to ensure that they voted in a certain way. If decisions that we make with regard to the environment and the economy of this country are made on the basis of people sending out those sorts of scare letters, and if there is no other means of education of the public or the work force, we will always have this conflict and we will not be able to solve the problems that we are facing.

In finishing, I simply say to Senator Coulter that I totally agree with him when he says that we must have cooperation. But I think Senator Coulter ought to have some discussions with some of the independents in Tasmania. They have been put in a situation, a very healthy situation, where, because they are really part of the Government in Tasmania, they cannot so comfortably get up in Parliament and publicly demand that things will be done knowing full well that they will never have to deliver. They have had to reassess their thinking on a whole range of matters and determine how they will approach them. I think that is very healthy. I suggest that the Australian Democrats ought to consider that sort of process. Maybe they ought to sit down more often with the Government and talk about some of these issues rather than simply suggest solutions by way of press releases and matters of public importance. Constructive discussions which take place behind the scenes often lead to a more satisfactory outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, rise to speak on the subject of the matter of public importance, which is:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to comprehend the indissoluble links between good environmental and good economic management.

For a start, I think it is fair to say that it has really been quite interesting to hear the different subjects that have been raised by earlier speakers. I will deal with this matter in my own way. In the 15 minutes which I have to speak on such a broad subject, I intend to focus mainly on the question of forestry. But, in view of the contribution by Senator Devereux, I think I should also say something about the Wesley Vale mill.

I wish to point out that it is very easy for people with a negative frame of mind to look back and blame everybody who has gone before. The only reason for looking back is to learn. We should not condemn people for doing what, at the time, was deemed to be reasonably in our interests. It is an absolute cop-out just to look back and blame someone else. What we must do at all times is demonstrate that we have learnt from what has happened. It is our job in this place to look forward. We have to look at the present and at the future. We have to deal with our problems; that is why we are here.

Our legacy is the future and that is the matter I wish to deal with. We are expected to provide economic opportunities for the future and to do so within safe and sustainable environmental limits. I believe that that is a reasonable statement and that is the way this topic should be looked at. I believe that we should achieve a sound, safe and reasonable balance. `Balance' is a word that has not been used in the debate today. I believe that our future lies in this word. Development is absolutely essential and it must be done carefully.

I turn now to the pulp mill question. May 1989 saw Tasmania change government in what was a pulp mill election. A party with 34 per cent of the popular vote is now in government. The story of that campaign is absolutely pathetic and I guess that the part played by Senator Richardson and his colleagues will haunt them forever. The decision that Senator Richardson ultimately foisted upon us was stupid, short-sighted, ill-informed, poorly based, politically inspired and wrong. And all the time he had available to him the right advice, starting with Mr Kerin and Mr Kerin's junior associate. We saw the politics of ignoring the facts and falling for the desperate loony fringe and the sensational, distorted hysteria of the day.

In fact, the election was fought on one thing-the tonnes and tonnes of deadly dioxin that were going to kill everybody. But we were never told what this dioxin was all about. We were never told that it was the same dioxin that the people complaining about it emit from their cars, burn in their incinerators or in their backyard barbecues. Accordingly, we were given the impression that that sort of dioxin was all right, but that dioxin from a pulp mill was bad and we had to be careful about it. We saw an hysterical, overstated, politically inspired campaign of absolute rubbish. Of course, it was not until after the event that we started to find out a bit more about it. For instance, the Australian Associated Press report of 1 November states:
Some scientists had duped the public into an exaggerated view of the health risks of dioxin, a senior government scientist said today.
It has been played up by some unscrupulous scientists . . . so in that sense they (the public) have been duped . . .
The report also states:
The statement noted that there had been widespread community concern at the possibility that dioxin in paper products was a health hazard.

This hysteria was whipped up. But, really, we have to take account of the facts. How many dioxin-related deaths are there in Australia? How many do we suffer per year? The answer is: nil. There have been no deaths in Tasmania and none in Australia. The next death in the world that can be identified as being caused by dioxin will be the first one. Yet we fought an election on the hysteria generated by this matter. We must not capitulate to these problems. Our entire generation is taking notice of negative people when we should be saying, `We recognise that there is a problem and we will deal with it'. Let us deal with the problems; do not let us capitulate to them. Still, that is the way it goes.

Of course, the pulp mill proposal has been shelved. Ostensibly, it was destroyed on environmental grounds when we all know that it was really shot to pieces on political grounds. It suited the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and his henchman to shoot it down. If there had been a degree of bona fides, we would have had the guidelines by May; we would certainly have had them six months later, by the end of November. But I believe that the Minister was hoping that we would be out of this place before these guidelines became available. Is it good economic and environmental management to run a country like this? We are talking of linking the environment and economics; that is what this matter of public importance is all about.

The Wesley Vale mill and the Huon Forest Products mill were going to utilise an otherwise unused resource. A recent survey which I saw and the veracity of which I do not doubt, said that, as a result of various projects that this new Tasmanian Government has shelved, put aside, or cancelled, 7,000 jobs have been lost in Tasmania. These two mills would have been able to produce and export a very good value-added resource which, in turn, would have led to a huge investment in our forestry plantation industry and I am sure that this is one of the things that even Senator Coulter would support. What a stupid example of a lack of balance between the environment and economics! Does Senator Richardson fully appreciate that, in our wood products alone, we have a balance of trade deficit of $1 1/2 billion per year? We are still rolling up heaps of logs in various parts of Tasmania and burning them because this Government will not provide an export licence so that they can be exported at a profit. They have no other value.

As a result of the way in which everybody treats it, poor old Tasmania's major mineral areas and vast areas of degenerating forests are being locked away and there is no prospect of their being unlocked. One of the major tourist roads that has been planned for years and was being worked on as at the date of the election has been stopped. The Antarctic industry in Hobart has been stopped in its tracks. The new tourism operator of magnitude in Tasmania, P and O is now putting its developments on hold because it does not know whether there will be any development. Where are we going as far as the environment and economics are concerned?

I turn now to the forests. The big news about forests is the one billion trees referred to by Senator Richardson. Mind you, that is not to be confused with the funding of the program or with the planting of the trees. It does not take account of the fact that people are supposed to plant these trees. These trees somehow will magically appear. It is a lovely piece of gimmickry and it sounded good the day that he said it. When one examines it, one sees that the commitment is different.

What have we done to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Division of Forestry? We have hacked into it. What have we done to Mr Francis Clarke? On 21 November the Australian said:
Pragmatic conservationist Mr Francis Clarke has little faith in the Federal Government's environmental initiatives or research strategies.
His intention was to assist the CSIRO with six research projects on the potential of planting trees for profit while maintaining the same number of cattle and sheep grazing numbers.
But the six CSIRO projects . . . have all been abandoned because of funding cuts.

That was one of the great forestry projects of Australia. Thousands of farmers all over Australia were interested and involved in it. They were watching it. But, according to the Australian of 21 November, the project has been cut because the funds were cut. That is what this Government thinks about the forests and forestry, and environment and economics.

What are the plans? Is there a national plan for forests? Is the Government genuine? We all know that this billion-tree project is humbug, but what is the plan and what is the philosophy? The coalition supports the National Conservation Strategy for Australia of June 1983 which says:
Development and conservation are but different expressions of the one process. Together they are the means of providing for the needs of the present and the future.

The World Conservation Strategy's three main objectives are to maintain essential ecological processes and life support systems; to preserve genetic diversity; and to ensure the sustainable utilisation of species and ecosystems. That is what the strategies say and that is what we say. It is important that the World Conservation Strategy talks about utilisation. We must not get to the stage of thinking that if something is valuable it must be locked up. We are locking forests up and the ultimate result in Tasmania is that we must burn them to get rid of them when we should be conserving them.

I now want to look at the Resource Assessment Commission. I hope that it does a very good job but we should not forget that in 12 years Tasmania has already had 10 inquiries on forestry. Will this be another? Will it just delay the process another two years, which is the time limit of the inquiry? What is the Government's commitment? I have never heard it say what it is, but I hope it does so. Forestry and the forest products industry should be targeted industries. They need to be planned on a 20- to 50-year basis. There needs to be real and proper planning. We need a program of research in breeding, growing and harvesting, end use, product development and recycling. It is ludicrous that Australia has a deficit of $1 1/2 billion.

The Tasmanian forestry operation is a model as far as it goes but there are tens of thousands of hectares of old degenerating forests. They are lovely in theory but are death traps as far as carbon dioxide emission is concerned. They give off about five times as much carbon dioxide as they absorb. That is terrible in relation to the ecology of the country. Why do we not hack them down and put in good viable trees that will get us somewhere? Let us not fall for the `Stop it; we don't like it' approach. If there is a problem, we can fix it. I do not care whether it is the bush, the very fast train project, or whatever. We should not dwell on the problems; we should dwell on the solutions and fix the problems. It is up to us to look after the solutions for the next generation. Does the Government have a plan? Where is Australia going? Is Australia an industrial society? Is it research based? Are we a pre-banana republic society? What are we? Like most Australians, I want to be told.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recommend that Senator Archer go back to his science books for some further and better particulars about the functions of old growth forests and the contribution they and new growth forests make to the carbon dioxide problem. I want to address the subject matter of our matter of public importance this afternoon. I have considered it and I think I agree with its spirit but perhaps not exactly the form of words used to express it. I do not believe that the Government has entirely failed to comprehend the link between good environmental and good economic management; it just has not done enough about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Actions, not words-or even major statements such as the greatest environmental policy that ever was-are the measures we should use to judge the Government's commitment. Whether the Government understands the linkage or not, some members of the Government certainly have a firm grip on the rhetoric of the subject. Just a few weeks after fulminating about the vile and insidious influence of the environmental movement on the Government's Coronation Hill decision-or rather, non-decision-the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) was using all the correct liturgical environmental phrases like `sustainable development'-as if anybody would ever advocate unsustainable development. He did this during relatively considered reflection on the relationship between development and environmental protection. However, I suspect that by `sustainable development' Mr Kerin might mean something different from what is meant by conservationists. Many different issues and problems are lumped together under the `environment' heading. We have heard about a number of them during this debate. These issues ought to be considered properly as belonging to different categories that demand different responses because they have different bearings on our economic management. They can be divided into global, national and local issues. I want to take examples from each.

The first is the big picture-the global problems. This category includes the global problems that are basically pollution effects from human activities, including the greenhouse effect and the problems with the ozone layer. The possible economic influence of these problems in the long term is incalculable but we seriously need to be able to calculate them and to adjust our behaviour to minimise the damage and perhaps to survive in the new environments that will be created.

Obviously Australia cannot solve these problems by itself but there is a need for Australia to take them seriously by collaborating in international efforts to solve them and also by identifying the impact of these problems on our local region. For instance, a lot of atmospheric testing is currently being done in the Northern Hemisphere but we must search for solutions to the possible greenhouse effects in the Southern Hemisphere. Predictably such research is concentrating on effects elsewhere and not enough is being done here in Australia, as Senator Coulter has already pointed out.

These headline threats are the most serious but there are many others. We are just beginning to realise how widespread the damage to the global environment is. The discovery a long time ago of high concentrations of dangerous synthetic chemicals in animals living in the Arctic and Antarctic regions reveals that we are messing up the whole planet. This does not primarily demand the allocation of blame, as we heard earlier in this debate. Yesterday's miracle product has turned out to be today's problem. This calls for a new approach which neither the Government nor the Opposition is able to develop adequately.

On the national level, more and more of our environmental problems are being thrown into the national basket and perceived to be the responsibility of the Federal Government. This is properly so. The States lack the resources, the competence or the necessary national perspective to solve some of these problems. Perhaps the most critical problems we presently have are coastal pollution and coastal erosion right around the country. Many decisions relating to these matters are left up to local government, and we know that there are serious problems with local government in some areas, particularly in New South Wales and particularly in the northern regions, although I do not believe the problems are restricted to those regions.

The Federal Government is also expected to provide the planning for the profitable and sustainable use of our resources, both our human resources and our natural resources. Up to a point, I sympathise with the Government. It is being pushed into the future at a pretty frightening pace-but so are we all. We must expect more from government than suggestions like Senator Richardson's that in the future we might have a referendum to see whether the people of Australia are willing to pay the price for a responsible and sustainable approach to the environment. Of course, a referendum is not necessary.

In fact, the legislation I introduced into this place a couple of weeks ago would certainly give the Federal Government the power to protect National Estate areas and perhaps, by doing so, it would also develop the willpower to provide some immediate solutions to alternative employment in those areas, particularly in the south-east of New South Wales. We must have better leadership than this at a critical time. Our leaders, including Senator Richardson, ought to be presenting well-developed long term plans to the electorate and not just making the passive and vague suggestions that they do. It is a lot to ask but we have to ask more of our governments these days. The days when we hoped to find sport rather than politics or economics on the front pages of our newspapers are well and truly past.

One aspect of our economy that troubles me is our continuing dependence on the export of unprocessed raw materials. It is also the feature of our economy that generates most conflicts over the balance between industry development and environmental protection. This dependence makes us very vulnerable to powerful buyers and unscrupulous competitors in the international marketplace and in the past we have lost out badly. We need only look at the prices that are paid for Australian coal and look at the effect of United States wheat subsidies on Australian wheat. Our exports, I believe, of the raw materials that we have in this country ought to be the cream of our economy and not our staple diet.

Let us look at the south-east forests as an example of a State issue that has been dumped into the national basket, particularly this year. Changing our whole economic structure is a very big task but there are some immediate areas where change in this direction is not only possible and desirable but also absolutely essential. I have said quite a bit about south-east forests in this chamber. In fact, just a couple of nights ago I spoke on the subject of future planning for the forestry industry in the south-east. It is a good example of an unsustainable approach to resource use. I cannot resist quoting, just one more time, the words of our eminent Senator Button, who described the woodchip business as a `bastard of an industry'. I know why Senator Button said that. It was because he understood that we were losing much of our unreplaceable natural resources and we were getting so little for them. I accept that the export of woodchip will continue, for a while at least. But we cannot afford to degrade permanently our native forests, especially for such meagre returns.

A better approach to this particular situation has become increasingly clear, largely because of the efforts of environmentalists opposed to the status quo. It is the underresourced environmental groups which have come up with the most wide-ranging solutions to the problems of jobs in the south-east region of New South Wales. I believe that they have developed a reasonable program and only the details need to be filled in. Everyone seems to agree that hardwood plantations are a good idea and that they should have been established some time ago.

In the event of the failure of the New South Wales Forrestry Commission to establish them, I believe that the Federal Government should make some genuine and immediate commitment in this area, instead of having more studies done. It is obvious, and has been obvious for quite some time, that value added timber processing industries will have to be established in this region if employment expectations are to be satisfied. I have said many times that it would be a very poor victory for the conservation movement if jobs have to be lost in the south-east region. That is not sustainable development. We cannot afford to protect our environment and have, at the same time, people who are out of jobs, who are facing mortgages and who have children to feed and educate. We need to have long term planning to ensure that we do not have this sort of conflict in the community, which is a conflict that only arises out of the short term opposition to jobs in the environment, industry and our natural resources.

Returning to another area, I believe that vital research is necessary for both environmental management and agricultural productivity and sustainability and this area is being neglected, although some money is being put into electorally fashionable areas. On this very interesting matter, shortly after the great environmental policy was put out Mr John Langmore on 31 August asked a question in the other place about programs in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). It seems to me that it is quite hypocritical for the Government to put out an environmental policy to get electoral kudos and votes out of that environmental policy when, at the same time, the CSIRO programs are being decimated. There are pages of this in Hansard. Many areas have been cut back or could not be fulfilled because of lack of money for our most important national research organisation. But here are some important research projects which have been curtailed or terminated. Cuts have had to be made in research into the ecology of native forests. This research is critical if we want to establish native hardwood plantations. At the moment, we have another rabbit plague but I find in the Hansard the answer:
All rabbit control research other than that funded by the Wool Corporation has been terminated.
Turning over the page, I find:
New important initiatives not begun
Developments, via molecular biological approaches, to induce sterility in wild rabbits, as an effective means of rabbit control-
not begun-
Developments in the work on distinguishing land degradation from natural change, and on erosion forecasting, are over two years behind-
not begun-
Research into how to prevent species lost in the remnant vegetation of the western wheat belt has had to ignore all of the insects, owing to the loss of scientists.

The two most eminent entomologists in the CSIRO have lost their jobs. This is a much under-rated area of research in Australia and yet it is vital to our agricultural industry; it is vital to our possible hardwood plantations. Yet how much of this has got into the media? Very little of it.

There is a different class of local problem that is represented by the dispute over the third runway which is proposed for the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The environmental degradation aspect here primarily affects the urban area and its residents. It is not a natural asset. Nonetheless, in view of the conservation moves by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) into urban areas, I think that this is another typical example of the Government's hypocrisy. It recently paid $100,000 to the community groups which are opposing the third runway when it has the option of alleviating the problem immediately. The third runway is merely a stopgap measure. The Badgerys Creek proposal is something that I was writing about in a local paper 10 years ago. We may well blame previous governments, but this Government has been in office now for six years and has not done anything about it.

The reason that this is so important is that efficient transport facilities are necessary for long-term planning in this country. The failure of planning, as in this case, will result inevitably in the environment of Sydney being severely degraded through the noise pollution, the air pollution and, in addition, the safety problems over the city. I have no doubt that that $100,000 was given because-in view of the experience of the Balmain electorate in the State election-the Government may well be very worried about mass defections from the Labor Party if that third runway proposal goes ahead because of the numbers of people in those electorates who oppose it.

If we do not begin to restructure, to provide sustainable industries based on a minimum of irreplaceable resource consumption and a minimum of environmental degradation, we will not have a place among the truly developed nations of the future. The maintenance of our environment, the control of what we put into it and take out of it are not luxuries that we can indulge in. If we feel that we can afford it, it is fundamental to our long-term economic performance. I must say that I was surprised at Senator Richardson's stunning examples and I for one am not stunned. I am thinking of more recent examples such as the non-decision on Kakadu National Park. I have no doubt that if the Labor Party is returned to government mining will go ahead at Coronation Hill. The Opposition speakers have already referred to the indecision on pulp mills. Of course, we have the continuing open wound of the south-east forests.

Senator Richardson warns against a Liberal government environment policies. I would have to agree with him because I find them to be rather confused. But this is no reason to become complacent about the Government's policy. It should not be forgotten that the Government's environment policy was drafted only after the Tasmanian election results. Those results stress the importance of having environmentally concerned parliamentary representatives who are free of the strictures of the major political parties. It is the presence of those representatives in Parliament that will not only remind governments of their environmental commitments but also be instrumental in strengthening those commitments which are the basis of preserving the environment, protecting and enhancing our quality of life, and encouraging industries which are genuinely sustainable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the following matter of public importance raised by Senator Coulter:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to comprehend the indissoluble links between good environmental and good economic management.

As pointed out by my colleague Senator Puplick, the Opposition supports that view of the Government. I will just discuss briefly what I understood Senator Coulter to be saying. I may be wrong because I think we all had some difficulty with the apparent deep philosophical content of his speech. I thought that what would be worth pursuing initially is what is meant by `sustainable development'. As Senator Dunn said, it obviously means different things to different people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sustainable growth, not development, because growth has a very specific meaning.

—Sustainable development is a term that is publicly accepted. I was defining it, but I will come to Senator Coulter's comments on growth in a minute when I touch on his comments. It was interesting to note the definitions given by various people. Brian Loton, Deputy Chairman and Managing Director of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, stated in a recent address:

SPEECH.PARA: The sciences, combined with application and enterprise, have done wonders to deliver high living standards based on expanding use of the world's mineral wealth. By this success, though, they have also raised weighty questions about the management of many side-effects and by-products of the increased tempo of human activity.
Knowledge hasn't stopped there. The same blend of science and reason is capable of giving solutions to the new generation of industry challenges, as much as to the old ones.

That basically supports the optimistic view that I and Senator Archer would take as compared to the modern Malthusians as represented by Senator Coulter. That is the full significance of the concept and objective of sustainable development.

Our Common Future, published in April 1987 and sometimes called the Brundtland report, is the most recent of a series of global environmental statements, which are widely accepted by all sections of the community. In the foreword there is this important statement:
Environment is where we all live and development is what we all do in attempting to improve our lot within that abode. The two are inseparable.

Our Common Future, the Brundtland report, follows the world conservation strategy, which identifies three prime issues: the maintenance of ecological processes and life support systems; the preservation of genetic diversity; and ensuring sustainable use of species and ecosystems. Brundtland suggests that sustainable development is another goal but further suggests that sustainable development is also a method for reaching the common goals of the Brundtland report and the world conservation strategy.

In the time I have left I will comment on some of the remarks made by previous speakers, particularly Senator Coulter. Senator Coulter made a point which I find incredible. He said that growth is making poverty in poorer countries worse. I think it is recognised that one of the great problems in the poor countries is lack of development. We do not have to look too far afield-bearing in mind that we in this country are very fortunate with what we have in our inherent wealth-to see that if we could get the sort of developments in those poorer countries that apply in the more developed countries, many of their problems would be solved. We have recent examples of this. There are countries in our own region, the South East Asia region, which but a decade ago were Third World countries but today have left this country behind. Good examples are Korea, Taiwan and, more recently, Thailand.

TALK.START.PARA: —In what respect?

—In the growth of their economies and in their ways of life compared to their situation years ago. Prosperity comes with economic growth. This prosperity will lift the standards of living of all people.
—It depends how that economic growth is distributed.

—I agree. If I had time, I would debate that a bit further, too, because Senator Devereux made some remarkable statements about that. Senator Coulter also spoke of the greenhouse effect and of stopping carbon emissions, and so on. It is interesting that when we mention greenhouse-friendly options such as producing power from nuclear energy, the Democrats throw up their hands in horror and throw themselves to the ground. Senator Coulter also said that nuclear energy is not competitive. The question I would ask of Senator Coulter is: If nuclear energy is not competitive, why are countries going into nuclear energy? Again, the answer is very simple.
