With Australia's natural wealth, we tend to make those fine criticisms, but here are other countries that do not have the energy resources that we have and rely on imports to feed their power generation units to provide electricity for their people. They have to make a choice certainly on the capital cost of nuclear plants and other factors that can determine the ready supply of the cheapest electricity they can get.

SPEECH.PARA: The countries that have moved to nuclear generation are, in the main, those that do not have other resources. Good examples are Korea, Japan-both running at about 30 per cent generation from nuclear-and France, running at about 50 per cent, because of the high cost of its indigenous coals and the high cost of coals from other European countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Japan has a marvellous source of geothermal energy.

—Of all the people in this world, those who would go to the most cost-effective would have to be the Japanese. Yet to a large extent they still rely on the importation of coals from places such as Australia and, of course, uranium for the 30 per cent of their energy that is nuclear-generated.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson, when defending his Government in its handling of environmental matters, said that when hard decisions had to be made, the Government made them. What incredible nonsense! Sure, Senator Richardson makes a hard decision when it relates to a small number of people and where it does not affect in any way the political outcomes in a seat of government. But what about the fact that our roads are chock-a-block with semitrailers that go from Melbourne to Sydney and to Brisbane? Has the Government confronted the really hard decisions of coastal shipping and the waterfront? They are the decisions that count. It is absolutely obscene that it is cheaper and more effective, per unit, to move half a dozen motor vehicles on a semitrailer from Melbourne to Brisbane than to put them on a boat and take them up in maybe 100 or 200 lots. That is what we mean by hard decisions-which Senator Richardson will not and cannot confront.

TALK.START.PARA: —And railways. You have no problem with me on that one.

—Senator Coulter could not agree more when it comes to railways. Senator Macklin raised the old phoney story, yet again-and I paraphrase what he said-`Profit is a dirty word'. He puts all the problems of the world down to the fact that people need to make a profit to survive. What is forgotten is that the tax paid on those profits, whether by way of company tax or pay as you earn tax, enables government not only to function but also to exist and to provide roads, hospitals, power stations and all the other things that people need. Today there seems to be a political battle between the Australian Democrats and the Government to capture the minority lunatic fringe and not responsible conservationists.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. The discussion on the matter of public importance is concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The statement Australia's Regional Security which I table today is a substantial document covering not only an analysis of the global and regional security environment, but also the formulation, implementation and presentation of Australia's policy responses. In these introductory comments, I intend only to highlight the statement's main themes, with particular emphasis on the multidimensional approach to security policy advocated in it. I should say at the outset that this statement was not motivated by any concern that Australia's strategic environment was deteriorating, or that we needed to revise the basic policy assumptions behind our regional security policies. Rather, it resulted from a prudent wish, at a time of rapid and fundamental change in the international and regional environment, to review our regional security interests and policies, and to set out in a comprehensive and integrated way our approach to the pursuit of those interests.

SPEECH.PARA: The overarching theme of the statement is that the most effective regional security policy is a multidimensional policy: one in which all the components of Australia's network of relations in the region-military and politico-military capability; diplomacy; economic links; assistance with development and so-called non-military threats; and the exchange of people and ideas-work together to help shape a security environment which is favourable to Australia's interests.

The statement acknowledges the very important contribution that an effective military capability makes to national security. But it also seeks to set defence policy in the wider context of Australia's regional relations, emphasising the way in which defence policy is both supportive of wider policy and in turn supported by it. Military capability is just one among many instruments of an effective security policy. The geographical scope of the statement encompasses the South Pacific, South East Asia, including Indo-China and Myanmar, and the eastern reaches of the Indian Ocean-essentially the same area described in the 1987 Defence White Paper as our region of primary strategic interest.

The maintenance of a positive security environment in our region, so defined, is only one of our overall foreign policy priorities. Other priorities include pursuing trade, investment, and economic cooperation, where North East Asia, North America and Europe are of major importance; contributing to global security, including through our alliance with the United States and our active involvement in multilateral disarmament negotiations; and playing our part as good international citizens in the resolution of global-scale problems from threats to the environment to human rights abuses.

Even within the field of security interests, the statement's regional focus does not imply that developments outside the region are marginal to Australian security. The avoidance of nuclear war, the security of the Persian Gulf, the conventional balance in Europe and the military balance in North Asia all have implications for Australian security. Moreover, in a world of extensive economic interdependence, the boundary lines between regions are increasingly blurred. South East Asia is becoming more and more integrated with the economies of North East Asia, vertically and horizontally, as the Asia-Pacific chain of development is pushed south. Australia itself is already closely tied economically with the dynamic economies of North East Asia. These are all trends which will become more pronounced over the 10 years-plus time span that the statement covers, and it would be unrealistic to expect that the strategic map of the region will somehow be insulated from this changing economic map.

Yet currently, and for the foreseeable future, the broad South East Asia South Pacific region remains the one which most influences Australia's immediate strategic environment. It is also the region in which Australia can exert influence on strategic issues in ways which are not open to us elsewhere. Within this region, Indonesia and Papua New Guinea are of particular importance because of the inescapable geographical reality that any military threat to Australia-unlikely though that currently is-would almost certainly be posed from or through our north.

The strategic analysis in the statement is set against the background of a rapidly changing global and regional environment. The international order crafted in the aftermath of the Second World War and sustained through the Cold War is drawing to an end. The flow-on effects of this period of transition are, in South East Asia and the South Pacific as elsewhere, far from clear. What is clear is that the equations of power in Europe and the Pacific are changing as the roles and capabilities of the two superpowers change, and the United States and Soviet Union are joined by Japan, the European Community, China and India as major global influences.

All these trends-and others such as economic globalisation-are likely to have implications for regional security. In particular, the point is made that it would not be wise to assume that the United States will continue to maintain its present level of security activity in this part of the world. The United States will want to continue to protect its major strategic interests in maritime passage through the region, and its current interest both in renegotiating the Philippines bases agreement and in developing modest military facilities in Singapore certainly shows that it wishes to maintain a presence in the region for the time being. But with the decline in ideological competition and other global and regional developments, United States attention on the region may well become over time increasingly less geopolitical and more oriented to its major economic interests.

Overall, the statement assesses the security picture in South East Asia as relatively favourable, with most of the countries in the region, for all their various internal problems, more likely than not to continue down the path of nation building based upon participation in the global economic system and a generally pro-Western foreign policy outlook. Indo-China appears to be the main exception, but even here there are signs evident of a more outward-looking economic orientation.

The South Pacific faces rather more problems. A number of the island nations confront economic, environmental, cultural and demographic pressures which will place increasing strain on their political systems. In view of its crucial strategic location for us, the course of Papua New Guinea's development will have particular significance for Australia's security, requiring a sustained and sensitive Australian policy response in the months and years ahead. None of this is to suggest that the South Pacific region as a whole is likely to pose major strategic problems for Australia over the next 10 years or so. But there is certainly the possibility that we will see over this period in some of the island nations a renewal or a continuation of many of the political tensions which have been evident over the last few years.

I should perhaps make the point that while New Zealand is geographically very much part of the South Pacific region, our diverse and close relationship with that country is not dealt with in any detail in the statement. New Zealand has a very special status for us, as an ally and closer economic relations partner, and in terms of the way in which we conduct our bilateral business and consult on wider issues. Thus, in the context of what is essentially an outward-looking statement, the discussion of the South Pacific focuses primarily not on New Zealand but on the other Forum countries.

The statement identifies seven areas around which Australia should build its multidimensional approach to regional security. First, there is the acquisition and maintenance-in line with current defence policy-of a military capability designed to deter, and if necessary defeat, aggression against our territory or maritime jurisdiction. This capability, based on the principles of self-reliance and defence in depth, should be seen as relevant not only to the defence of Australia, but also to the security of the region as a whole. Australia's possession of significant but non-aggressive military power contributes to the strategic stability of our neighbouring regions by providing a `secure south' for South East Asian countries, and a `secure west' for South Pacific nations.

Secondly, Australia should use its military assets and presence in the region to help foster the gradual development of a regional security community based on a sense of shared security interests: this is described in the statement as the exercise of politico-military capability. We should not be embarrassed about using the military capacity we possess, with prudence and sensitivity, to advance both Australia's security and the common security of the region.

The statement also addresses the sensitive and difficult question of the extent to which we should be able, and prepared, to use military force in pursuit of security interests going beyond the defence of Australian territory, noting that this is an issue which arises more in the South Pacific than the South East Asian context. It makes the point that the use of military force may conceivably be appropriate in unusual and extreme circumstances and that any such decision can be made only on a case by case basis, bearing in mind certain cumulative criteria which are canvassed. The statement explicitly rejects any notion of Australia claiming the role of regional arbiter of political legitimacy or moral acceptability.

Thirdly, we should use traditional diplomatic skills of persuasion to manage tensions and frictions, to ensure that small problems stay small, and to achieve accommodations of interests with mutual benefit. Diplomacy should also extend beyond the region itself to dialogue on regional security issues with those external actors capable of exercising influence within the region. The statement, here as elsewhere, carries some important implications for departmental resources, which I will be addressing within the context of our overall needs and priorities in the lead up to next year's Budget.

Fourthly, the statement emphasises the importance of trade and investment in creating more substantial and mutually beneficial links, especially in South East Asia, where economic complementaries offer a great deal of scope for expansion. We must devote a level of effort and resources to our current economic relationship with the region greater than its current relative economic importance might otherwise justify, bearing in mind that, in this region as elsewhere, our success will depend primarily on the success of our efforts to restructure the Australian economy into a strong and internationally competitive entity. We do not pretend that nations which trade together always stay together, but extensive economic linkages create mutual interests which can work to restrain any resort to military conflict. The Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) process, notwithstanding its exclusively economic focus and broader membership, is an excellent example of how new connections can be built up in the region. The Timor Gap Treaty with Indonesia, to be signed next week, is another example of a non-military solution to a problem that historically has often led to conflict-a disputed boundary involving prized resources.

Fifthly, development assistance programs can contribute to our national security interests in the region in a variety of ways: promoting economic and social development; reducing the political disaffection caused by economic deprivation; creating further economic linkages with Australia; and encouraging perceptions of Australia as a sensitive, practical and technologically competent neighbour. Sixthly, Australia can further demonstrate its neighbourly credentials by assisting regional countries with so-called `non-military threats' such as environmental degradation, acquired immune deficiency syndrome, narcotics trafficking and unregulated population flows, including the problem of refugees. Finally, there is scope for a great deal more to be done in the area of exchanges of people and ideas to reduce the cultural distance between Australia and the region and to overcome the significant image problem we still tend to have in South East Asia and the South Pacific. Mutual understanding, like all the other strands in this multidimensional approach, is no guarantee of peace. But mutual ignorance is a greater risk, and so-called `second track' diplomacy-seeking to get our message across through various non-governmental channels-has an important role to play in countering it.

The concluding section of the statement identifies some broad themes which should govern our approach to the formulation, implementation and presentation of all the different policy strands I have just outlined. We should recognise the impact on our wider security interests that a number of apparently non-security-related policies have, and give them greater emphasis, as a result, than they might otherwise get; we should develop policy responses with creativity, alert to opportunities for new agenda setting, and pursue them with discipline and persistence; and we should be sensitive to regional perceptions of us, and behave accordingly. In this last respect, the statement develops the point that we need to be aware of the extent of Australia's perceived `otherness'-our unique character and position as seen by our neighbours. Australia's history, cultural affiliations, values and traditions, ethnic makeup and the like do make us distinctly different from the countries of our immediate region other than New Zealand. Our `otherness' is not a constraint on our freedom of action, but does affect how we should exercise it. Thus, we should be conscious that in some contexts public and formal initiatives will be appropriate, but that in others the emphasis should be on informal and incremental activity. Particularly where there are political sensitivities involved, other governments may prefer discreet and gradual movement. While ambiguity and imprecision may not be viewed positively in the Australian cultural context, in other settings these attributes can usefully clothe initiatives and activities which would provoke opposition if starkly delineated. This point is particularly applicable to South East Asia.

Pulling all these policy responses and themes together, the statement suggests that our long term goal in South East Asia could best be described as `comprehensive engagement' with the countries of the region, while in the South Pacific we should continue with the policy of `constructive commitment', which I announced in September 1988 soon after assuming the foreign affairs and trade portfolio. In South East Asia our approach should be `comprehensive' in that there should be many elements in the relationship, and one of `engagement' because it implies a mutual commitment among equals. Security threats requiring a military response arise when there is a motivation, an intention to do something about it, and the capability to do it. If we develop a substantial and mutually beneficial range of linkages with our regional neighbours, the motivation and intention to threaten us will simply not arise. Moreover, the linkages will do more than save us from threats; they will become networks of connective tissue, binding together us and our neighbours in a strong regional partnership, with a sense of regional commonality of interest.

The essential elements of `comprehensive engagement' can be described as building a more diverse and substantive array of linkages with the countries of South East Asia so that they have an important national interest in the maintenance of a positive relationship with Australia; continuing to support the major existing regional association, the Association of South East Asian Nations, and working with the countries of the region to shape additional regional organisations or arrangements, such as APEC, which can contribute to the social and economic evolution of the region; participating actively in the gradual development of a regional security community based on a sense of shared security interests; working for the involvement of Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos and Myanmar in the cooperative framework of regional affairs; and recognising that Australia, in vigorously pursuing its national interests in the region, should do so as a confident and natural partner in a common neighbourhood of remarkable diversity, rather than as a cultural misfit trapped by geography.

In the South Pacific we are already pursuing a policy of `constructive commitment'. By this we mean essentially that, notwithstanding our greater size and economic capacity, we want to approach the region within a framework of regional partnership, not dominance-not regarding the South Pacific as our sphere of influence but as a region of mutually reinforcing opportunity. The essential elements of `constructive commitment' are described in the statement as the promotion of close, confident and broadly based relations with all Pacific island countries on a basis which recognises their individual differences; fostering effective regional cooperation, through the South Pacific Forum and its agencies, and the South Pacific Commission; recognition that for the island countries security hinges on economic and social development, and offering assistance to help them achieve both; respect for the full sovereignty of the island states in relation to both their internal and external affairs; but, at the same time, promotion of shared perceptions of the region's strategic and security interests, laying the basis for a regional approach to situations, internal or external, which put regional stability at risk.

The overall prospects for our regional security environment are positive, but there are also many uncertainties and, undoubtedly, many surprises in store for us. We cannot assume that in the next 10 years or so states in the region or outside it will not use military power and influence to achieve goals contrary to our security interests. For Australia, the essential fact is that we are dealing with a more fluid and complex region and that in doing so we will be required to be much more the master of our own fate than we have been prepared to accept until recently.

In the 1950s, the 1960s, and during some of the 1970s, Australia tended to perceive the relevance of South East Asia and the South Pacific to our security largely in military terms. We now have the capacity to reinforce our national security by utilising the many dimensions of our external policies in an informed, coordinated and vigorous way to participate in the shaping of the regional environment. It is very much in our interests to be seen as a significant partner to the region, an accepted and natural participant in regional affairs. Effectively implemented and properly explained, the multidimensional approach to regional security advocated in the statement is the best way of maintaining our national security into the next century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

We are pleased that Senator Gareth Evans has finally put down in the Parliament a statement on some issues of foreign policy. Under Senator Gareth Evans, the Parliament has been given little courtesy in terms of enunciation of the Government's foreign policy directions, and that is a matter of regret. Senator Evans could have taken a lesson from his predecessor, who was much more willing to put down positions and have them debated in the Parliament. Having got the statement finally, we regret that it is so shallow. Clearly, it has been produced for propaganda purposes rather than for substantive debate, as is demonstrated by the fact that it is filled with photos of Messrs Hawke, Beazley and Duffy, Senator Evans, who gets eight photos, and Senator Cook-all, of course, doing important things with important people.

The statement is entitled `Australia's Regional Security'. Its thesis is that protection requires more than a sound military and that it can be contributed to by government diplomacy, education, cultural contacts, tourism, visitor programs and the like. In other words, security is multidimensional. What an amazing revelation! I remember the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade of eight years ago entitled Threats to Australia stressing that point. I am sure that those in this chamber who go back further than I do will remember that this stating of the obvious has been said many times before.

There is a rumour that the report was written personally by Senator Evans. We on this side of the chamber hope that is so because, if it is the sum total of months of work by the Departments of Defence and Foreign Affairs and Trade, our problems are more serious than we first realised. It has certainly been tarted up for the media. Our relationship with South East Asia is comprehensive engagement; our relationship with the South Pacific constructive commitment. We suggest that this jargonising is a poor substitute for serious policy contribution.

I would argue that Australian foreign policy terms under this Government have become more irrelevant, particularly as our economic position has declined. There is little recognition in this paper that our principle role in the eyes of Asia remains as a supplier of raw materials to north Asia, particularly Japan, Korea and Taiwan, from which those countries then build wealth. Our economic relevance to South East Asia is low and decreasing. Had that, and how we can together build an economic future to mutual advantage, been the thesis of this paper, I respectfully suggest that it would have been a more worthwhile contribution. We are now reminiscent of so many Third World countries that have little economic clout. We are boasting of our military power as giving us status. What a sad day.

In my view paragraph 72 of the paper reflects a new low in Australian diplomacy. We once boasted of our democratic traditions and our liberal values. For a while we could talk about our considerable economic achievements. Now our national status is linked to our significant military power. That could be another debate in itself. That reminds us of the genesis of this paper, which was a series of press articles in June this year headed `How bomber Beazley blitzed Bill Hayden' or, in other words, how we came to have a defence driven policy in this nation.

The statement delivered today was to be the answer to foreign affairs, demonstrating that our influence is based on much more than defence policy, and that it fails to do. We can no longer look at our own region-the expression used in the paper-in such limited terms. The world has become too integrated. If we are to look at the region which most directly affects us, we must include Japan, Korea, China and Taiwan-four of our largest trading partners. If we accept that argument, we cannot look at protecting Australia's security without, for example, addressing the issue of China's future economic and political stability; the issue of Taiwan; the issue of Hong Kong in the lead up to 1997 and afterwards; the issue of the two Koreas with the suggestion that we heard in this chamber this week of North Korea seeking nuclear weapons; and so on.

I do not think that we can look at Australia's security interests for the future without addressing the complex and changing en- vironment in south Asia. All of these major security issues are either avoided altogether or touched upon in a most superficial way in this document. China gets one paragraph which, in itself, condemns this statement. China has an influence in practically every key issue of the region. One need only think of Cambodia, of relations with Indonesia, India and so forth.

I am also appalled at the down playing of Japan's future significance in this document. I refer to paragraph 19. The West has consistently underestimated the capacity and determination of the Japanese people since the Meiji restoration at the start of this century. It seems that the Australian Government, so far as Senator Evans is concerned, is still doing so. To argue, as this document does, that Japan cannot achieve great power status because it is resource poor is to resort to an argument which was outdated a generation ago. In this information age, real wealth and power does not come from being blessed by nature. In the future the major Japanese plants will not even be located in Japan, but the wealth will be transferred home. This degree of naivety would be amusing were it not so serious.

I guess that we should at least be gracious enough to acknowledge the endorsement of our cautious policy in relation to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). Honourable senators will remember this Government bagging that policy, when we put out our statement, as continuing the cold war. Now we find that it maintains the same reservations itself. There is also an implied acceptance of the limitations of Australia's capacity to influence and, therefore, a recognition that there needs to be a greater concentration of effort. It is about time that this air of reality was recognised by the Government in our foreign policy. Again, I commend the Government for listening to us in this regard. Whilst it is very idealistic to talk about a goal of our foreign policy as the cause of good international citizenship, every other country of the world puts its own interests first. We suggest that it is time to become a little more hard-nosed about what is in Australia's best interests.
Let us have a look at South East Asia, which is the focus of this Government paper. We will start with Cambodia.
Senator Gareth Evans interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade the courtesy of listening to him; I suggest that he do the same. Cambodia, a country suffering the continuing misery of people continuing to be killed each day, hardly rates a mention. That challenge in which regional and wider diplomacy continues to fail is avoided in this statement. Why? No doubt because of the differences between Senator Evans and the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN). A week ago without warning or advice from his Department but under great pressure from within Caucus-I congratulate Senator Schacht-Senator Evans ditched the ASEAN position and adopted a more domestically appealing position, previously advocated by Congressman Solarz with whom Senator Evans seems to have struck up a mutual admiration society.

SPEECH.PARA: The thesis of working with other states in the region, which Senator Evans emphasises in this document, to achieve a common goal is abandoned at a hint of domestic pressure-of course, on the eve of a Federal election. What does that tell our regional friends about the way Australia develops its foreign policy? One day in the United Nations Australia is part of an international consensus as to the best chance of achieving peace in Indo-China; the next day, without negotiation, without consultation, that policy is ditched. So the Khmer Rouge communists, supported by China, and the Hun Sen communists supported by the Soviet Union continue to fight it out and the position of countries such as Thailand, trying so hard to force the four Khmer factions together to some accommodation, is undermined. The change, when it comes down to it, is really in any event cosmetic. Even Senator Evans ought to be gracious enough to admit that there will not be a cease-fire and an interim United Nations administration in Cambodia without the agreement and support of the Khmer Rouge-no matter how much all of us might regret it.

Let me move on to Myanmar, formerly Burma. This does not receive a paragraph, or even a full line, in the statement. Why not? Because to date Australia has got it all wrong and criticisms such as that from Garry Woodard, a former Australian diplomat, have been highly embarrassing to this Government. At the time that Senator Evans was standing up in the Parliament saying that the election program was on track in Myanmar, the Myanmar regime was setting up martial law courts, cutting telephone and other links and arresting Opposition leaders. Through poor intelligence or poor interpretation, the Hawke Government was the first to resume aid after last year's massacre of students and workers. Why? Senator Evans has said that it was `in order to ensure for technical reasons that a major earlier funding program would not be wasted'.

Let us move to Vietnam. Senator Evans sees great hope, great economic opportunity, in Vietnam. He has said that Australia under Labor has made a considerable investment in Vietnam. So why is there so little mention of it in this document? Perhaps it is because Vietnam has not learned the lesson that it is impossible to liberalise economically yet maintain a hardline communist regime. Impoverished Vietnam, in its United Nations speech this year, condemned the reforms that are taking place in eastern Europe. In this conundrum it seems to Senator Evans that the best option is to avoid the difficult issue of Vietnam; so there was no mention of it.

The Philippines also demonstrates the fragility of democracy in this region of the world, where President Aquino is being battered not only by the continuing communist insurgency but also by disloyalty and insurrection within her own defence forces. This statement does not mention the continuing economic pain in the Philippines and the frustrated expectations that are being experienced in that country. Where does this sad picture fit into Australia's security interests in the region? Honourable senators will not find the answer in this statement on Australia's security interests.

As time is against us, I will move briefly from South East Asia to the South Pacific. I commend to any serious student of this subject the recent report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on relations with the South Pacific because it contains a much more useful account of the difficulties facing that region than does this statement. Of course, the South Pacific has been an area of great failure by this Government. We read Senator Evans's comments about constructive commitment, but then ask, `What has changed?'. It is hard to find significant changes. Fiji remains a dilemma. It still does not have a constitution. Elections are not expected for another two years. Colonel Rabuka has still not returned to the barracks. Will the policy of stand-off be maintained for another two years? Honourable senators will not find the answer in this document.

Let us move to the difficulties facing Papua New Guinea (PNG), which are at least recognised in this document. The difficulties are recognised, but there is no policy prescription. Rather, in a comforting way, Senator Evans said:
In the months and years ahead detailed attention will need to be paid to the country's needs and problems.

That is a disappointing contribution set in the background of the recent high profile public dispute between Senator Evans and Mr Beazley-of course, won by Mr Beazley in support of the Jenkins thesis-over the supply of helicopters to PNG. There is a serious debate here. Recently at the Australian National University General Gration quoted an American leader:
If your neighbour's house is on fire, you lend him your hose.
But later, in answering questions, he said:
Australia is not the South Pacific's policeman.

So it seems that this important debate is too complicated or too difficult for a paper such as this. Again, I am pleased to be able to say that the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee is at least taking the function of government in this area and looking at a detailed analysis of relations between Australia and Papua New Guinea and how we might assist that country in the difficult years that lie ahead. As the only politician from this place who has visited Bougainville since the mine ceased operation due to the local insurgency, I for one know the urgency of looking seriously for ways in which we can be of help to PNG.

New Zealand is dismissed in a paragraph in the statement. It was obviously an oversight because it was picked up in the oral contribution by Senator Evans today. It seems that the Australian Government has abandoned hope of New Zealand's again accepting a wider defence responsibility. I guess that is said by Senator Evans as a result of Australian Labor's and New Zealand Labor's fraternal relationships. It is all very negative and very disappointing.

Let me move briefly to what this paper was to be about, that is, justifying the Government's performance in areas other than defence as contributing to Australia's security in the region. On the subject of diplomacy, we are told that our foreign service assets are under severe strain. That reflects Government priorities. What we have witnessed is a mass exodus of experienced officers from the Department, with little effort to stop the haemorrhaging. We have seen serious management problems and a lack of political leadership. The officers are professional and will respond to policy directions if they know what the policies are. A week or two ago Ambassador Butler in Thailand was advocating a step by step partial settlement for Cambodia because he was unsure of the Government's position. Ambassador Flood was recently confused by some of Senator Cook's pronouncements which caused some difficulty. Ambassador Sadlier in China was unsure whether it was in Government policy that he should attend the national day fireworks display. Their confusion is quite understandable.

Human rights are mentioned in this document, but I regret that my observation of this Government is that it is more willing to criticise human rights abuses further afield, such as in Central America. We did not hear the condemnation of abuses in Tibet or in Myanmar that we should expect from the Australian Government.

Let us move to the importance that this document places, not surprisingly, on personal relationships at government level. I suggest that another lesson from the experiences in China should have been that Australia had to develop international relations of greater substances and depth than the personal relationships of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with other national leaders. The Government says that we may need to reinforce our diplomatic assets in the South Pacific. That should have been a lesson from the events in Fiji in 1986. By now the gaps should have been filled. The Government has been in office for some six years.

The economy does get a mention. This part, which should be the key to the multidimensional approach to security, is particularly shallow, as I indicated earlier. There was obviously no business input to this document, which is the same criticism we have heard from business in relation to the recent Asia-Pacific economic cooperation (APEC) conference. Of course, Government knows better. I would like to ask business for a definition of `Greenfields' trade that is referred to or to tell me how they are being helped by the Ministerial Group on Coordination of Bilateral Trade Issues.

The Minister mentions bilateral civil aviation. That surprises me. With the mess that the Government has got itself into over the Taiwan-Australia direct air link, I would have thought that that subject would have been avoided. More than any other part, this section dealing with economic relationships demonstrates a government out of touch. On the subject of development assistance, I simply remind the Government that it cut aid to the South Pacific in the last Budget.

Cultural diplomacy is commended in this document. But our contribution to cultural diplomacy is negligible. It is almost too embarrassing to mention, being $2.2m to the Australian Abroad program out of a foreign affairs vote of about $1.5 billion, compared with the efforts of France, the Soviet Union, Japan and so on. We have never appreciated-certainly this Government does not appreciate-the role that culture can play in extending our influence. The Minister mentions education. I am glad that he at least recognises that we cannot afford a repetition of the recent English language intensive courses for the overseas students debacle in Shanghai. There was no option but to get the Chinese Government offside in the post-Tiananmen environment. But now we have the Chinese people offside as well. We took their applications, which required them first to resign their jobs. We took their money and then we changed the criteria. It has been a sad chapter of Australia's international relations at the people to people level, and it still has not been fully written.

In the time remaining, I want to look at some of the issues that should have been included in a document of this type, which has been styled in the terms given it by the Minister. There are at least three areas of change likely to pose major challenges for the region and for Australia. They are the power relationships in North and South East Asia, economic growth and trade relations and the impact of economic change on political stability and institutions.

Looking briefly at the power relationships, the Asia-Pacific region will continue to have a major potential for interstate conflicts and regional instability. The recent improvement in superpower relationships is not likely to alleviate these problems decisively. The recent distinct improvement in relations between the superpowers-the United States and the USSR-has primarily revolved around and been influenced by developments in Europe. They are not directly or easily transferable into the Asian region. In Europe there has been a pattern of conflict revolving around two major players, the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and the Warsaw Pact, and there had already been major attempts to stabilise their relations well before the Gorbachev era-for example, the Helsinki accords. In Asia, there is a multi-polar power disposition and there has not been any agreed framework for promoting stability in regional power relations.

The USSR and Japan have remained in a stand-off, without a peace treaty and with ongoing disagreements over the northern islands. There are several major Asian powers with significant strength and which exist and operate either largely or completely independently of the superpowers, especially China, North Korea and, in South Asia, India. Several of the regional powers have policies and approaches which are to a degree unpredictable. China has a rising military capability-and these are some of the issues which the Minister should have addressed-but faces serious political and economic problems post-Tiananmen. China has in the past shown a willingness to use force to assert its national interest-for example, against Vietnam in 1979, in the South China Sea in 1974 and 1988 and in Tibet-which is so often overlooked by this Government. India has in recent years shown a tendency towards intervention in South Asia and has rapidly built up its navy. There is also potential for nuclear competition with Pakistan, although their bilateral relations have improved since the change of government in Pakistan.

There is considerable potential for conflict in the Asia-Pacific region in the 1990s. Although the Cold War started in Europe and is now being seemingly decisively eased there, Asia has been left with some of the most intractable legacies of that period. For example, there is still an unresolved conflict between China and Taiwan, and China would be most reluctant to accept any move by Taiwan to assert a long term independence if a Taiwan, post-KMT, government tried to pursue this. The Koreans are still in a state of Cold War hostility and confrontation which I mentioned a moment ago. As I also mentioned a moment ago, Cambodia remains racked by conflict between the four Khmer factions and ultimately between China and Vietnam.

As economic prosperity and growth produces stronger economies and enhanced military potential, the prospect of force being used in regional conflicts may well rise. This growth can fuel not only long term `Cold War' foci for conflict, but also conflicts over access to resources such as those in the South China Sea.

Looking briefly at the challenges that might be ahead in an uncertain economic environment, if an unsuccessful Uruguay round is an ultimate result there is the suggestion of a differing relationship between the newly industrialised economics of North Asia and those not as industrialised in South East Asia-a new level of challenge. There is the effect of the US-Japanese economic relationship and the strains that it is presently going through. I might say that Japan is asserting its position with some vigour. There is the advent of the European Community's single market and the opening up of a number of eastern European states to trade and investment which will add a new foci for economic activity and possibly new sources of competition for markets and investment. The APEC process-which we have supported-if it can be sustained, will obviously continue to be particularly important.

I will now look at how these changes in economic relationships may affect political and institutional stability. The states of the region have major problems in adapting to the political implications of economic growth and change. In some countries there have been clear signs that rapid economic growth and change can outrun capacities to institutionalise demands for political participation and reform. There is now automatic process by which economic growth can be accompanied by a transition to more pluralist and democratic political processes. It has occurred in some countries in the region-and Thailand is a good example-but most countries are facing major problems in coping with the political fruits of economic growth.

Several of the most successful east Asian economies face sensitive periods of trying to pursue more pluralist paths-for example, Taiwan and South Korea. In a number of countries, a particular problem is posed by the growth of labour movements demanding a greater share of the fruits of export-produced economic growth. Peaceful and orderly leadership transition is another major ongoing problem. Several important states have yet to demonstrate a capacity for orderly replacement of leaders with widespread popular participation. The serious coup attempt in the Philippines, that I mentioned a moment ago, which has taken place less than three years after the constitutions in some regional states. One can add to this complexity the situation of the Asia-Pacific communist states where there are major issues of political stability as their economic positions evolve.

As I indicated, most of the communist states of eastern Europe have been prepared to recognise that they cannot achieve economic liberalisation without political liberalisation and political reform. So far, the communist states of Asia have rejected the possibility of major political change that would allow the dominant role of the party to be seriously challenged. China, of course, tried to pursue economic reforms while blocking political change. Vietnam has so far rejected the prospect of major political change. North Korea remains isolated. A key issue for regional stability will be whether the Asian communist regimes can pursue a process of productive economic and political liberalisation that would enable them to participate confidently and capably in the region's economic growth.

So the picture is much more complicated and much more challenging than this Government would have us believe. It is a matter of great regret to those on this side of the chamber that the Government has avoided in its rather simplistic statement today all of these difficult issues and, therefore, has not made a contribution of any great substance to any important debate on Australia's regional security. It reinforces the impression that this Government has failed in this vital area and that should be something of concern to all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats acknowledge the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) on Australia's regional security as a contribution to the debate on Australia's role in our international regional community. In general terms, this Government has shown a greater commitment to improving Australia's relations within the South East Asian and South Pacific region than have previous governments, and it certainly is to be commended for that. This ministerial statement covers a wide range of issues affecting Australia's relations with the nations of the South East Asian and South Pacific region. Those issues range from military, diplomatic, economic and development assistance to issues relating to the so-called-and I think it is an extremely poor title-non-military threats such as the environment, narcotics and health.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my intention to respond to all of the points raised by the Minister in his statement, or to engage in a bulletin-style exercise such as Senator Hill has just done. I want to concentrate my remarks on what I see as the important aspects of the paper and the recommendations arising from it. First, the Democrats accept the Minister's acknowledgment that this statement was not motivated by any concern that Australia's strategic environment was deteriorating. While there have been developments over the last few months in our region that are a cause of concern for any liberal, democratic country-notably, the continuing problems in Bougainville and the recent events in the Philippines-Australia's broad strategic environment is a stable one.

Given that assessment, however, what has occurred in respect of Australia's new militarism is of great concern to the Democrats and, I think, to the international community. The recent AIDEX arms exhibition in Canberra, which was the largest such exhibition every held in the southern hemisphere, and which was supported by the Government, represents an alarming trend towards the promotion of military exports by Australia. I want to put on record how strongly the Democrats are opposed to these types of developments. Indeed, the Labor Government has come under strong criticism for fostering what I think many people see-and certainly we do-as an aggressive military build-up and for allowing its relationships with regional peoples and governments to be driven by the Department of Defence and not by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

In particular, the 1987 Defence White Paper, followed by the regional statement by the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, in February last year, has set the tone for the recent rise in military activity by the Australian defence forces in the South Pacific and South East Asia. The former head of the Foreign Affairs Department, Stuart Harris, wrote in a recent letter to the Independent Monthly that the Defence Department did not consult Foreign Affairs in producing the White Paper. Yet the White Paper heralded the largest defence capital investment in Australia's peace time history. It set the scene for a drive to double Australia's arms exports, mainly to South East Asia, and for a revitalisation of the five-power defence agreement, linking Australia to the defence of Malaysia and Singapore.

Australia's naval defence in the region has grown markedly, as has our military aid to the South Pacific states. A major campaign to convince the New Zealand Government to buy four of the so-called Anzac frigates has been waged against the wishes of 70 to 75 per cent of New Zealanders. Most of all, Australia's military forces have been mobilised to intervene during internal upheavals in the South Pacific states with the stated aim of rescuing Australian tourists. Consequently, Australia's military activities have provoked a great deal of criticism and uncertainty in neighbouring countries. Officials from South Pacific states recently told a Canberra seminar of their fears of military intervention by Australia. Strong criticism has been directed by prominent Papua New Guineans at the donation of the Iroquois helicopters to the Papua New Guinean Government's bloody campaign to reopen the Bougainville copper mine. There is serious dissatisfaction in most levels in New Zealand society about the Australian Government's role in the frigates decision.

It is clear that there is a substantial body of opinion in the Indonesian elite which is wary of Australia's military intentions. One can only guess what the Vietnamese Government thinks about last year's five-power air exercise against the Soviet base at Cam Ranh Bay, an exercise which was commended by a Royal Australian Air Force officer. Clearly the Defence Department and the Defence Minister have had a profound effect on our regional relations. Yet this paper is the first attempt by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to cobble together a synthesis linking military issues with wider security concerns.

Before dealing with the contents of the paper, some comments about process surely are in order. In most areas of government policy, formal public consultation is the norm. Examples abound in the areas of health, education, the environment, industrial development, industrial relations, the law, the economy and so on, but not in the matters of national or regional security or defence. The winds of democracy are not to be felt in these areas. This paper repeats the formula of presenting a document which has received no formal public input and which will be subject to no formal public inquiry. This is an outmoded, outdated and discredited method of policy development. Above all, it is profoundly undemocratic in an area of vital concern. There seems little doubt that this document is more an attempt to hose down mounting criticism than to foster a widely supported and carefully crafted policy based in the community.

As for the contents of the document, the mere fact that non-military dimensions of national and regional security have been acknowledged and addressed is something of a breakthrough. Having said that, the way they have been addressed and the priority they have been accorded leave a lot to be desired. On reading the document, one is struck by the over-emphasis on the importance of Australia's military contribution to national and regional security. It is a scandalous misappropriation of resources. The Kangaroo 89 exercise, a military exercise predicated on a threat which realistically could be posed only be Indonesia, was funded to the tune of $230m, while the Australia-Indonesia Institute, which could very well help to create a climate where such conflict could be easily avoided, receives $700,000-$700,000 for the peaceful linking of our countries compared with $230m for the continuation of outmoded military exercises. This imbalance surely is reflected in this paper, which puts our military capacity at the top of the list of Australia's policy responses to our regional security environment, while human rights, development assistance and the responses aimed at so-called other non-military threats are relegated to the bottom.

Much more emphasis in this document should have been given to people's diplomacy, yet the people's diplomacy that is talked about is through naval ships visiting the South Pacific rather than more effective and peaceful alternatives. What sort of neighbour are we when we regard machines of war as important symbols of friendship? Of course, nothing is said about conventional arms control.

The document acknowledges that the prospect of a reduced United States military presence in the region would leave a vacuum which states like India, China and Japan might seek to fill. Yet no criticism is offered of the rise in those nations' military capacities, particularly those of India and Japan. No concrete proposal is made to fill the vacuum with non-military security arrangements of the kind that are being developed in Europe. It is assumed that the United States has a natural right to obtain military facilities in Singapore, for example. The dilemma for the Government is that Australia's own military build-up is in conflict with any attempt to curb regional arms build-ups. Our support for United States global military deployments makes it difficult, if not impossible, to criticise other large powers who are developing similar types of ambitions.

A much more aggressive approach to regional arms limitation is needed, backed up by restraint on Australia's part. This document dismally fails to meet that need. It does not challenge the notion that Australia has a natural right to send its military forces into South Pacific states to rescue tourists or to prop up governments. The use of the military for this purpose is confined to small states with limited defence capacities. When Australia's tourists were threatened during the Beijing massacre, the Government sent in Qantas to rescue them, not the Army or the Navy. Civilian means should be used for tourist rescue, not military means, which carry a clear implication of intervention. After all, a document drawn up by officers in the Fiji military forces and recently leaked to the media indicated that they would have treated the landing of Australian troops as intervention.

The Minister's statement identifies seven areas around which Australia should build its multidimensional approach to regional security. I wish to look now at area No. 5, regional development assistance programs. The Minister in his tabling statement, as distinct from the document itself, said that development assistance programs can:

. . . contribute to our national security interests in the region in a variety of ways: promoting economic and social development; reducing the political disaffection caused by economic deprivation; creating further economic linkages with Australia; and encouraging perceptions of Australia as a sensitive, practical and technological competent neighbour.
The Democrats certainly welcome this recognition that foreign aid, as it is more colloquially known, is one of the major elements of Australia's broad foreign policy agenda.

For a more concrete example of the importance of foreign aid in the overall context of our national policy, I will refer to figures in the 1989-90 Budget. An examination of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade budget reveals that by far the largest amount is directed towards international aid. Of the total 1989-90 Foreign Affairs and Trade budget of $1,563m, some $1,125m, or 72 per cent, is devoted to the foreign aid component. The vast majority of this total foreign aid is administered by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB), which reports directly to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. For a country of Australia's size and status, the judicious distribution of the aid budget provides the best means of achieving many of Australia's major foreign aid policy goals-such as the achievement and advancement of Australia's national interests and the promotion of peace and stability in our region. They are not promoted by touring warships.

Since the Australian Labor Party (ALP) took office in 1983, official development assistance has slipped alarmingly. The ratio of Australia's overseas development assistance to our gross national product has fallen from 0.51 per cent in 1983, under a conservative government, to 0.33 per cent in the 1989-90 Budget. This is historically Australia's lowest aid contribution for many decades. As a donor nation, Australia is roughly in the middle of organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development nations. However, we are well below the United Nations recommended figure of 0.7 per cent of GNP. The Government is also providing less than the level preferred by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade-0.4 per cent of GNP for official development assistance (ODA). The Australian Council for Overseas Aid Organisations (ACFOA), Australia's peak body involved in non-government aid organisations, in its submission to the Government's Expenditure Review Committee earlier this year, recommended a rise to 0.4 per cent of GNP. ACFOA issued a strong statement after its annual conference in August saying that:
the continued reduction in overseas aid makes Australia appear selfish and unconcerned about the immense poverty and suffering in the region.

The Government has made it clear that within difficult economic circumstances, the aid budget has had to suffer. It has fallen victim to the hard heads and economic rationalists that rule the roost in the ALP Caucus and Cabinet. The aid budget is a soft target and has suffered disproportionately against other government outlays. As a senior AIDAB official mildly put it, over the past decade, Australian overseas aid expenditures have been `subject to very tight constraints'-so tight in fact that:
while total government expenditures have risen by over 70 per cent since 1972 in real terms, overseas aid expenditures (again in real terms) have not risen at all.

Against this background, the Democrats believe that the Opposition would certainly do better than the Government. That is, they would reduce the aid budget further. It is the only area where they would probably do better. As part of the Liberal-National Party economic policy launch in the latter part of this year, the conservatives announced they would slash the total aid budget by another $100m. A recent departmental review found that the effect of the Opposition's proposals would be a cut of $200m in the aid budget. Not surprisingly, Senator Hill, who had the audacity to talk about aid, has been reluctant to say where the money is going to come from. He is probably thinking that if he gets into the job he is not going to have much difficulty with the electorate, but he will have enormous difficulty explaining to recipients who will have to lose out.

The massive cuts in the Labor Party Budget and those foreshadowed by the conservative Opposition go firmly against the advice of experts within and outside government with regard to the type of support that our foreign policy needs in this area. The all-party Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which Senator Hill quoted from on a number of times in his speech, in its very thorough report on a review of AIDAB and Australia's overseas aid programs recommended:
by 1992 Australian aid should once again stand at 0.5 per cent of GNP.

That was one of the items not quoted by Senator Hill. The Committee commented that Australia's adherence to the 0.7 per cent ODA-GNP target was in danger of becoming `purely rhetorical'. As part of the high profile One World Campaign, ACFOA has called on the Government to restore Australian aid to proper standards. I put on the record again the Australian Democrats' policy which calls for an immediate rise in the aid budget to 0.1 per cent of GNP.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—It is 0.1 per cent of GNP immediately. While that is a large figure compared to that currently being given by the Government, it is well to bear in mind that small northern European countries have been able to provide this level of expenditure for many years. Australian can and should do likewise.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as increasing the aid budget, there is a strong case for improving the quality of the aid which the Minister's statement refers to. In fact there are economic, humanitarian, environmental and political reasons for providing more development assistance, and improving the quality of that assistance to South-East Asia and the South Pacific. The influential report of the World Commission of Environment and Development, Our Common Future, highlighted the complexity of world poverty issues. It argues that the issues of human and economic development, environmental quality and natural resource husbandry are highly interdependent. The matter of public importance that we debated this afternoon was directed to that proposition. Sound development requires a sound environmental and strong natural resource base; an unhealthy environment and resource depletion ensures poor development. The Commission found that:
aid from donor nations has not only been inadequate in scale but too often has reflected the priorities of the nations giving the aid, rather than the needs of the recipients.

The Commission offers a blunt message to aid donor nations and multilateral aid organisations both in terms of the quantity and quality of this aid. Unfortunately, the Government has not registered that warning. For example, it is stated on page 32 of the ministerial statement:
we need to be attuned to the possibility of adjustments in the balance and content of our own (aid) programs in order to better serve our interests.

Surely it is time to recognise, first and foremost, what development aid is about. There has been some recognition of this complex relationship between aid development, poverty, the environment and Third World debt. There needs to be far greater focus on it in terms of the future. Not surprisingly, some sceptics have argued that the Government's recent interest in environmental concerns in the domestic and international arena have been as a result of a reaction to popular opinion. A recent survey found that 80 per cent of voters said the economy was a very important issue in determining how they would vote. Seventy-one per cent of them also said that the environment was a very important issue.

Foreign aid is particularly relevant in our own Asia-Pacific basin region. Australia is a very large power in the region and a wealthy neighbour to some of the poorest people in the world. While the benefits to Australia's foreign relations and strategic interests of providing aid are not readily quantifiable, development assistance supports the broader diplomatic strategies. For example, the continuing focus on the developing nations of our region is an expression of Australia's more general commitment, in foreign policy terms, to its developing neighbours. Australia is a very large supporter of Papua New Guinea and the Pacific nations. Some 33 per cent of our total overseas aid budget goes to Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific region, as it should.

Australia's official aid organisation, AIDAB, cites the capacity of aid to underscore Australia's stance on a number of foreign policy issues. A specific example is increased development assistance to the nations of southern Africa-the so-called front-line states to South Africa. AIDAB also identifies the special role which aid can play through international organisations. It states:
Australia's reputation as a compassionate nation, and our international bona fides were enhanced by increased allocations to for example UN relief in Palestine and other emergency relief in Africa.

Australia's own region poses many challenges for development assistance. There can be a high degree of complementarity in foreign affairs and humanitarian motivations. For this reason the regional focus of Australian aid should and must be maintained.

I wish to comment on one specific item, Australia's aid to Cambodia and Vietnam in the light of the Government's policy of comprehensive engagement in the South East Asia region. In light of recent developments in that region, the Democrats believe that the Government should now be looking at resuming official development assistance to Cambodia and Vietnam. We are very concerned about recent developments in Cambodia, particularly the internal fighting which has flared up since the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops in September. While we support any Australian move to assist in bringing a lasting and just peace to Cambodia, we had reservations about the Government's policy with regard to the involvement of the four major factions, particularly with regard to the inclusion of the Khmer Rouge in any transitional regime in Cambodia.

The Democrats are also opposed to the current representation of Cambodia in the United Nations by a member of the Khmer Rouge faction, which does not legitimately represent the aspirations of the Cambodian people. However, on 24 November the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade announced the Government's altered policy stance. It holds out a very real and concrete proposal for the establishment of a United Nations transitional administration in Cambodia. We believe that this is an excellent proposal that ought to have the support of all Australians. We see that it has merit not only in terms of the United Nations, but also because it removes any necessity for a role for the Khmer Rouge. Cambodia is one of the poorest countries in the world and clearly warrants the resumption of Australia's bilateral humanitarian and developmental assistance.

The public supports this exercise. A recent Australian National University survey found that three out of four Australians either approve or strongly approve of Australia providing foreign aid. Against this, only 11 per cent disapprove or strongly disapprove. While 45 per cent of respondents rated the nuclear arms race as the most serious issue facing the world, 41 per cent rated hunger as the most serious issue. Adding together those who thought an issue most serious and those who rated it in the second category of priority, that is, very serious, hunger scored highest at 78 per cent, followed by the nuclear arms race with a score of 71 per cent and disease with a score of 70 per cent. Poverty and lack of economic development rated 68 per cent. Unfortunately, politicians too often ignore the fact that the Australian population is aware of and knowledgeable about the importance of our support to other peoples in the world. I hope that Australia's humanitarian assistance, which has been so much a feature of our efforts in the past, can be brought back into focus and again be seen as a major element in our relationships with other countries.

Today we are talking about foreign affairs, about our relationships with other countries in the world. When one realises that 20 per cent of the world's population is living in dire poverty and when a report on the state of the world's children is about to be launched in Parliament House, one must be aware that the increase in poverty and disease among the poorer sections of the community, amongst children, breeds unrest and tension. Recently, a liberation has taken place within the Warsaw Pact countries. The freedom of people in those countries to determine their own affairs is very important for Australia and the world. However, there is a tendency to ignore the fact that while that change takes place, other people are bound in chains which are far more tight and vicious than those of the regimes that operated in eastern Europe. I refer to the chains of dire poverty and imminent death.

The fact that the Government has been able to reduce its donations and its development assistance and the parties purporting to be an alternative government are talking about reducing assistance by another $100m does not spread any lustre on Australia; indeed, in the eyes of most it would be seen to be our weak link. If we link that with the increased expenditure on military operations, we see that our foreign affairs are in difficulty. They need more than a statement to resurrect them; they need a change of policy, a change of emphasis, and ultimately they probably need a change of heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the ministerial statement relating to regional security. First, I support the thrust of the document. Senator Gareth Evans has tabled in the Parliament an important document that adds further explanation to the Australian Government's foreign policy and defence policies. Above all else, the document brings together the thrust of both areas of policy in a way which is comprehensible. Some people will criticise the statement for placing too much emphasis on defence; others will criticise it for placing too much emphasis on the diplomatic. I believe it achieves a reasonable balance.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people will criticise, in particular, the defence expenditure of the Government. When Bill Hayden was the Minister for Foreign Affairs, at a national conference of the Labor Party he told people who were critical of our defence expenditure that the very same people were supportive of Australia having an independent foreign policy. He said, `You cannot have an independent foreign policy with a pacifist defence policy'. I think that is a truism in this document. There is reasonable defence expenditure. We spend about 2.3 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) on defence. It is by no means excessive by any comparison with what countries in our region and elsewhere in the Western world spend. The Australian public believes such a level of defence spending is necessary for the security of the country and our neighbours overwhelmingly accept that level as reasonable. Nobody is running around our region or the world saying that Australia is a militaristic country because it spends 2.3 per cent of GDP on defence. Some countries are spending a lot less; that is their decision. Many countries who are our allies spend a lot more and sometimes make criticisms that they spend more, so other countries spend less. I believe we have the balance about right in Australia between what we spend on defence and what we spend on foreign affairs. I admit a prejudice-if one could call it that-in that I would like to see Australia spend a lot more on foreign aid. However, I note that the Australian Democrats said that their position is to spend one per cent of gross domestic product. That would mean that, instead of spending $1,100m a year, we would be spending about $3.3 billion a year. I would like to hear from the Democrats the sort of timescale in which they want to see that sort of expenditure increase implemented. There is no way that the Australian Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB), our overseas aid agency, could at present soak up or digest that amount of money without there being extraordinary waste. Unless these targets, though commendable in the theoretical, are put down on paper and it is explained that they are to be implemented over a long period of time, we will end up having a more disastrous overseas aid policy even though we are supposedly spending more.

If one wants to see an example, have a look at what the Japanese have done in the Pacific region and South East Asia. They have suddenly increased massively the overseas aid development. Those of us who toured the South Pacific last year as part of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee saw a number of examples of where Japan has poured money into these small countries which has basically been wasted. I suppose the most famous of all is the Tonga Cultural Centre-a $6m building that the Tongans cannot afford to run because the air-conditioning and electricity expenses are too big a drain on their budget. Though I, like many people in the community, want to see more aid spent, I do not want to take the Democrats' position that it is just one per cent and away we go.

I want to return to the remarks made by the shadow Minister for foreign affairs, Senator Hill. In my view, his remarks were a potpourri of picking here and there, but contained no comprehensive statement of what the foreign policy would be of the coalition in government. It went all over the place of individual criticism. It is very easy in foreign affairs to make individual criticisms about what is happening in various parts of the world. For a coalition that ruled in Australia for 30 of the the last 40 years and had a foreign policy of utter obsequiousness to the United States, one would have to say that it is very hard for our side of politics to take seriously its criticism that Australian foreign policy at the moment is not being effective.

I want to turn to three specific areas that Senator Hill mentioned where I think he was just wrong. They are Cambodia, Myanmar and the South Pacific. First of all, Cambodia: I, like many people in the community, have an interest in Cambodia. I had the good fortune to visit Cambodia last year and have followed the affairs of that country with considerable interest. I do not claim to be an expert on Cambodia. I think anybody outside of Cambodia who claims to be an expert is deluding himself. Trying to get a resolution of the Cambodian situation really is a most complex political problem.

Senator Evans announced, only 10 days ago, that Australian would support a comprehensive settlement whereby the United Nations would take over the running of the country in a similar way to the Namibia peace process. United Nations public servants, possibly 200 or 300, would be put into Cambodia to oversee the administration of the country pending free and fair elections. That would mean that none of the four factions, including the Hun Sen Government, would have absolute control in the running of the affairs of that country. The big advantage of it for most of us is that it would exclude the Khmer Rouge from having a role in an interim government. I do not think any reasonable person in Australia would agree to that.

In saying that, I have to point out to Senator Hill that in the last few months the Opposition has had a number of positions on Cambodia that are quite confusing. First of all, Mr Spender, when he was shadow Minister earlier that year, said that there should be no role for the Khmer Rouge at all in Cambodia in a peace settlement. Then only about 3 1/2 to four weeks ago, I think it was, there was a statement from Mr Peacock which said that the coalition supported a comprehensive settlement and an interim government in which all the factions would be represented, and that included the Khmer Rouge. That was the position 3 1/2 weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your position of a week ago.

—I must admit, Senator Hill, that that was our position two weeks ago. The coalition had that position 3 1/2 weeks ago, which was contradictory to Mr Spender's position of earlier this year. Then finally, only last week, I think because of embarrassment that the Liberal Party is seen as taking a policy of supporting the Khmer Rouge being in the interim government, we have Mr Peacock supporting an international tribunal on war crimes to have the Pol Pot clique from the Khmer Rouge tried. This is something that Bill Hayden supported, I think, three to four years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it interesting that when Bill Hayden, in the mid-1980s, was attempting to find a settlement to the Cambodian impasse he was roundly criticised and abused by the Opposition for deluding himself. One of the things he said at the time was that there should be an international tribunal on the war crimes of Pol Pot and his clique. Now, four years later, Andrew Peacock suddenly announces that that is the Liberal Party's position. The Opposition has no comprehensive or credible policy on Cambodia. It does not understand the situation in Cambodia. It makes no attempt to understand it and it jumps all around the place. I would hope that the initiative taken by Senator Evans, and this Government, in the last 10 days leads to success. I must say, in view of Senator Hill's interjections that, since Senator Evans made his announcement there has been no public criticism, no major criticism of any of the major players on the Cambodian issue. China has made no public statement criticising the proposal. The initiative has been well received in a number of quarters. It may not work. Anybody who can predict what is going to work in Cambodia is, as I say, deluding himself. It is quite clear that what Senator Evans has put down on behalf of the Australian Government has been well received both in a number of countries in the Association of South East Asian Nations and with the other major powers--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one?
—Name one.

—Name the countries that have put out a statement criticising it. Has Chatichai criticised it? Of course not.
