Because Chatichai-the Prime Minister of Thailand-realises that what Senator Evans has announced is an additional point of strength to what he has been trying, which is the incremental step for a negotiated settlement of Cambodia. I believe Senator Hill's criticism of this area of the statement, and of Senator Evans, just does not hold water.

SPEECH.PARA: Myanmar is the next area that Senator Hill criticised. It is an area that I do feel I have some knowledge of, but I do not claim to be an expert. Senator Hill said Australia was the first to restart aid to Myanmar. That is just not correct. The first country was Japan. The only aid program we started, or restarted, in Myanmar was the famous, or infamous-whichever way one likes to put it-Mandalay dairy project. Guess who put the Mandalay dairy project into Myanmar? It was the coalition, when in government. When it cut off aid to Vietnam it was left with a dairy factory that could not go to Vietnam, so it plonked it into Burma. It is one of the aid programs that any aid agency, or any aid expert, would say would never be done again because it was starting off from scratch without the infrastructure.

I fully supported Senator Evans restarting that program earlier this year, because when I was in Burma in February I saw the factory. I saw the equipment which Australian taxpayers have paid for sitting in the yard rusting, being inappropriately put together and going to be destroyed through misuse. If we had stopped there, with no technical experts, we would have wasted $3m or $4m of taxpayers' money. Guess who would have been the first ones in the Estimates committee to complain about the loss of taxpayers' money. Members of the Liberal Party would have said, `You've wasted all of this money'. All we did was restart the program so that the material and equipment already there could be put to use without loss to the Australian taxpayer. No aid program has been restarted in Myanmar other than that one.

Members of the Burmese community to whom I have spoken, in this country, in Thailand and in Burma, did not see the restarting of the Mandalay dairy project as being a breakout from the isolation imposed by other Western countries. One person, Aung San Suu Kyi, who is now under detention, put criticisms to me, and I said I thought that Australian taxpayers would not put up with having several million dollars of their funds wasted on equipment lying in a paddock outside the half-assembled factory, going to rust. I must admit that she did not say that I had convinced her, but she did take the point that it would be a problem for Australian taxpayers and probably for the Australian Auditor-General.

The final area I want to mention is the South Pacific. Senator Evans has quite appropriately divided the report into two sections dealing with our policy towards South East Asia: `comprehensive engagement'-and I have dealt with a couple of related areas-and `constructive commitment' in the South Pacific.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must be embarrassed by that.

—Senator Hill may wish to denigrate the use of that language, but I think it is a reasonable description. In diplomacy, language is what it is all about. I think these are reasonable descriptions. In our constructive commitment to the South Pacific, in one area alone I think we can claim considerable credit, and that is the dialogue that has developed with the Rocard Government about the settlement of New Caledonia. While the Chirac Government was in power we had an absolute disaster on our hands, which all sides agreed--
—You played no part in that settlement. It was the change of government in France.

—The Chirac Government had a terrible policy for New Caledonia. I know that Senator Hill has publicly disagreed with the Chirac Government's policy. The Rocard Government took the initiative in regard to the Matignon Accord--
—Australia did not play a role in that.

—Australia was not involved in the negotiations, but I think Australia's position was overwhelmingly vindicated because a constructive policy was put forward by the French Government which we can fully support and which substantially reduced tension in the communities, despite the tragic assassination of Jean-Marie Tjibaou earlier this year. In the end the Rocard Government adopted a policy that shows a constructive way out of the morass of New Caledonia and its colonialist history. That was in line with what this Government has been arguing for several years. I know that Senator Hill has held a similar view, but most members of his Party have not held a similar view about how to handle the situation in New Caledonia. This constructive commitment has worked and we have now made arrangements with the French Government to start an aid program in New Caledonia. French officials from New Caledonia have visited this country, as have Kanaks, to start a dialogue with what I hope by 1998 will be a new independent country in the region and one of our closest neighbours. That is just one area in which we have had a constructive commitment to the South Pacific, which has worked.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to our aid program in the South Pacific there are areas which can be criticised regarding money being misspent. Since AIDAB has been rebuilt and reformed, since the report of the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program, in 1984-85, the delivery of appropriate aid to those countries has been significantly improved. The aid is now more in tune with what those countries need. Although we would all like to see more aid being given, the aid being given to these countries is being digested into those countries' own systems. I believe that in this area alone the present Federal Government can take some credit for the reforms of AIDAB. I congratulate AIDAB and its officers on its country program in the South Pacific.

I know that many other senators want to speak in this debate. I believe that the document tabled by Senator Evans is a very constructive one and provides a further stone or plank in the overall development under this Government of an independent foreign policy and a self-reliant defence policy in our region that have substance and political will, and which will work, unlike the rambling and episodic comments made by the shadow Minister when he replied to the statement earlier today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a very peculiar statement entitled Australia's Regional Security. One cannot really work out why it has been made. The best thing one can say about it is that it is better than the long, rather rambling foreign policy statements that Senator Gareth Evans has made in recent months in answer to dorothy dixers in Question Time, because they cannot be debated. At least this statement can be debated. One must ask why it was made and why by Senator Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Essentially, it is about defence. One suspects that the reason that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has made this statement is that it is a counterclaim to the allegations that the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, has been making foreign policy, particularly in the South Pacific area. I suppose that the Senate has to put up with claims and counterclaims by two rival Ministers in the Hawke Cabinet, but it seems a peculiar basis on which a statement on defence policy should be made in this chamber. Surely it should have been made by the Minister representing the Minister for Defence.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, it is essentially a very peculiar document. It seems to be a collection of former press releases cobbled together to make a supposedly new statement. It also seems to be, as I said, a propaganda campaign by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade against the Minister for Defence in what is essentially a defence area. For instance, in the document there are eight photographs of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and two of the Minister for Defence-a ratio of 4 : 1 in favour of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It seems a rather petty basis on which to make what is supposed to be a serious statement about Australia's regional defence problems.

The statement is disappointing. I think the way in which to sum it up would be to refer to what is alleged to have been said about someone's essay on one occasion. The supervisor said to the student, `In your paper there is much that is good and much that is new'. As the student was preening himself, the supervisor said, `What is new is not good and what is good is not new'. I am afraid that is the way in which I would sum up this document, except to say that there is very little new in it. It is only a cobbling together of old press releases to make this very disappointing statement.

We are living in an extremely turbulent era. No-one knows what the outcome will be. I was recently a delegate-until I was recalled rather peremptorily to preside over the Senate in a debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill-at a meeting of the North Atlantic Assembly. There were two guest speakers before this body. The two guest speakers were the American Commander-in-Chief of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, General Galvin, and the Russian Chief of Staff of the Warsaw Pact, General Lobov. They spoke jointly and severally to that meeting and answered questions asked of the delegates. That would have been inconceivable until two years ago. Extraordinary changes are taking place. That does not mean to say that we can predict what is going on. I attended that meeting in October, just a few weeks ago, and no-one there would have predicted the events that have occurred in East Germany. Everybody thought that East Germany would be the last hold-out of the rigid communist doctrine. I think they underestimated the effect of television beamed from West Germany into East Germany on the East German population. Nevertheless, they knew about it; they did not assess it correctly. On an issue with which they were familiar, they did not get it right. It is so difficult to predict events, and that is what one must always remember: things change, both for the better and for the worse, with astonishing rapidity. If we look at Australia, say, in the depths of the Depression in 1931, who would have assessed then that in 10 years Australia would be at war with Germany, Italy and Japan? I suggest that if anyone had said that in 1931 they would have been regarded as insane. It is so difficult to predict in this turbulent world-and we are living in a particularly turbulent era-but the signs appear to be very favourable, much better than they have for many years. Nevertheless, we must remember the very great difficulty of long term projections.
Senator Hill interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, of course the turbulence of this type has not yet hit Asia. North Korea, which might be regarded as the East Germany of Asia, is still locked into a rigid dictatorial communist regime. China seems to have taken the path away from liberalisation. As I discussed earlier, the problems of the ex-French colonies of Indo-China are certainly very far from solved. The point I am trying to make is that in defence preparations, which are inevitably long term, both in personnel and equipment, one must be aware that rapid changes, both for better and worse, are possible. One must not assume long term predictions when such predictions are inherently fallible. I would like to point out that in this document which, as I have said, appears to be a cobbled together collection of press handouts, there are some very curious omissions. For instance, much of what it says about India I would agree with. The paper says:

SPEECH.PARA: Its already significant military capabilities, which make it the predominant power in South Asia, will be followed by increasing strategic reach, including into South East Asia. It sees itself as a great power and a major actor on the global scene.
I would agree with that. It goes on to say:
. . . its power projection capabilities are growing.
It finishes by saying:
The increases in India's military capabilities appear to be motivated by preoccupations in its immediate region and considerations of prestige, rather than by a desire to intervene out-of-area.

I think that is true, although, one of the dangers of having a capability is that people may use it unexpectedly. Perhaps, the Argentine invasion of the Falkland Islands is an example of that. Argentina had the capability and unexpectedly used it, taking people by surprise. What is so curious, and I am dealing with omissions in this paper, is that the Government and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, or both, do not seem to be aware that there has been a change of government in India. The direction that has been going on with the expansion of the Indian Navy may not be continued by the new Government. I do not know and I am certain that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade does not know. It seems extraordinary that in a statement of this nature it does not point out that the Congress Party, which has been in power almost continuously since independence, has been defeated. There has been a change of government in India and that may well mean a change of direction. It is not mentioned in this paper which is supposed to deal with our regional security.

Another curious omission is that Mr Gorbachev, just a few months ago, made a series of disarmament proposals, one of which was that there should be a zone of peace in the Indian Ocean. That is now on the table. There are many arguments as to whether it would or would not be in the interests of the littoral states of the Indian Ocean, including Australia. There is no mention of that in this document, which is meant to be discussing Australia's regional security. The proposal has to come to a head, I would think, in the next few months.

New Zealand has always been a close ally of Australia. We are involved very much together. It is dealt with in six lines on page 11. There is no mention in this paper of the South Pacific nuclear free zone or what its advantages are. I, of course, am an opponent of it, but one at least would think that it would be mentioned in a paper purporting to discuss Australia's regional security.

ANZUS, I would have thought a central core of our defence policy, receives seven lines on page 15. ANZUS is a vital treaty for us. People misunderstand it by thinking that it is a guarantee of American support which it most certainly is not. America, if we are ever threatened, will come to our aid if it thinks it is in its strategic interests to do so which, if we think about it, would be absurd on any other basis. The advantage of the ANZUS Treaty to us is not that. It is that it allows our forces to be compatible, interoperable with the American forces so that if they came to our aid they would be effective. When America came to our aid in 1942 there was no common communication system, no common tactical system, no common ammunition or logistics. It took a very long time-over a year-before we could really operate together. At least ANZUS assures that if the United States comes to our assistance, it will be immediately effective. Of course, ANZUS, with the exchange of intelligence, which is of enormous importance to a country like Australia with small forces and vast distances, is of inestimable value, enabling us to link into the American logistics network. This saves us billions of dollars. It has been assessed-I think accurately-that if we did not have the ANZUS Treaty to provide our present modest defence capability we would have to double the defence vote. It receives seven lines on page 15 in this paper which talks about Australia's regional security.

Indonesia is dismissed in the most cursory way. I do not want to get into the subject of where particular threats to Australia might come from. Senator Macklin, I think rather unfortunately, raised this issue. I do not see any threat from Indonesia, certainly in current times. Nevertheless, looking at the long term security of Australia, our territorial integrity cannot be threatened while the Indonesian archipelago is firmly held in friendly hands. It must be an overriding purpose of our defence and foreign policy to ensure that the Indonesian archipelago is held in friendly hands. That, surely, is central to our long term strategic security. It is not discussed at all in this paper about Australia's regional security.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is. Haven't you read it?
—Of course I have read it. It is not discussed in any sensible way. I would like to turn to the section on Australia's military power. I agree with what it says. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's national defence policy is genuinely defensive: we harbour no aggressive intentions towards any other nation. Our military capability, while substantial in regional terms, is not based on the need for comprehensive power projection within our region, but rather on what is required to defeat aggression against our territory or maritime jurisdiction.
The foundation of Australia's defence planning is self reliance . . .

In the remainder of time available to me I would like to concentrate on this aspect of defence because I agree with what is said there. I agree with many things this Government has done about defence. I agree with the emphasis on self-reliance. I have been arguing for it, both inside the Defence Force and in this Parliament now for 30 years. The days in which we were regarded as mere contributors to an alliance were, in my view, disastrous for coherent defence planning. The problem was that we, as minor contributors to allied forces, had no real guidance to structure our own Defence Force. In many key areas we assumed that these capabilities would be performed by someone else.

I will give one example. In 1975, when we were still responsible for the defence of the internal security of Papua New Guinea, there was, as there is now, an attempted secession movement in Bougainville. The Chiefs of Staff in 1975 were then asked, if necessary, whether it would be possible for us to put a battalion, for security purposes, into Bougainville. The Chiefs of Staff said, `Well, yes, but you understand that we have no amphibious assault capabilities'. We assumed that would be provided by the Americans. `We have no airborne assault capability'. We assumed that would be provided by the Americans. `We could only get a battalion into Bougainville if the airfield were firmly held in friendly hands'. That was an example of the very great difficulty we had if we wanted to pursue a national objective and if we were a member of an alliance and we were only partly self-supporting. Therefore, I agree very strongly with the concept, as I have always expressed it, that we must structure our Defence Force around the things we might have to do on our own. It should be so designed, organised and equipped so that it can operate with allied forces if something beyond our own capability to deal with, on our own, arises. That is, in my view, the importance of the ANZUS alliance. That aspect of interoperability has been, to some extent, neglected. The neglect is reflected in this paper. ANZUS is mentioned on seven lines and New Zealand on six lines in a long report.

I also agree with many of the equipment decisions that have been made, though I have some doubts about the selection of the Swedish submarine which was a very expensive program. I do not think that was costed correctly. There may well be very serious cost overruns with that project. The danger of that is that, in a limited defence vote, cost overruns and capital equipment have to come out of other capital equipment we need or, as has happened under this Government, out of the pay and conditions of servicemen.

We have serious equipment shortfalls at the moment. We have no airborne early warning capability. Our in-flight refuelling capability is derisory. We have what is charmingly described in the paper as only limited amphibious troop lift capacity. I would modify that to say that we have no useful amphibious lift capability. That weakness is a very serious one in our area. We have serious equipment defects, and cost overruns in existing projects would eat into our ability to deal with these in the near future. But I agree with the equipment decisions that have been made.

I also agree in part with the reorganisation that is going on in the Department of Defence. It has been a very unsatisfactory department in the past. As organised under the so-called Tange reforms, it was made into a confrontationist establishment-servicemen against public servants. It was a very unsatisfactory environment from which to get sensible decisions. It is gradually changing. I am very pleased to see that the planning for each element of the Defence Force-the Navy, the Army and the Air Force-is being taken over and coordinated centrally under the Chief of the Defence Force. That was vital. As was going on before, there was a confrontation atmosphere within the three Services-not looking at what was needed for an effective Australian Defence Force but at what was best for their own separate service. That, I hope, will be ended.

There has been some timid move towards reducing the gross overbearing of senior officers, but regrettably the fundamental cause of this has not been tackled. What has built up in recent years is an extraordinary overbearing of senior officers. I have the figures here for the end of last year. In the Navy there were 13 admirals and 30 commodores; in the Army, 16 generals and 49 brigadiers; and, in the Air Force, 14 air marshals and 34 air commodores. That is absurd in relation to the scale of our forces. The reason this happened is that, when the Defence Department was integrated, public servants were given quasi-military rank. It was said that a lowly assistant secretary was the equivalent of a one-star officer-a brigadier; a first assistant secretary was the equivalent of a major-general; a deputy secretary was the equivalent of a lieutenant-general; and so on.

The problem was that, having done that and then requiring comparable ranks in all the multitude of committees that the Defence Department had, there was an explosion of these ranks. The Navy, for instance, fought the Second World War with 40,000 men, including three admirals and four commodores. It now has 15,000 men, 13 admirals and 30 commodores. One might think that that does not matter much but if there are only a limited number of operational jobs, there are a very large number of senior officers with no recent operational experience and no expectation of getting any. That makes for a very inefficient defence force.

There has been a move now to reduce the number of senior officers by 20 per cent and make a comparable reduction in the number of senior public servants. That is good. But the cause of the problem-that is, the improper linkage between service rank and public servants-has not been removed. While that remains there will always be a gross overbearing of senior military officers who will be unable to achieve and receive adequate operational experience. As I have said, that makes for a very poor defence force.

There are some aspects of what is going on in the defence area that I would disagree with. In order to pay for the new capital equipment, with a limited defence vote of roughly 2.3 per cent of gross domestic product, other areas are cut back. The areas that have been cut back on are in the supply support of the Defence Force-the amount of ammunition that can be fired and the amount of training that can be done. Soldiers in the operational deployment force in Townsville, which is a key deployment force, spend $400 of their own money in order to buy satisfactory backpacks. They cannot get satisfactory backpacks out of the service machine. Their snipers are buying their own rifles because the service ones are not satisfactory. The training command has no slouch hats for new recruits.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was boots not long ago.

—It was boots not long ago. These will not destroy our Defence Force, but they are indications of an attitude which permeates the morale of the Defence Force. If members of the Defence Force feel that they are being undersupplied or ignored in this way what happens is that they vote with their feet; they do not re-engage. We have to remember that the training of a private soldier costs $50,000: it costs $50,000 to train a single soldier. It costs several million dollars to train an airman-a pilot. We are penny-wise and pound-foolish-these days I ought to say `cent-wise and dollar-foolish'-if we do not give these people proper equipment, proper pay and proper support, because otherwise they go somewhere else where they are more accepted and rewarded. The losers will be the Government and the country-in the efficiency of the Defence Force-as will be the defence vote, because it costs so much to train their replacements.

SPEECH.PARA: This personnel wastage is the biggest problem we have. It is extraordinary, in view of the level of unemployment, that there is so much personnel wastage. We have to tackle this problem. The Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade has made some recommendations on this. It will have to make many more because the matter is not being seriously tackled. One of the most important statements put down, a very fine one made by Senator Newman-I will not go through it in detail-made recommendations and promises in our defence science and personnel policy to tackle the problems of pay and allowances, Defence Force retirement benefits, to get a better career path for our servicemen and to tackle the very serious problems of accommodation both for single servicemen and married people. It promised that we would look at the problems of removals, personnel support services and family support services.

If we want to keep a high morale, efficient Defence Force, we have to stop this appalling wastage which very seriously lowers the efficiency of our Defence Force. If we want to stop those things we have to tackle them. As I have explained, I agree with quite a lot of the things Mr Beazley has done, but he seems bemused by capital equipment and finds the problems of the people who are going to man, operate and direct this equipment of no interest to him. That is a very serious shortcoming in our defence preparedness and one which the incoming government will have to tackle urgently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it appalling that, despite the assertion that the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has been delivered in a bid to counter suggestions that foreign policy is being subordinated to military planning, all we have is a document which proves that that is exactly the case. Military aspects totally dominate this paper. There are 7 1/2 pages on the military and only 1 1/2 pages on diplomacy and two pages on aid programs. Military aspects come through at every point. It is depressingly obvious that what we have here is a defence-driven foreign policy.

SPEECH.PARA: In his lecture at the Australian National University on 6 December 1988, reprinted by the Australian Fabian Society this year, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade stated that in a very real sense the Hawke Government's defence policy had once and for all liberated Australian foreign policy. What absurd nonsense. What on earth did he mean by liberation? Did he mean liberation from the straitjacket of subservience to willing, grovelling subservience? Foreign policy should be decided before defence policy makes its demands, sets its parameters, limits the boundaries of the operation of our foreign affairs policies. Neighbours, alliances, methodology for peace-building, all need to be identified before defence planners go to their drawing boards.

Defence agreements with the United States of America absolutely and utterly underpin our foreign policy and constrain Australia's role in the region. In this statement we have what some of us have come to refer to as dual rhetoric because it represents the confusion over which direction Australia should be moving in. In the Ray Milne lecture given in April 1989 the Minister referred to the significance of the North-South divide, but he has become trapped between his own inclinations and the old fears of his advisers and their controllers in the United States, who are living out the last days of the Cold War which has so dominated their lives. The Cold War is over and we now have the spectacle of the military desperately looking for a threat to justify Australia's largest peacetime capital expenditure build-up: that is, $25 billion over 15 years. In fact, Australia might well be defined as a country that has always been looking for a threat. As the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) aptly put it to an American journalist four years ago:
I have $6.3 billion in search of a threat.

The new line is that the Asia-West Pacific region is unstable, that new middle ranking powers such as Japan, China and India are emerging as military forces to be contended with, and that Australia must get into the game. The new strategy is regional forward defence as the United States seeks to persuade its allies of the need for burden-sharing to take the financial load off its shoulders. The US has suffered the cost of being the world's global policeman, and its own people are saying, `No more'. The result is this new strategy of self-reliance within ANZUS which is a contradiction in itself, and a continuing high level of military expenditure which is no more justified than the coastal fortifications that we constructed in Australia to ward off the French and the Russians in the nineteenth century.

We cannot seem to shake off this appalling dependence on a great and powerful friend, despite the Minister's unconvincing rhetoric that Australian foreign policy has been liberated. That is a very bad joke. We now find ourselves like someone doing the splits, torn between the reality of where we are in the world, which the Minister recognises, and our total inability to make a break with the past. Australia is like a child who is unable to leave home, even though he has grown up and should have gone out into the world on his own long ago. The dual rhetoric says that we belong to the Asia-Pacific region, that we should improve our understanding of the region, that we should learn Asian languages, and that we should promote trade and investment to develop a more integrated regional economy. The Minister talks of the exchange of people and ideas. That is excellent. I applaud this recognition. Yet at the same time we are told that the threat comes from this same region, although we are never told which countries it might come from or why.

Where foreign policy is not defence-driven it is trade-driven-opportunities for Australians to extract dollars from our neighbours rather than any altruistic motivation. The latest `opportunity' is the Timor Gap Treaty, which will be ratified soon, in mid-air I believe, between Australia and Indonesia. The Timorese, who could justifiably claim to own the resources, were not consulted. Maybe that is why the meeting is being conducted in mid-air. The parties cannot quite decide whose territory is involved.

Embarrassingly, development assistance is given two pages in this 46-page document. Perhaps it is just too embarrassing to talk about, seeing that Australia's contribution to foreign aid is dropping year by year and is currently less than half the United Nations recommended level of 0.7 per cent of gross national product. Australia is in the category of the meanies. Where is our generosity of spirit, which is so obvious among the people? This statement does not reflect that generosity of spirit. What about humanitarian concerns? What about the massive poverty and population problems which beset people in our own region? Australia is so resource rich, so wealthy, but it has no concept of actually sharing the resources it has with people in its region. This is not seen as a good way of building better relationships with them. It is no wonder that there is so little in this paper about foreign aid.

In the recent Budget the Department of Defence received a whopping 9.6 per cent increase. On the other hand, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade received 1.8 per cent, only a small proportion of which is spent on aid. In this paper there is no philosophy, no priority outline, no guidelines for foreign aid. I agree that the foreign aid we do give must be very carefully spent. I acknowledge Senator Schacht's example of Japan's very inappropriate expenditure in some areas in the South Pacific. Obviously, the locals were not consulted. That is a primary priority when setting foreign aid guidelines, but there is nothing about that in this document. It is about time this Government realised that we can achieve good relationships with our neighbours by helping them in environmentally sound self-help projects, which are ultimately in our best interests.

Of course, the Opposition is no better. In fact, it is a lot worse. It proposes to cut the foreign aid budget by at least $100m. That is its promise. That is out of step with the will of the Australian people to be more humanitarian in our region, at least from the point of view of self-interest. The Opposition cannot even see the benefit that Australia could gain by more active foreign aid distribution, preferably through non-government organisations, who are the best deliverers of foreign aid because they are more closely in touch with the people that foreign aid is meant to be helping.

At least lip-service is given in the document to some environmental considerations and there is a short section on non-military threats such as environmental degradation in the region, drugs and illegal immigration. Surely they are the real threats to Australia's security-so often identified by people in the north-west as I was travelling in the Kimberleys during the amazing episode of Kangaroo 89, in which we had to invent an enemy to fight against. People said, `What about illegal drugs? What about illegal immigration? What about illegal fishing?'. That is where we need to be spending our defence dollars.

Another omission I must comment on is that of New Zealand. Senator Hill suggested that this was because of chummy trans-Tasman Labor Party relationships. I suspect that this is not correct. The Minister's excuse for the omission of our close neighbour was unconvincing. We should not take New Zealand for granted, as I think we sometimes do, nor should we underestimate the right of New Zealanders to self-determination. I mention very briefly two cases in point. In the nuclear warships ban, which was initiated in 1984, New Zealand was not supported. In fact, in a letter written by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to the then Prime Minister of New Zealand, David Lange, the Australian Government indicated that Australia was very put out by this because our other alliance partner was put out. In effect, Australia went in to bat for the Americans against our trans-Tasman neighbour on that point. In the second and more recent case, the Anzac frigates project, New Zealand was unmercifully bullied.

Relationships between the trans-Tasman Ministers may be suitably massaged to give the Ministers and their minders the reassuring impression that all is okay, but at the community level the relationship has soured. All is far from okay. The Australian Government should acknowledge that problem, which is of its own making. Maybe that is why New Zealand was left out-another item for the too-hard basket. Again, these problems stem from a fetish with a defence orientation rather than with what foreign policy should be-foreign policy setting the tone, setting the pace, rather than a defence. Unfortunately, this document represents the capitulation of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to the Department of Defence. It seems that the battle between the two departments is all over. There is not even any shouting any more. We have seen this coming with the relaxation of export controls on military equipment and the responsibility for those exports moving from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to the Department of Defence.

I feel very disappointed with this depressing defence-driven document. Really, I had hoped for better from Senator Gareth Evans. The most positive thing I can say about his role since he has taken over the portfolio is that he has been active in promoting human rights concerns in the many countries he has visited. Of course, I do not want to take an entirely critical position, so I offer a constructive alternative. Those of us who are being critical of what we term Australia's new militarism are suggesting that Australia should use these momentous times to recognise the obsolescence of ANZUS and to implement a policy of non-provocative defence that covers Australia and nowhere beyond. Linked with this, there should be an emphasis on implementing measures towards common security in the region, just as the Europeans are also discussing similar proposals and defence strategies for the future of their continent. The Cold War, which has held the continent of Europe in its icy grip for 44 years, is rapidly melting. We need to ask what we can do to respond to this thaw in our own part of the world, or are we too afraid of peace breaking out? More community input into Australia's foreign policy would be a good idea. This would help in formulating a more realistic, compassionate and truly independent foreign policy.

I have a lot more to say, but in deference to other senators I am cutting my speech short at this point in the hope that the favour will be returned at a future time. As an Independent, I am so often either left off the speakers list altogether or put so low on the list that I have to share the available remaining time. I shall conclude my comments in a future adjournment debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main significance of the statement put down by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is that it is a personal statement. It is a political statement which reflects his vocabulary and values. It is clearly not a production of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade or else it would be much more substantial. Most speakers in this debate have said that the statement is thin, that it is lacking in substance and that it is stating the obvious. I can only summarise it in those terms and in this way: it is the kind of statement which any one of us might make to an interested body in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the statement is designed for domestic consumption. An election is coming up which, very likely, will mean the end of the term of office of this Minister in the foreign affairs and trade portfolio. Before the end of that period, the Minister wants to put down his own personal statement about our own region. He got a lot wrong. He left out the global context. He defined South East Asia and the South Pacific in a narrow way-in a way that one might, with few resources and little time, begin to address something that one personally felt to be important but which, inevitably, is dealt with in an inadequate fashion.

There is a brief introductory reference to global matters and to the superpower relativities. References are made in some sentences-and at the most, paragraphs-to Japan, China and Europe. Yet, the developments in Europe and the transition from the two superpower dominated world to a polarity with six major military and economic powers require much more of a statement than these brief and bare references. The final sentence on page 46 of this brief statement gives a clue as to why Senator Evans wanted to put down this personal, last gasp statement about foreign affairs in our region. It is a reaction to the criticisms that many of us have made that there have been too few statements by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and that he feels overshadowed by the 1987 White Paper on defence. Indeed, Mr Beazley, who is seen by many as a competent Minister for Defence and who has brought many gains to this area for Australia's good and for the security of our region, has overshadowed Senator Evans. So the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade wants to try to right the balance. In the last paragraph on page 46 he says:
Australia in the past has tended to perceive the relevance of South East Asia and the South Pacific to Australia's security in largely military terms. We now-
having received the Minister's statement-

have the opportunity to reinforce our national security by utilising the many dimensions of our external policies in an informed, coordinated and vigorous way to participate in the shaping of the regional environment. Effectively implemented and presented, this multidimensional-
Gareth Evans-
approach to regional security policy is the best way of maintaining our national security into the future.

It goes out in a blaze of lights. In making those remarks, particularly the one that describes this statement as stating the obvious, I want to make it clear that the motherhood statements, the obvious statements, in this document are so shared by the majority of senators in this place that we would not want to detract from those universally held aspirations by making any criticisms. We want to see a secure region. We want to have excellent relations in the South Pacific and South East Asia and, indeed, with all of our trading partners and allies in the whole global context.

It is insufficient for the Minister to bring down a glowing, brief, obvious statement and to omit so much that ought to bear upon any sensible discussion in this chamber, let alone in any forum in Australia, of our regional security. The focus of the statement is so narrow that it begs some response to the defence statements of Mr Beazley which are, by necessity, confined to this region of the world-the South Pacific and South East Asia; the immediate neighbours of Australia. I find that the criticisms of the inadequacy of the statement that have been made by so many in this debate stand.

Many ambassadors to this country and many foreign observers will look at this statement in terms of the values and vocabulary of Senator Evans's own mind. It is clear that this statement has Gareth Evans's vocabulary all through it. Much of that is obvious and his aspirations are shared by those in this chamber. Anything that is distinctive in the document, or anything that is new, is best read in the context of understanding what this failing Minister for Foreign Affairs is all about. He is making a last gasp statement before the end of this Hawke Labor Government.

I wish to draw particular attention to two emphases which I think have dangerous aspects. One danger is the way in which Senator Evans describes the United States without any clear reference to ANZUS, without any clear reinforcement of our close alliance. Rather, he gives the expectation that the United States will have less and less interest in the security needs of this region and of Australia as a major ally of the United States. Page 5 of the statement says:

South East Asia and the South Pacific thus may well be relatively less in the focus of the United States priorities than in the past; certainly it would not be useful to assume that the United States will continue to maintain its present level of security interest and activity in this part of the world.
On page 4 of his tabling statement the Minister said:

But with a decline in ideological competition and other global and regional developments, United States attention on the region may well become over time increasingly less geo-political and more oriented to its major economic interests.

The implication is that if it is not in the economic interests of the United States to play any role in the security arrangements of this region, or the Pacific as a whole, it will not do so and that Australia ought to be realistic and change its expectations that what we have always understood is involved in ANZUS is now dated and will no longer occur.

Linked with this is another emphasis which is dangerous in so far as it raises expectations of a security arrangement of a kind that was entered into with the South East Asia Treaty Organisation or the present five power defence arrangements-some sort of North Atlantic Treaty Organisation of the south! On page 20 of the ministerial statement, Senator Evans says:

It might eventually prove possible and appropriate to subsume such arrangements in a wider new regional security community arrangement or understanding, but our objective at this stage should simply be participation in a gradually emerging sense of shared strategic and security interests.
More clearly, in the tabling statement Senator Evans gives the aspiration that:

. . . Australia should use its military assets and presence in the region to help foster the gradual development of a regional security community based on a sense of shared security interests: this is described in the Statement . . .

This politico-military emphasis of Senator Evans is a new emphasis and presumably is taking up the vacuum that will be caused by the end of the United States involvement that he has foreshadowed. I regard both of these statements as new emphases that are dangerous and that will need very careful attention along with much else that is in the statement. As time is no longer available to me, I will seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the hearings of Estimates Committee D, which I attended, Senator Newman asked a question relating to the supply system redevelopment project of the Department of Defence, in which I was also interested. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: I see in the annual report that there is a list of consultants to the Department-one of them is Arthur Young Services-who have undertaken a study to a contract value of $644,539 to identify ways to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of the defence supply services in meeting Defence needs and objectives.
That was on 10 October. She said:
I imagine that that is now completed. Is that correct?

Major-General Grey responded, `That is correct'. Senator Newman then asked, `Can I have a copy of that report?'. Major-General Grey replied, `We would be pleased to provide a copy of that report'. That was on 10 October. I hope that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is in the chamber, will recognise the significance of this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do because it was the day before my birthday.

—I am glad that the Government Deputy Whip recognises this. The Army representatives said they were quite pleased to provide a copy of that $644,000 report. But it has not turned up. It is now December and the report that the Army said it was quite happy to supply in early October is not available. Why is this? Let us face it: the report seemed fairly straightforward. Dr McIntosh of the Department of Defence said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Arthur Young Study deals with warehouse rationalisations and things way beyond simply the computer system.

One imagines that savings of some substance could well emerge from this report; but this Government has not released it. On 28 November, during debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1), Senator Newman asked Senator Richardson whether she could have a copy of this report. This was a month and a half after the undertaking that it would be readily available. Senator Richardson responded:
With regard to the Arthur Young report it is being printed and the Minister for Defence will decide on the date of release when it is available to him.

That was an incredible response given that the report had been completed and a copy was capable of being provided by the Army. Clearly, the bureaucracy, the Ministry or both have found some reason not to provide this document. I want to know that reason. What do they have to hide? Is the Minister trying to hide something? Is the bureaucracy trying to hide something? I want to be convinced that the alleged hold-up in the printing of the report-a report which has been available for two months-is not in fact an excuse for the reprinting of an homogenised, pasteurised report-sanitised for bits that some people perhaps do not want to have included in it.

The question at the Estimates Committee hearing related to the report as it then was and an undertaking was given not only that it would be provided but also that the Army would be pleased to provide it. I want to know whether the document being printed is the same document that was promised to us, or is it a different document? If it is a different document, why have we had to wait such a long time for the unwanted comments to be removed? What concerns me most about this is that I understand that at the moment the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts is presently examining this whole issue of the supply system redevelopment project for the Army. I want to know whether the reason that this report has not been provided to this chamber is that it also has not been provided to the Public Accounts Committee. I fear that may be the reason for the delay. I have no knowledge of that; I do not know what happens on that Committee. It is naturally obliged to carry on in a confidential manner. If the report is good enough to go to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, why is it not good enough to come here? Is it being kept out of both places?

This is grossly unsatisfactory. We have had a whole series of unsatisfactory activities and responses during the Senate Estimates committee hearings this year. I really hope that the Senate decides to take a serious look at this problem. I ask the Minister to look into this and to give a response as quickly as possible. Quite frankly, we deserve a copy of this report. Unless there is some pressing reason, I cannot see why we cannot have it before we rise at the end of this week.

I refer very briefly to one other issue. Today, Senator Robert Ray presented 55 papers to this chamber for debate in the normal 30-minute period for reports. In doing so, he said, `Well, I did not know that they were all going to be dumped in one day. It is not my fault that there were none on Monday or Tuesday and 55 today. Don't blame me.' Well, who are we to blame? It is clearly a stunt by this Government. Many of these reports listed today were delivered to my office on Monday; others were delivered on Tuesday. Why were they not on the lists on those days so that we could use the half-hour available for reports to debate them? It is clearly a stunt to prevent our giving proper scrutiny to these reports. It is remarkable that on the one day that 55 reports are listed we did not even get the half-hour to debate reports because the Senate rises early tonight and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans)-and defence-brought out his statement to be certain that we did not deal with reports today. It is absolutely incredible that this sort of thing goes on.

Clearly the objective of the Government is to try to make it impossible for us to deal with this mountain of reports with which we are being inundated. I bet there will be none listed for tomorrow because we will have a 30-minute period available tomorrow. I bet there will be none listed next Monday or whenever we next sit. It seems as though the Government has saved them up for the days when we cannot debate them. Not only have 55 reports been circulated, but also we have 20 treaties which are included with item 39. Do we get the chance to discuss these? No, we do not, except that we will have an hour tomorrow in general business when these and all the other accumulated reports from recent times-which we have not had time to deal with-will be presented to us.

The Government is treating the Senate with contempt in this matter. It is not as though these reports are inconsequential; there are many annual reports of departments. There is the annual report of the Repatriation Commission and the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and the annual report of the Department of Social Security. There is the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation. Now, there is a lively report. There is the annual report of the Department of Industrial Relations, the annual report of the Department of Transport and Communications, and the annual reports of many major departments which we have every right to look at. There are other reports such as the annual report of the Australian Customs Service, which would be interesting to debate. Honourable senators would remember that the Australian Customs Service complained very strongly about the lax security at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. We have the annual report of the National Companies and Securities Commission, which is a matter of some interest to the Minister who is at the table. We have the annual report of the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions who has made some statements that at least the Minister found interesting at Question Time today. We have the Industries Assistance Commission's report 422 on government non-tax charges. There are four volumes to that report. Volume 3 deals with efficiency issues and public enterprises, which is a matter of major concern to the Opposition. Volume 4 is entitled Studies-Public Rail Freight, Electricity and Workers Compensation Arrangements. These are matters of massive substance. We have a report entitled Schedules of Special Purpose Flights by the Royal Australian Air Force. It is two years out of date-is it not remarkable-yet it was brought on on a day when we could not debate it because we ran out of time before we got to reports. This is a farce. I hope that the Minister, who I know is a decent man and is concerned with the proprieties of this sort of thing, will chide his colleagues and ask whoever the smart alec was who determined this sort of procedure perhaps to try a little harder to give some proper respect to the requirements of the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has the Government taken, since receipt of the report, in relation to each of the 73 recommendations set out at pages (xi) to (xxvi) of the (Altman) Report on the Review of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account of December 1984?
(2) In cases where no action has been taken to give effect to a recommendation, for what reason was no action taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Action taken in relation to the recommendations of the Report on the Review of the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account (ABTA) and, where relevant, reasons why certain recommendations have not been put into effect, are described below, with reference to each of the numbered recommendations in the Report.

1a The Government has accepted in principle the thrust of the major recommendations in the Report. Action has been taken towards a staged introduction of the major recommendations. Where some of those actions have not been completed a major consideration has been recent trends in the level of the ABTA's royalty equivalent income and Land Councils' administrative costs.
1b Measures have been adopted to increase the autonomy of the ABTA Advisory Committee, as detailed below. The matter of complete Aboriginal control of the ABTA is still under consideration.

1c (i) It was not found to be necessary to retain the working party as an advisory body because the Government has staged the implementation of recommendations and has established an ABTA Sub-Committee to assist the ABTA Advisory Committee in its annual policy formulation. Refer to answer to paragraph 5g.

1c (ii) Aspects of the Report's recommendations and the structure of the ABTA are being considered in investigations currently being conducted into ways to overcome the decrease of the ABTA's reserve funds.
1d The Report was widely circulated. I understand that my predecessor was informed of the views expressed by interested parties.
1e The specific recommendations made at the end of each chapter of the Report have received consideration.
2a and 2b The recommendation that the ABTA be divided into two distinct trust accounts will be considered in the context of the proposal that the ABTA become an autonomous statutory body.

3a This recommendation will be included in consideration of the division of the ABTA into two distinct trust accounts. This matter is also being considered in the context of the current investigation of ABTA financial matters.

3b The ABTA Advisory Committee, with the assistance of the Sub-Committee, has formulated positive policies relating to investments and grants. These policies are subject to annual review by the Advisory Committee.
4a and 4b See the answer to paragraphs 2a and 2b.

4c The Present ABTA Secretariat has established an office in Darwin physically separate from the office of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. No regional office has been established in Alice Springs due to a lack of resources.

4d and 4e No small regional offices of the present ABTA Secretariat have been established. The co-operation of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and other relevant agencies is sought in relation to the assessment of grant applications.

4f The budget of the present ABTA Secretariat, which is funded by subsection 64 (5) payments from the ABTA, is approved by the Minister's delegate, the Northern Territory State Director of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The present ABTA Secretariat submits audited annual financial statements to the Auditor-General and to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in accordance with section 41d of the Audit Act 1901. The Auditor-General reports to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on matters covered by the financial statements.

4g A separate ABTA has not been established and there is no power under the present Act for the Minister to require an audit of the present ABTA or withhold the payment of mining royalty equivalents into the ABTA. The Australian Audit Office conducts annual audits of the ABTA's accounts and records (see answer to paragraph 4f).

5a The recommendation that the name of the ABTA Advisory Committee be changed to the ABTA Committee will be considered in the context of proposals that the ABTA become an autonomous body. In electing members to the Advisory Committee, Land Councils have been asked to consider candidates most suitable to fulfilling the tasks now undertaken by the Advisory Committee having regard to the criteria suggested in the Report.

5b and 5c The size of the Advisory Committee has been increased to twelve members. There are six members from the region of the Northern Land Council, four members from the region of the Central Land Council and one from the Tiwi Land Council.

5d The Chairmanship of the Advisory Committee has remained a Ministerial appointment with a fixed term of three years. The policy of rotating the Chairmanship between Chairmen resident in the northern and central regions of the Northern Territory has been adopted.

5e Members of the Advisory Committee are elected from time to time by Land Councils in accordance with paragraph 65 (1) (b) of the Act. The Land Councils are aware of the Report's recommendation that they elect Advisory Committee members to serve a two year term, with the possibility of a further term.

5f The ABTA Advisory Committee is actively involved in the formulation of expenditure policies and the development of guidelines for the assessment of grant applications. These policies and guidelines and the general performance of the ABTA are subject to annual review by the Advisory Committee.

5g An ABTA Sub-Committee has been established, consisting of the Chairman of the ABTA Advisory Committee, the Manager of the ABTA Secretariat, the Directors of the Northern and Central Land Councils, a nominee of the Tiwi Land Council Executive and the Northern Territory State Director of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The Sub-Committee provides advice to the ABTA Advisory Committee on policy formulation and grants assessment as recommended in the Report.

5h The Chairman of the Advisory Committee has been given a delegation to approve grants of up to $100,000, in Committee, upon the advice of the Sub-Committee. The limit of the delegation will be reviewed.

5i ABTA Advisory Committee and Sub-Committee procedures have been formulated. The incorporation of procedural requirements in the Act will be considered in the context of the proposal that the ABTA become an autonomous statutory body.
6a New policies and guidelines have been formulated by the ABTA Advisory Committee, with the assistance of the Sub-Committee.

6b This matter will be examined when the division of the present ABTA into two trust accounts is considered. The ABTA Advisory Committee has established a policy that grant approvals will be limited to $5 million per annum for five years, with the remaining moneys available being put into long-term investments.

6c The policies and guidelines used in the assessment of grant applications are subject to annual review by the ABTA Advisory Committee, with the assistance of the Sub-Committee. At these policy meetings the Advisory Committee establishes categories under which funding proposals are considered and sets restrictions on the funding available under particular categories.
6d These recommendations are being complied with in the context of the present system.
6e The ABTA now publishes annual reports which include information on grant approvals.

6f The Act enables loans to be made from the ABTA, but no loans have been made since the Trust Account was established. Loans made by the previous Aboriginal Benefits Trust Fund have been transferred to the ABTA.
7a The NTATA has not been established. Refer to answers to paragraphs 2a, 2b and 3a.
7b Refer to answer to paragraph 6b.
7c The NTATA has not been established. Refer to answer to paragraphs 2a, 2b and 3a.

7d, 7e, 7f and 7g The investment options of the ABTA remain within restrictions set by the Audit Act 1901. The ABTA Secretariat is consulting with the Department of Finance concerning ways to maximise returns on investment. Investment options available to the ABTA, should it become an autonomous statutory body, will be considered at an appropriate time.
8a and 8b The ABTA Advisory Committee has adopted the policy that, in general, the ABTA will not provide funding for projects which fall within the responsibility of other Government agencies.
8c The Commonwealth has taken the view that the Northern Territory has a proper role to play in funding the provision of services to Aboriginal people.

9a and 9b As indicated earlier, the NTATA has not been established. On 19 June 1987, the Minister for Finance approved a determination under section 41d of the Audit Act 1901 for the purpose of having the accounts and records of the present ABTA subject to an annual audit by the Australian Audit Office. As a result, the ABTA now provides an annual report which includes audited financial statements. The annual report is tabled in the Parliament. The ABTA is covered in the Auditor-General's reports on the Aboriginal Affairs Portfolio. Reference is made to the activities of the ABTA in the annual report of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

9c Information concerning details and results of grant applications is provided to the Land Councils and to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs within a month of each grants meeting. Individual applicants are also advised of the result of their applications within that time.

9d and 9e Applications for grants are invited well in advance of the grants meetings of the ABTA Advisory Committee. Advertisements informing Aboriginals of grants policies are placed in the Northern Territory newspapers and the Land Rights News. Application forms include information on the ABTA's role and policies, administrative guidelines, application assessment factors and categories for funding. This method of seeking applications reaches a large number of Aboriginals and generates a large number of applications. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs and ABTA newsletters are no longer published and radio is not used for dissemination of information on grants.

10a This recommendation has not been implemented because of doubts as to whether it offers a realistic alternative to supplementary funding arrangements for Land Councils. The exemptions of Land Councils from mining withholding tax was referred to the Treasurer in 1985 but was not agreed to at that time. The matter of mining withholding tax is currently under further consideration.
10b This recommendation has not been implemented because the administrative expenses of the Northern and Central Land Councils exceed the moneys available under subsection 64 (1) of the Act.
10c The Act has not been amended but procedures and a timetable related to the submission, evaluation and approval of Land Councils' estimates have been approved by the Minister.

10d In accordance with section 34c of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 the Land Councils are required to submit their annual reports to the Minister within six months of the end of the financial year. The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 has been amended, by the addition of subsection 37a (3), to require the Minister to table Land Councils' annual reports and financial statements in the Parliament.
10e This recommendation has been implemented.
11a This recommendation will be included in the consideration of the division of the ABTA into two distinct trust accounts.
11b Paragraph 35 (2) (b) of the Act has been amended by the insertion of the phrase ``or are the traditional Aboriginal owners of'' after the words ``live in''.

11c Subsection 35 (2) of the Act already provided that Land Councils distribute the relevant moneys within six months of their receipt by the Land Council. Subsections 35 (3) and 35 (4) have been amended to require distribution of moneys within the same period. Subsection 35 (9) has been added to the Act to enable Aboriginal recipients of moneys under subsections 35 (1), 35 (2), 35 (3), 35 (4) and 35 (6) to request a Land Council to hold these moneys in trust.

11d This recommendation has been addressed by the addition of subsections 35 (5) and 35 (6) to the Act. Subsection 35 (5) requires a Land Council to report to the Minister if it fails to disburse moneys under subsections 35 (1), 35 (2) and 35 (3) within the required time limit because it has not been able to make a determination on disbursement. Under subsection 35 (6), the Minister may then make a determination upon which the Land Council is required to act.

11e The Act has been amended accordingly by the addition of subsections 35 (8), 35 (10) and 35 (11). Before the Act was amended, royalty trust accounts had been established by the Northern and Central Land Councils to receive payments under section 35 of the Act. These trust accounts now fulfil the purposes of the above amendments. The Tiwi Land Council distributes section 35 moneys as soon as they become available and has not established a trust fund.
11f This recommendation has been put into effect by the addition of subsection 37a (1a) to the Act.

11g The Act has been amended by the addition of subsection 35 (12), which requires Aboriginal communities and groups entitled to receive moneys under section 35 to be incorporated under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976 unless they received section 35 moneys prior to the commencement of this subsection.

11h The Act has been amended accordingly by the addition of section 35a. There is ongoing monitoring by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Land Councils of the use of these moneys by recipient groups.

12a It is proposed that an amendment be made to subsection 63 (3) of the Act to enable the payment into the ABTA from the Consolidated Revenue Fund of amounts directly equivalent to royalties received by the Northern Territory under the Mineral Royalty Act 1982.

12b The recommendation that the Commonwealth investigate the possibility of annually adjusting the Northern Territory's General Revenue Assistance Grants, taking into account royalties raised by the Northern Territory on Aboriginal land has not been pursued. Its adoption would be contrary to principles followed by the Commonwealth Grants Commission which considers such grants on a revenue neutral basis.
12c The amendment referred to in paragraph 12a above is in accordance with the principle that mining royalty equivalents are pegged to actual royalties paid by miners.

12d Refer to answer to paragraph 12a. This amendment will overcome delays in the transfer into the ABTA of mining royalty equivalents related to the Northern Territory Mineral Royalty Act 1982. Delays between receipt of other royalties and payment of equivalents into the ABTA have not been a significant problem. The Act has not been amended to specify that royalty equivalents be paid into the ABTA within thirty days because, under its existing administrative procedures, the ABTA Secretariat is able to achieve the transfer of mining royalty equivalents from the Consolidated Revenue Fund within a short time of receiving notification of the amount of royalties paid.
12e Refer to answer to paragraph 12d.
13a and 13b Refer to answer to paragraph 10a.

14a and 14b ABTA moneys are not used for the fencing of Aboriginal Land Trust areas. The Aboriginal Development Commission and the ABTA are aware of ongoing financial liabilities including the cost of boundary fencing associated with pastoral properties bought with their funds.
15a, 15b, 15c and 15d Refer to answer to paragraph 3a.
